title: What if someone asked "What if?"
abstract: Research Highlights was a newsletter highlighting the research being done at the Boston University School of Management (Questrom School of Business).MBC (MANAGEMENT BY CURIOSITY) The great advances always come from asking the right questions. The questions throughout this booklet reflect some of the ways Boston University School of Management alumni have transformed academic experience into professional results. Curiosity is a positive force, because good management is about exploring, not accepting. It's about revision, refinement, and rethinking rather than regurgitation. It's a matter of taking the heat rather than taking shelter. It's a career of challenging yourself and your employees continually to improve the quality of your products and service. And it's the kind of management you'll learn at Boston University
summary: This document, "Research Highlights," is a newsletter from the Boston University School of Management (Questrom School of Business), emphasizing "Management by Curiosity" (MBC). It showcases how alumni transformed academic experience into professional results by asking critical questions and embracing exploration over acceptance. A key example illustrates a Gillette Corporation Assistant Product Manager's successful million-dollar prize marketing campaign for the Gillette Sensor razor, achieving high awareness and sales. The publication highlights the importance of challenging oneself and employees for continuous improvement in product and service quality, and the breadth of course selection available at the university. It concludes with information on admissions and financial aid, emphasizing academic achievement.

summary: This bulletin provides comprehensive information for graduate programs at Boston University's School of Management for the academic year 1980-1981. The document outlines Boston University's organizational structure, listing its various schools and colleges, specifying which admit undergraduate or graduate students. It also includes important disclaimers regarding the university's right to modify programs, schedules, and course content. This bulletin serves as a key resource for prospective and current graduate students at the School of Management, providing essential academic and administrative details.

title: CORPORATE SOCIAL RESPONSIBILITY IN ROMANIA
abstract: The purpose of this paper is to identify the main opportunities and limitations of corporate social responsibility (CSR). The survey was defined with the aim to involve the highest possible number of relevant CSR topics and give the issue a more wholesome perspective. It provides a basis for further comprehension and deeper analyses of specific CSR areas. The conditions determining the success of CSR in Romania have been defined in the paper on the basis of the previously cumulative knowledge as well as the results of various researches. This paper provides knowledge which may be useful in the programs promoting CSR.Corporate social responsibility, Supportive policies, Romania
fieldOfStudy: Business, Corporate Social Responsibility, Management, Marketing
summary: This paper identifies the main opportunities and limitations of corporate social responsibility (CSR) by involving a wide range of relevant CSR topics to provide a holistic perspective. It examines the conditions determining CSR success in Romania, leveraging existing knowledge and research findings. The study's purpose is to offer insights that can inform and support CSR promotion programs. Key methods involve a comprehensive survey approach and synthesis of cumulative knowledge. The findings are useful for further comprehension and deeper analyses of specific CSR areas, particularly in a Romanian context, focusing on supportive policies for CSR implementation.

title: Improving water productivity: how do we get more crop from every drop
abstract: Water management / Productivity / Irrigation management / Supplemental irrigation / Crop production
authors: International Water Management Institute (IWMI) / Comprehensive Assessment of Water Management in Agriculture
fieldOfStudy: Business, Water Management, Irrigation Management, Crop Production
summary: This document explores strategies to improve water productivity in agriculture, aiming to reduce the need for additional freshwater withdrawals globally. It highlights that agriculture consumes 70% of the world's freshwater and suggests a 40% improvement in water productivity could eliminate further withdrawals. The text discusses the water crisis, evidenced by salinization, declining water tables, and degraded aquatic ecosystems, particularly noting issues in Central Asia and the Yellow River basin. It emphasizes the importance of research and policy actions in water management, irrigation management, and crop production for sustainable water use.

title: Water Figures: quarterly newsletter of the International Water Management Institute (IWMI).
fieldOfStudy: Business, Water Management, Agricultural Research, Knowledge Sharing
summary: This newsletter from the International Water Management Institute (IWMI) focuses on 'Putting Knowledge to Work' in water management and agricultural research, aligning with the Millennium Development Goals. It highlights the GFAR 2006 Triennial Conference, discussing reorienting agricultural research and blending knowledge systems. Key initiatives include engaging with ungauged basins, the Global Irrigated Area Mapping (GIAM) project, and the Global Wetland Inventory and Mapping (GWIM). The issue also covers an interview on knowledge sharing in research and recent publications, emphasizing IWMI's research on irrigated areas using remote sensing and international collaborations for sustainable water resource development.

abstract: Research institutes / Strategy planning / Financial situation / Research priorities / Research projects / Project planning / Maintenance costs / Water resource management / Irrigated farming

summary: This document outlines the International Water Management Institute's (IWMI) Medium Term Plan for 2010-2012, detailing its strategic objectives and project portfolio. It includes an overview of the plan, financial indicators, and four key project areas: Water Availability and Access, Productive Water Use, Water Quality, Health and Environment, and Water and Society. The plan covers research priorities, project planning, and addresses challenges in water resource management and irrigated farming. It also lists numerous acronyms and abbreviations relevant to international agricultural research and development.

title: Promoting cooperation through management of transboundary water resources
abstract: Water resource managementInternational watersRiver basin managementInternational cooperation
fieldOfStudy: Business Water Resource Management International Cooperation
summary: This document challenges the conventional "water wars" hypothesis, arguing that while some historical conflicts over transboundary water resources occurred, cooperation is far more common globally. Research by IWMI scientists and Aaron Wolf at Oregon State University indicates that most of the world's approximately 300 shared river basins have positive records of cooperation. The paper promotes transboundary water resource management as a means to foster cooperation, overcome disputes, and address climate change uncertainties, informing policymakers and future water specialists on effective institutional design and monitoring.

title: IWMI Strategic plan 2009-2013: water for a food-secure world
abstract: Strategy planning / Research institutes / Institutional development / Research priorities / Water resource management / Water governance
fieldOfStudy: Business, Water Resource Management, Institutional Development
summary: This Strategic Plan outlines the International Water Management Institute's (IWMI) vision, mission, and guiding principles for 2009-2013, addressing global challenges like population growth, poverty, and the world food crisis exacerbated by water scarcity. It details four research themes: water availability and access, productive water use, water quality/health/environment, and water and society, emphasizing scientific and socioeconomic solutions. The plan also covers stakeholder engagement, capacity building, and core values, highlighting the critical role of water resource management in ensuring food security and sustainable development.

title: Water Figures: quarterly newsletter of the International Water Management Institute (IWMI).
summary: This document, the "WATER FIGURES" newsletter from the International Water Management Institute, discusses various water and energy management topics. It announces an International Conference on linkages between energy and water management for agriculture in developing countries, aiming to foster collaboration and joint research. Contents include discussions on spatial data, water resources management, sanitation in cities, wastewater solutions, and Outcome Mapping for knowledge sharing and evaluation. The newsletter also highlights sustainable development conferences in Hyderabad and Delhi, and a global forum on science, technology, and innovation capacity for sustainable growth and poverty reduction. Key themes involve integrating monitoring, evaluation, and knowledge sharing for improved project impact.

title: Water Figures Africa: news of IWMI’s work in Africa
abstract: River basin management, Wetlands, Public health, Malaria, Ghana, Ethiopia
fieldOfStudy: Business, Water Management, Agriculture, Public Health
summary: This document, "Water Figures Africa | Issue 1, 2007," by IWMI, focuses on sustainable water management and its implications for public health and agriculture in Africa. It highlights the SWITCH project's response to urban water challenges, including demand management, eco-sanitation, and pollution control, with IWMI leading research on urban water use for livelihoods. The publication also discusses a tradeoffs analysis approach to wetland management in the Limpopo River, malaria cases near Koka Reservoir, and outreach activities of the Small Reservoirs Project. Furthermore, it covers EMBRAPA's efforts to adapt Brazilian agricultural technologies, such as improved crop varieties and integrated pest management, for African regions like Ghana and Ethiopia.

It defines strategy as a vision of an organization's future, essential course elements, and their justification. The strategy covers strategic areas, elements of irrigation management, IIMI's themes, collaborative field research, thematic research, management training, and information services. title: Irrigation management transfer: how to make it work for Africa’s smallholders?
abstract: Water management / Privatization / Small scale systems / Small holders / Africa
fieldOfStudy: Business, Water Management, Privatization, Small-scale Systems, Small Holders, Africa
summary: This briefing reviews international experiences with Irrigation Management Transfer (IMT) and argues that many African smallholder schemes, as currently envisioned, are unlikely to survive. The authors contend that for IMT to be successful in the African smallholder context, governments must first focus on enhancing the income-creation potential of smallholder irrigated farming by strengthening market access, promoting high-value crops, and improving extension and technical support. This approach, prioritizing wealth creation over direct management transfer, is crucial for fostering an environment where IMT can genuinely benefit farmers and improve livelihoods.

title: Water Figures: quarterly newsletter of the International Water Management Institute (IWMI).
abstract: Groundwater irrigation, Electrification, Biofuels, Sedimentation, Catchment areas, India
summary: This newsletter issue from the International Water Management Institute focuses on water as a high priority on the development agenda. It covers various topics including changing consumption patterns and their implications for future food and water demand in India, the poverty reduction potential of groundwater irrigation and rural electrification in eastern India, and a contribution to the biofuels debate, specifically "Biofuels and implications for agricultural water use: blue impacts of green energy." The publication also discusses maize and cassava as major sources of sediments from catchments, and announces upcoming water-related conferences.

Published in June 2003, the report details efforts to improve water resources development, water resource management, and institutional development through strategic development plans. It emphasizes the importance of robust frameworks for managing water resources effectively across regions, providing key insights into institutional structures and policy recommendations for sustainable water management. Keywords: water management, institutions, water resources, development plans, institutional development, Asian Development Bank, International Water Management Institute.

title: Pro-poor intervention strategies in irrigated agriculture: lessons from the Asian experience
abstract: Irrigation management / Poverty / Women / Water rights / Water allocation / User charges / Asia / China / Vietnam
fieldOfStudy: Business, Irrigation Management, Poverty Reduction, Water Allocation
summary: This briefing examines how irrigated agriculture, a major contributor to Asian food security, can reduce poverty by deliberately prioritizing the poor. It highlights the necessity of an integrated approach by policymakers and managers, emphasizing that the right institutional, technical, incentives, and management practices are crucial for pro-poor irrigation projects to significantly impact regional poverty. The document draws lessons from experiences in Bangladesh, China, India, Indonesia, Pakistan, and Vietnam, focusing on the sensitivity of poverty to irrigation projects and the historical productivity upturns following the Green Revolution.

title: Water Figures: quarterly newsletter of the International Water Management Institute (IWMI).
summary: This newsletter announces a collaboration between IWMI and WorldFish, appointing a joint Corporate Services Director and planning a shared Information and Knowledge Group to enhance efficiency and reduce costs. It also covers topics such as IWMI's gender and diversity goals, irrigation system changes in Ethiopia, health impacts of small dams in Morocco, progress reviews of CGIAR's Water and Food Challenge Program, and an interview on the Karkheh River Basin project. A new book, "Irrigation and Drainage Performance Assessment: Practical Guidelines," is highlighted, focusing on improving water management and performance assessment in irrigated agriculture.

title: State-of-the-art approaches for evidence-based springshed management to increase resilience to climate change in Nepal
abstract:
• A thorough understanding of spring systems is essential to design evidence-based springshed interventions. The necessary information can be collected by conducting hydrometeorological monitoring, hydrogeological assessments and
isotope analysis.
• Springs are recharged by a combination of both surface water and groundwater sources that may extend beyond administrative and surface water boundaries. Identification of the nature and seasonality of springs provides a basis for prioritization of springs and design of interventions.
• Considering a broader landscape approach, integrating the management of forests, agricultural fields, soils and water systems
over larger areas, is recommended for longterm springshed management and to ensure adequate water supplies under conditions of climate change
publisher: CGIAR Research Program on Water, Land and Ecosystems
fieldOfStudy: Business, Water Management, Climate Change, Hydrology, Hydrogeology
summary: This document outlines state-of-the-art approaches for evidence-based springshed management to enhance resilience to climate change in Nepal. It emphasizes that a thorough understanding of spring systems, achieved through hydrometeorological monitoring, hydrogeological assessments, and isotope analysis, is crucial. Springs are recharged by surface and groundwater sources, potentially extending beyond administrative boundaries, and identifying their nature and seasonality aids prioritization. The study recommends adopting a broader landscape approach, integrating forest, agriculture, soil, and water system management, for long-term springshed management and ensuring adequate water supplies under climate change. This is vital for the 13 million people reliant on springs in Nepal.

title: ICLARM annual report
abstract: A report of the Center's activities during the year.ICLARM, Annual reports
authors: International Center for Living Aquatic Resources Management
summary: This annual report details the activities of ICLARM – The World Fish Center in 2000, focusing on its re-establishment in Penang, Malaysia, and the Board's meetings, including one in Egypt. The report highlights the Center's global programs aimed at the poorest regions of Sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia, with offices and projects in numerous countries. Specific initiatives include beneficiary-based management of inland fisheries in Bangladesh, integrated aquaculture-agriculture technologies in Cameroon and Malawi, marine protected area studies in the Caribbean, aquaculture research in Egypt, and development of global databases in the Philippines. The Center also works on species improvement and profitable farming methods for various aquatic resources.

title: Links between environmental management and the company's other management systems especially the quality mangement system
fieldOfStudy: Business Management, Quality Management, Environmental Management
summary: This research explores the crucial links between a company's environmental management and its other existing management systems, with a particular focus on the quality management system. The article, published in Børsens Miljøhåndbog in 1999, investigates how these systems can be integrated for improved organizational efficiency and sustainability. Key themes include system integration, environmental standards, quality control, and holistic corporate management practices. This work is valuable for understanding interdependencies in corporate governance and operational excellence.

title: Enterprise Vocabulary Management; a Lexicographic View
abstract: The central theme in this paper is the problem of shifting from natural language descriptions, as in traditional dictionaries and thesauri, to working IT (Information Technology) systems that support people carrying out their administrative tasks. An explicit description of the specific language used in an organization is necessary to guarantee properly working IT systems and a healthy flow of information. Traditionally, there are different ways of capturing such a vocabulary. Different options are considered, arguing that the general form of a thesaurus offers the optimal solution for a broad range of cases. Various requirements for such a thesaurus are examined. A real world example is discussed in some detail. Finally, the paper examines how modern Web technology can help optimizing the creation, management and use of enterprise thesauri. Using these technologies, the enterprise thesaurus can take up new roles in managing the information household of an organization
summary: This paper addresses the challenge of transitioning from natural language descriptions in traditional dictionaries and thesauri to functional IT systems for administrative tasks. It emphasizes the need for explicit organizational language descriptions to ensure effective IT systems and information flow. The authors argue that a general thesaurus form offers an optimal solution, examining its requirements and discussing a real-world example. The paper concludes by exploring how modern Web technology can optimize the creation, management, and utilization of enterprise thesauri, enabling them to play new roles in organizational information management. Keywords include information technology, enterprise vocabulary, lexicography, thesauri, and web technology.

title: SDN management layer: design requirements and future direction
abstract: Computer networks are becoming more and more complex and difficult to manage. The research community has been expending a lot of efforts to come up with a general management paradigm that is able to hide the details of the physical infrastructure and enable flexible network management. Software Defined Networking (SDN) is such a paradigm that simplifies network management and enables network innovations. In this survey paper, by reviewing existing SDN management layers (platforms), we identify the general common management architecture for SDN networks, and further identify the design requirements of the management layer that is at the core of the architecture. We also point out open issues and weaknesses of existing SDN management layers. We conclude with a promising future direction for improving the SDN management layer.This work is supported in part by the National Science Foundation (NSF grant CNS-0963974)
fieldOfStudy: Business, Software Defined Networking, Network Management
summary: This survey paper investigates Software Defined Networking (SDN) as a paradigm for simplifying network management in increasingly complex computer networks. The research aims to identify a common management architecture for SDN networks, pinpointing the design requirements for its core management layer. By reviewing existing SDN management platforms, the authors highlight open issues and weaknesses, concluding with promising future directions for improvement. This work contributes to advancing flexible network management and innovation within SDN environments.

title: The energy-irrigation nexus
abstract: Water management / Energy
authors: International Water Management Institute, IWMI-TATA Water Policy Program
summary: This document examines rational power supply and pricing policies for pump irrigation as a tool for managing groundwater and energy use, particularly in South Asia. It proposes that while consumption-linked pricing improves efficiency, the popular metered tariff faces high transaction costs and farmer resistance, especially for millions of small users. A more feasible alternative is a transformed, rational flat-rate tariff combined with power supply restrictions. The paper highlights the unsustainable legacy of electricity subsidies, leading to overuse of water and energy, threatening power sector viability and groundwater resources, and impacting livelihoods.

title: MANAGEMENT DECISION MAKING IN MARKETING
summary: This text explores the theoretical bases of management decision-making in marketing, advocating for their adaptation and utilization within Ukraine's crisis conditions. It defines marketing broadly, encompassing consumer needs, preferences, purchasing habits, and product promotion strategies. The author emphasizes that management marketing involves complex functions like organization, motivation, and control, which are crucial for achieving tactical and strategic goals. The text highlights the difficulty in distinguishing administrative decisions from marketing-specific ones in practice, arguing that most decisions influence market relations. Ultimately, the core principle is to identify market needs, develop and implement marketing strategies, and provide superior satisfaction compared to competitors, adapting to dynamic market environments through innovation and promotion.

title: Leapfrogging the value chain through aquaculture
authors: CGIAR Research Program on Water, Land and Ecosystems
publisher: CGIAR Research Program on Water, Land and Ecosystems
summary: This document outlines a business model for aquaculture using treated wastewater to grow fish feed or raise fish directly, aiming for profit generation to sustain treatment plant operations and recover capital costs while providing treated wastewater to local populations. It details business characteristics, including geographical considerations for land availability and market demand, production scale (200-2,000 m3 wastewater intake/day), and typical organization as public-private partnerships. Key aspects include investment costs (USD 20,000-100,000), capital investment in fish and ponds, O&M, marketing, and revenue streams from fish and crop sales, and optional water treatment service payments. Performance indicators from 2012 show a payback period under 10 years and a 26% rate of return. This model offers an inexpensive source of fish and crops, part-time jobs, and an environmentally safe treated effluent.

title: The challenges of integrated river basin management in India
abstract: River basins / Hydrology / Water management / Water harvesting / Groundwater management / Drip irrigation / Institutional development / India / China / Sri Lanka / Australia
authors: International Water Management Institute, IWMI-TATA Water Policy Program
fieldOfStudy: Business, water management, hydrology, institutional development
summary: This document critically examines the transferability of Integrated River Basin Management (IRBM) solutions from developed countries like Australia and the USA to developing nations such as India and China. It argues that while IRBM is a powerful concept, ready-made institutional models often fail when imposed without tailoring to local realities, citing India's Damodar Valley Authority as an example. The paper highlights the need for context-specific approaches to water management, institutional development, and agricultural water use efficiency to achieve effective river basin management in these regions. Keywords: Integrated River Basin Management, water management, institutional development, India, China.

title: Bringing pumps to people: giving the poor better access to groundwater irrigation: sustainable approaches and options for eastern India
abstract: Groundwater irrigation / Pumps / Tube wells / Energy / Electricity supplies / Poverty / India
authors: International Water Management Institute, IWMI-TATA Water Policy Program
fieldOfStudy: Business, Water Management, Agricultural Economics, Development Studies
summary: This document explores how to improve poor people's access to groundwater irrigation in eastern India, focusing on sustainable approaches and lessons from tube-well programs in eastern Uttar Pradesh and north Bihar. It highlights that while small pumps have energized agrarian economies by enabling food and cash crop cultivation, public tube-well programs have largely failed due to bureaucratic inefficiencies and centralized control, contrasting with the decentralized management needed at the village level. The text emphasizes the need for public initiatives to adapt from their initial role of technology introduction to current farmer-led needs, suggesting a shift from institutional thinking to local realities for effective groundwater management and poverty reduction. Keywords: groundwater irrigation, tube wells, poverty, India, agricultural development, water policy.

title: Rethinking tank rehabilitation: issues in restoring old tanks to their original state in irrigation structure
abstract: Tank irrigation / Rehabilitation / India
authors: International Water Management Institute, IWMI-TATA Water Policy Program
fieldOfStudy: Business, Water Resources Management, Agricultural Research, Environmental Policy
summary: This Water Policy Briefing, based on research by Tushaar Shah and K.V. Raju, argues against renovating old irrigation tanks solely for their original purpose. It highlights that these tanks, even in disrepair, offer valuable socio-ecological services beyond just irrigation to local communities. The paper advocates for a rehabilitation strategy that considers all current socio-ecological activities and their values, rather than just irrigation efficiency, to avoid depriving communities of these broader benefits. The research focuses on tanks in various South Asian locations, including Rajasthan, South Bihar, and Sri Lanka.

title: TENDENCIES OF INTERNATIONALIZATION IN RETAILING
abstract: Manufacturing companies took advantage of internationalization as early as in the seventies and eighties of the last century, whereas retail companies have used these chances not before the last few years in order to improve access to resources, to increase sales and to extend activities to external markets. Once a retail company has decided to penetrate a foreign market they must be aware of the unfamiliar working of external environment that they cannot control. Even the world's leading retailers make mistakes when approaching markets they do not understand properly.retailing; internationalization; elements of external environment; behavioural polyvalence; consumers' orientation
summary: This article explores the internationalization tendencies within the retailing sector, contrasting its later adoption compared to manufacturing companies. It highlights that retail companies have recently pursued international expansion to access resources, increase sales, and extend market reach. The authors emphasize the critical need for retail companies to understand and adapt to unfamiliar external environments when entering foreign markets, as even leading global retailers make mistakes due to a lack of proper market comprehension. Key concepts include retailing, internationalization, external environment elements, behavioral polyvalence, and consumer orientation, crucial for effective global marketing strategies.

title: SIZE AND FIELD OF ACTIVITY INFLUENCE ON WEB SITES FUNCTIONALITY FOR ROMANIAN COMPANIES
abstract: The internet became an important part of the company's informational system. In order to take advantage on the Internet's interactive nature, a lot of companies have created their own websites. Companies use the website for numerous applications: to promote themselves, online shopping, and communication with targeted clients. This study reveals the fact that the company's size and field of activity have influence on website's functionality and interactivity. Small companies use the website to successfully compete corporations which do not have yet necessary stimulants to fully exploit the internet capacities.websites, informational system, company's promotion, market studies, on line selling, targeted audience communication
summary: This study investigates the influence of company size and field of activity on website functionality and interactivity for Romanian companies. As the internet has become integral to informational systems, companies leverage websites for promotion, online shopping, and client communication. The research reveals that smaller companies utilize websites effectively to compete against larger corporations, which may not fully exploit internet capabilities. Key findings indicate that both company size and activity sector significantly impact a website's features and interactive potential. Keywords include: websites, informational system, company promotion, market studies, online selling, targeted audience communication.

title: OMG/CORBA: An object-oriented middleware
fieldOfStudy: Business, Middleware, Distributed Systems, Software Architecture
summary: This paper focuses on OMG/CORBA, a prominent middleware standard for constructing heterogeneous and distributed software systems. It discusses CORBA's object model and its representation in the OMG Interface Definition Language (IDL), demonstrating how components written in various programming languages can be integrated using CORBA's language bindings. The authors differentiate between static and dynamic invocations, outline higher-level CORBA services, and mention recent standardization efforts by the OMG, emphasizing its role in integrating legacy and commercial off-the-shelf components in corporate IT systems.

title: USE OF ICT IN SMES MANAGEMENT WITHIN THE SECTOR OF SERVICES
abstract: This study investigates how the use of ICT could contribute to the success of small and medium enterprises (SMEs) within the sector of services. Within the knowledge-based economy, SMEs are facing both opportunities and challenges due to the information and communication technologies development. We consider that ICT should be used in small business management within the sector of services because ICT are key tools in management processes and could improve managerial practices. The study is based on evidence provided by articles and research reports. The research question was answered by analysing published sources and interpreting evidence. Another way of approaching this question could be collecting and analysing empirical data from the SMEs within the sector of services and comparing the results with the findings of this study.information and communication technologies, small and medium enterprises, management, services, knowledge-based economy
fieldOfStudy: Business, management, information and communication technologies, small and medium enterprises, knowledge-based economy
summary: This study investigates the contribution of Information and Communication Technologies (ICT) to the success of Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) in the services sector. It aims to reveal and analyze key factors for implementing ICT in small business management, recognizing ICT as vital tools for improving managerial practices and fostering competitive advantage within the knowledge-based economy. The research relies on evidence from articles and research reports, analyzing published sources to answer the research question. Future work could involve collecting empirical data from SMEs to compare with these findings, focusing on management and organizational practices.

title: The ecology of management concepts
abstract: How does the popularity of a concept depend on how it contrasts with and complements existing concepts? We argue that being similar to existing concepts, being located in a popular domain, and being combined with similar existing concepts are important for gaining attention early on but less important and even negative for sustaining popularity. To examine this question, we focus on the rise and fall of management concepts. We analyze data on the rise and fall of keywords in the Harvard Business Review between 1922 and 2010. Multiple tests confirm our hypotheses. The implication is that lessons learned from studies of popular concepts can be misleading as guides for how to make novel concepts popular
publisher: 'Institute for Operations Research and the Management Sciences (INFORMS)'
summary: This study investigates how a concept's popularity is influenced by its contrast and complementarity with existing ideas. The authors hypothesize that similarity to existing concepts, location in a popular domain, and combination with similar existing concepts initially boost attention, but become less important or even detrimental for sustaining popularity. Focusing on management concepts, the research analyzes keyword data from the Harvard Business Review (1922-2010), confirming these hypotheses through multiple tests. The findings suggest that insights from studies on popular concepts may not effectively guide the popularization of novel ideas. Keywords: concept popularity, management concepts, Harvard Business Review, innovation, attention dynamics.

title: Reducing poverty through integrated management of groundwater and surface water
abstract: Groundwater management / Irrigation management / Domestic water / Poverty / Asia / India / Pakistan
authors: International Water Management Institute (IWMI) / Global Water Partnership (GWP) Advisory Center
fieldOfStudy: Business, Groundwater Management, Irrigation Management, Domestic Water, Poverty
summary: This briefing from the GWP Advisory Center at IWMI addresses the inefficiencies and inequities arising from separate management of groundwater and surface water in irrigation systems. It highlights how this practice leads to land salinization, low agricultural productivity, and increased farmer vulnerability, particularly in the Indo-Gangetic Plains. The document proposes integrating groundwater quality and availability into surface water allocation to improve equity, sustainability, and productivity. It draws on IWMI research on wheat productivity and pro-poor intervention strategies in irrigated agriculture in Asia, advocating for Integrated Water Resources Management (IWRM) tools and partnerships.

title: SOCIAL INNOVATION - MODERN INSTRUMENT FOR SOLVING THE PROBLEMS OF LOCAL COMUNITIES
abstract: In present there is a certain perception along free time of the young. Messenger, internet and television are the new recreation and amusement ways that favourises sedentary life, in the detriment of tourism and fresh air walks. The counteract of the phenomenon can be materialized through social innovation principles, concepts that suppose a new vision upon sustainable development of local communities. The elaboration of Suceava city development strategy has to take into account the potential problems of the community. The green spaces that are insufficient and the complete detach of the young from nature can be the strategic points of the new strategy. This work wants to offer possible solutions regarding sedentary life problems of the "Messenger Generation" and the lack of green entertainment areas.social innovation, development strategies, local authorities, Messenger Generation, Active Park

summary: This work addresses the increasing sedentary lifestyle among youth, driven by modern recreation like the internet and television, which deters engagement with tourism and nature. title: “SUPPLY CHAIN MANAGEMENT OR ADAPTIVE BUSINESS NETWORK? – COORDINATION VERSUS COLLABORATION”
abstract: You are not the only company capable to create value for your clients. For making valuable products, for performing high standard services, one company is no longer enough in this new informational era, in this new needs era. Better business performing means now to satisfy more complex needs quicker than ever. Could one company face this challenge alone? Is there another way? Collaboration may be the answer. Maybe the most well-known term when it comes to collaboration between companies is Supply Chain. Why Supply Chain, why Supply Chain Management (SCM)? This article presents the answers to these questions, but also presents different approaches regarding SCM: the logistics approach regarding supply chain management, the strategic approach, the new entrepreneurial approach, supply chain as a win-win game. New paradigms regarding collaboration appeared regarding business collaboration: Adaptive Business Network (ABN). Do these new concepts imply the dead of SCM? Or are them only a new wave in SCM terminology and business orientation? Our conclusion is that these new approach is a normal change in business: businesses are made by people and people don’t like to be conducted (managed). The old-fashioned SCM was based on a coordinator versus several obedients relation. It is absolutely normal to dream at freedom and to be not very efficient while you have to play after somebody else rules. ABN is in the other side of human relations and also business relations – it insists on partnering. Everybody is a part of a chain which has as its main goal customer satisfaction, has the right to make proposals, to negotiate, and to be a winner. Of course, ABN appearance does not involve SCM disappearance, but change in how some chains are managed, in how some chains function. We shall see for the future if an organization with several brains is more successful.Supply Chain Management, Adaptive Business Network, Collaboration
fieldOfStudy: Business, Supply Chain Management, Adaptive Business Network, Collaboration
summary: This article explores the evolution of business collaboration, contrasting traditional Supply Chain Management (SCM) with emerging paradigms like the Adaptive Business Network (ABN). It delves into various SCM approaches—logistics, strategic, entrepreneurial, and win-win—before questioning if ABNs signal the demise of SCM or a natural evolution. The authors conclude that ABNs represent a shift from a coordinator-obedient dynamic to a partnership-based model, emphasizing shared goals and customer satisfaction. The study highlights how human desire for freedom drives business model changes, impacting supply chain management.

title: Management of erectile dysfunction post-radical prostatectomy
abstract: © 2015 Saleh et al.Radical prostatectomy is a commonly performed procedure for the treatment of localized prostate cancer. One of the long-term complications is erectile dysfunction. There is little consensus on the optimal management; however, it is agreed that treatment must be prompt to prevent fibrosis and increase oxygenation of penile tissue. It is vital that patient expectations are discussed, a realistic time frame of treatment provided, and treatment started as close to the prostatectomy as possible. Current treatment regimens rely on phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors as a first-line therapy, with vacuum erection devices and intraurethral suppositories of alprostadil as possible treatment combination options. With nonresponders to these therapies, intracavernosal injections are resorted to. As a final measure, patients undergo the highly invasive penile prosthesis implantation. There is no uniform, objective treatment program for erectile dysfunction post-radical prostatectomy. Management plans are based on poorly conducted and often underpowered studies in combination with physician and patient preferences. They involve the aforementioned drugs and treatment methods in different sequences and doses. Prospective treatments include dietary supplements and gene therapy, which have shown promise with there proposed mechanisms of improving erectile function but are yet to be applied successfully in human patients
summary: This review addresses the management of erectile dysfunction (ED) following radical prostatectomy for localized prostate cancer. The authors highlight the lack of consensus on optimal treatment, emphasizing the need for prompt intervention to prevent fibrosis and improve penile tissue oxygenation. Current regimens primarily use phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors, vacuum erection devices, and intraurethral alprostadil, with intracavernosal injections and penile prostheses for non-responders. The article critiques existing management plans as being based on poorly conducted studies and discusses promising prospective treatments like dietary supplements and gene therapy, which aim to improve erectile function but are not yet successfully applied in humans.

title: Management of e-learners: some implications for practitioners
abstract: Report of a CELT project on supporting students through innovation and researchInformation technologies have played a leading role in supporting many recent changes in teaching and learning approaches in Higher Education. Contemporary innovation finds information technology (IT) at the heart of Higher Education transformation. The opportunities afforded by these learning technologies are well documented in popular academic literature. They point to new applications of the latest communication technologies. However, they also bring with them a host of new questions and challenges. The management of e-learners is likely to be part of a more far-reaching organisational change. Where learning technologies are introduced, a layer of technical complexity is added. The redesign of business processes and structures is far from simple ‘technical’ matter. It involves significant social redesign. The extent to which enabling technology has driven the shift towards learner-centred learning in all educational contexts is a matter of debate. As the century turns, establishing the acceptance, let alone the effectiveness and quality of technology-mediated learning, is still seriously problematic (Salmon, 1999). However, the suitability of information and communication technology (ICT) as a means of encouraging self-directed learning is not in doubt, nor that the role of the tutor is changing to ‘guide on the side’: a facilitator not transmitter, of information (Marchmont, 2000). This paper reports findings of a single case study at Wolverhampton Business School. Qualitative data was collected through structured and unstructured interviews with learners and tutors on Business Administration Award. A total of 20 learners and 5 tutors form the basis of the findings
summary: This report from a CELT project examines the implications of information technology (IT) for managing e-learners in Higher Education, focusing on challenges and opportunities in the transformation of teaching and learning. It highlights that while IT offers new applications, it also introduces technical and social complexities requiring significant redesign of business processes. The study questions the acceptance and effectiveness of technology-mediated learning, emphasizing ICT's suitability for self-directed learning and the evolving role of tutors. A case study at Wolverhampton Business School collected qualitative data through interviews with 20 learners and 5 tutors on a Business Administration Award.

title: Integrated urban water management in Texas: a review to inform a one water approach for the future
abstract:
Texas has considerable experience grappling with historic droughts as well as flooding
associated with tropical storms and hurricanes, yet the State’s water management challenges
are projected to increase. Urban densification, increased frequency and severity of droughts
and floods, aging infrastructure, and a management system that is not reflective of the true
cost of water all influence water risk. Integrated urban water management strategies, like ‘One
Water’, represent an emerging management paradigm that emphasizes the interconnectedness
of water throughout the water cycle and capitalizes on opportunities that arise from this
holistic viewpoint. Here, we review water management practices in five Texas cities and
examine how the One Water approach could represent a viable framework to maintain a
reliable, sustainable, and affordable water supply for the future. We also examine financial and
business models that establish a foundational pathway towards the ‘utility of the future’ and
the One Water paradigm more broadly
publisher: Boston University Institute for Sustainable Energy
summary: This review addresses Texas's increasing water management challenges, including urban densification, frequent droughts and floods, aging infrastructure, and non-reflective water pricing. It proposes 'One Water' as an integrated urban water management paradigm that emphasizes the water cycle's interconnectedness. The study reviews current water management practices in five Texas cities, assessing how the One Water approach can ensure a reliable, sustainable, and affordable water supply. It also examines financial and business models necessary for transitioning to a 'utility of the future' and the broader One Water paradigm, offering insights into sustainable urban water systems.

summary: This document highlights how new management practices significantly improved water supply and reduced conflict over water resources in the Ferghana Valley, Central Asia. title: The Role of a Corporate Bond Market in an Economy - and in Avoiding Crises.
abstract: While much attention has been focused on the optimal ratio of a firm's debt to equity, the "optimal" or best balance between bond financing and (longer-term) bank financing has scarcely been addressed. This essay examines the principal differences between an economy with a well-developed corporate bond market free from government interference and an economy in which bank financing plays a central role (as in East Asia). When a full-fledged corporate bond market is present, market forces have a much greater opportunity to assert themselves, thereby reducing systemic risk and the probability of a crisis. This is because such an environment is associated with greater accounting transparency, a large community of financial analysts, respected rating agencies, a wide range of corporate debt securities and derivatives demanding sophisticated credit analysis, and efficient procedures for corporate reorganization and liquidation. In addition, the richness of available securities will tend to enhance economic welfare, and the market forces at work on the wide array of bond prices are likely to have a strong spillover effect on the health of the banking system as well
summary: This essay examines the differences between an economy with a well-developed corporate bond market and one reliant on bank financing, particularly in the context of East Asia. It argues that a robust corporate bond market, free from government interference, fosters greater accounting transparency, sophisticated credit analysis, and efficient reorganization procedures. This environment reduces systemic risk, enhances economic welfare, and positively impacts the banking system. The study highlights the role of market forces, financial analysts, and rating agencies in promoting stability and avoiding financial crises, contrasting it with economies where bank financing is central. Key concepts include debt-to-equity ratio, bond financing, bank financing, systemic risk, financial crisis, corporate bond market, accounting transparency, financial analysts, credit analysis, and economic welfare.

title: Student Perceptions and Learning Outcomes: Evidence from the Education Testing Service (ETS) Major Field Test in Business
abstract: We examine course evaluation data from the core finance course and analyze how these data relate to performance on the finance portion of the Educational Testing Service Major Field Test in Business (ETS). We find that gender, SAT scores, GPA and concentration all have significant impacts on student performance. We also find that student perceptions of teaching and of how much knowledge they gained do not relate to the finance ETS score. Finally, we find that students who feel challenged in their finance core course do significantly better on the finance portion of the exam. This result is robust to different data partitions
summary: This study analyzes course evaluation data from a core finance course to understand its relationship with performance on the finance portion of the Educational Testing Service (ETS) Major Field Test in Business. The research finds that gender, SAT scores, GPA, and concentration significantly impact student performance. Interestingly, student perceptions of teaching and knowledge gained do not correlate with ETS scores. However, students who feel challenged in their finance course perform significantly better on the exam. This finding highlights the importance of challenging coursework in finance education outcomes.

title: Beyond Mean-Variance: Performance Measurement of Portfolios Using Options or Dynamic Strategies.
fieldOfStudy: Business, Finance, Portfolio Management, Risk Measurement, Performance Evaluation
summary: This paper investigates risk and performance measures for portfolios with nonsymmetric return distributions, challenging the traditional CAPM framework which assumes normal returns or mean-variance preferences. The author argues that these assumptions are often violated, especially for options or dynamic strategies, and that investors exhibit skewness preference. The study considers a market where the market portfolio has i.i.d. returns, leading to its mean-variance inefficiency and mismeasurement by CAPM alpha. The research explores alternative criteria like "Value at Risk" and the "Sortino Ratio," focusing on how these measures perform under lognormal market and portfolio return assumptions, contrasting them with CAPM beta.

title: Women and Trade: Gender\u27s Impact on Trade Finance and Fintech
abstract: Woman-owned firms engage differently with finance for trade. The barriers they face in starting and running a business are well-known. Yet, this offers little insight into how they finance their business once globalized. Surveys indicate that finance is often the primary barrier to trade. We seek to deepen and modernize this finding by using a unique data set to explore the patterns of financial access exhibited by woman-owned exporting firms. We show that women face two levels of exclusion in access to finance—access to basic finance and access to trade finance. The latter is driven by characteristics common to firms owned by women. Also, in line with existing work, we show that woman-owned firms tend to turn to informal finance as an alternative more than their male counterparts. However, we also show that women are more likely to adopt fintech as a financial solution than men. This suggests that policies aimed at incentivizing banks to lend more to women may not be solving the right problem
summary: This study explores the financial access patterns of woman-owned exporting firms, aiming to modernize understanding of finance as a trade barrier. Using a unique dataset, it reveals that women face two levels of exclusion: access to basic finance and access to trade finance, with the latter driven by firm characteristics. Woman-owned firms are more likely to use informal finance but also more likely to adopt fintech solutions than men. This suggests that policies focused solely on incentivizing bank lending to women may be misdirected, highlighting the need to address underlying barriers and leverage fintech.

title: Finance for Climate Resilience in the Dawn of the Paris Era
abstract: This brief examines the gap in adaptation finance that must be bridged in order to fulfill the values of the Paris agreement, with a focus on regions such as Southeast Asia that are at particular risk from the effects of climate change. It also discusses new adaptation finance commitments from governments and the private sector; the landscape of existing adaptation finance channels and initiatives onto which these commitments build; and the undiminished role of developed countries -- such as the United States, Japan, EU countries, and others -- to facilitate an increase in adaptation finance as the Paris era begins
summary: This brief examines the critical gap in adaptation finance needed to fulfill the Paris Agreement's goals, particularly for vulnerable regions like Southeast Asia. It analyzes new adaptation finance commitments from governments and the private sector, along with existing finance channels. The document emphasizes the continuing role of developed countries, including the United States, Japan, and EU countries, in increasing adaptation finance as the Paris era begins. A fundamental shift in finance flows is necessary for global climate resilience and carbon neutrality, addressing the historical imbalance where adaptation finance trails emissions reductions.

title: Interacting Two-Country Business Fluctuations
abstract: In this paper we investigate the closed-economy Keynes-Wicksell-Goodwin model of Chiarella and Flaschel (2000) for the case of two interacting open economies. We introduce these coupled two-country KWG dynamics on the extensive form level by means of a subdivision into nine modules describing the behavioral equations, the laws of motion and the identities or budget equations of the model. We then derive their intensive form representation and the 10 laws of motion of the model on the basis of certain simplifying assumptions. Thereafter we present the uniquely determined steady state solution of the dynamics and discuss in a mathematically informal way its stability properties, concerning asymptotic stability and loss of stability by way of super- or subcritical Hopf-bifurcations. In a final section we explore numerically a variety of situations of interacting real and financial cycles, where the steady state is locally repelling, but where the overall dynamics are bounded in an economically meaningful domain by means of a kinked money wage Phillips curve, exhibiting downward rigidity of the money-wage, coupled with upward flexibility of the usual type.Interacting KWG economies, stability, persistent cycles, coupled oscillators.
summary: This paper examines the closed-economy Keynes-Wicksell-Goodwin (KWG) model in the context of two interacting open economies. The authors introduce coupled two-country KWG dynamics using a nine-module subdivision for behavioral equations, laws of motion, and budget identities. They derive the intensive form representation and 10 laws of motion with simplifying assumptions, then discuss the steady state solution's stability properties, including Hopf-bifurcations. Numerical explorations reveal scenarios of interacting real and financial cycles where the steady state is repelling, but overall dynamics are bounded by a kinked money wage Phillips curve exhibiting downward rigidity and upward flexibility.

title: Behavioral Finance
abstract: Behavioral finance as a subdiscipline of behavioral economics is finance incorporating findings from psychology and sociology into its theories. Behavioral finance models are usually developed to explain investor behavior or market anomalies when rational models provide no sufficient explanations. To understand the research agenda, methodology, and contributions, this survey reviews traditional finance theory first. Then, this survey shows how modifications (e.g. incorporating market frictions) can rationally explain observed individual or market behavior. In the second section, the survey will explain the behavioral finance research methodology -how biases are modeled, incorporated into traditional finance theories, and tested empirically and experimentally- using one specific subset of the behavioral finance literature, the overconfidence literature.
summary: This survey paper provides an overview of behavioral finance, a subdiscipline of behavioral economics that integrates psychological and sociological insights into financial theories. It aims to explain investor behavior and market anomalies not sufficiently addressed by rational models. The review begins with traditional finance theory, then explores how incorporating market frictions can rationally explain observed behaviors. The paper details the behavioral finance research methodology, illustrating how biases are modeled, integrated into traditional finance theories, and empirically/experimentally tested, using the overconfidence literature as a specific example. Key concepts include investor behavior, market anomalies, cognitive biases, and empirical testing.

title: Why Do Countries Matter so Much in Corporate Social Performance?
abstract: Why do levels of corporate social performance (CSP) differ so much across countries? We answer this question in an examination of CSP ratings of more than 2,600 companies from 36 countries. We find that firm characteristics explain very little of the variations in CSP ratings. In contrast, variations in country factors such as stages of economic development, culture, and institutions account for a significant proportion of variations in CSP ratings across countries. In particular, we find that CSP ratings are high in countries with high income-per-capita, strong civil liberties and political rights, and cultures oriented toward harmony and autonomy. Furthermore, we find that home country factors explain a smaller portion of the overall variations in CSP for multinationals and cross-listed firms than for non-multinationals and pure domestic firms, respectively
summary: This study examines why corporate social performance (CSP) levels vary across countries, analyzing over 2,600 companies from 36 nations. The research reveals that firm characteristics have minimal impact on CSP ratings. Instead, country-specific factors like economic development, culture, and institutions significantly explain these variations. High CSP ratings are associated with high income-per-capita, strong civil liberties, political rights, and cultures emphasizing harmony and autonomy. For multinationals and cross-listed firms, home country factors play a smaller role in overall CSP variations compared to domestic firms, offering insights into global corporate behavior and sustainability.

title: Why is finance critical? A dialogue with a women's community in Sri Lanka
abstract: The busrt of the bubble has given momentum to the search of escape routes from the current transnational financial system and its underlying principles. For the past century, The transnational financial system has relied heavily on currency exchange, security backed loans, stocks and shares - all operated through banks, investment agencies, insurance brokers and stock markets. This global financial architecture centred on monetray values. It strived for financial wealth and achieved it for few out of many. This study shows that the practice of finance can create a wealth of a different - a scoial- nature. Applying an ethnographic approach to financial practices, this study tries to uncover how the sociocultural aspects of finance practiced among the poor rural women in Sri Lanka lead to the creation of social wealth beyond financial wealth. It discovers how finance is critical to such communities becauise it is creating wealth beyond financial measurement. Finance comes to Sinalhese women's everyday lives through traditional savings systems - seettu, household and group saving and it operates through frienships, kin relationships and social realtions. These community organisation develop social wealth through their thrifts, based on traditional practices of saving.Since transnational finance is driven by monetary values only, it overlays structures and that ignores local cultures, social networks and community identies necessary for the creation of social wealth. As a consequence, encounters with transnational finance inspire resistance in citizens of developing nations such as Sri Lanka. In an attempt to preserve their more tradional ways of exchange, communities find themselves workign agianst finance. Therefore in this paper I am interested in engaging in a dialogue with a rural community, to learn their ways of organising finance and the extent to which finance becomes critical to their everyday live
publisher: School of Business & Management, Queen Mary
summary: This study examines how finance, particularly among poor rural women in Sri Lanka, can generate social wealth beyond traditional monetary value. It critiques the transnational financial system's focus on monetary values, which often disregards local cultures and social networks. Through an ethnographic approach, the research explores how traditional savings systems like 'seettu,' integrated with friendships and kin relationships, contribute to community well-being. The findings suggest that these localized financial practices create social capital and inspire resistance to transnational financial structures, demonstrating finance's critical role in fostering social wealth for developing nations.

title: Integrating Sound Finance with Functional Finance
summary: This paper addresses the fundamental problem in fiscal policy: balancing short-run stabilization with long-run systemic stability. It highlights the chaotic state of economists' views on fiscal policy in the early 2000s, where mainstream academic macroeconomists widely discredited short-run discretionary fiscal policy. The authors argue that the abandonment of Keynesian theories has left policymakers without clear guidance, allowing political interests to dominate budgeting. The discussion touches upon the Stability and Growth Pact in the EU and state government deficits in the US, emphasizing the need for integrating sound finance with functional finance principles.

title: Location, Proximity, and M&A Transactions
abstract: In this paper, we examine how the geographic location of firms affects acquisition decisions and value creation for acquirers in takeover transactions. We find that firms located in an urban area are more likely to receive a takeover bid and complete a takeover transaction as a target than firms located in rural areas, and takeover deals involving an urban target are associated with higher acquirer announcement returns, after controlling for the proximity between the target and the acquirer. In addition, a target\u27s urban location significantly attenuates the negative effect of a long distance between the target and the acquirer on acquirer returns, a fact that is documented in the existing literature. Our findings reveal a previously underexplored force—firm location—that can affect takeover transactions, in addition to proximity. Our paper suggests that a firm\u27s location plays an important role in facilitating the dissemination of soft information and enhancing information-based synergies
summary: This paper investigates the impact of firm geographic location on M&A acquisition decisions and acquirer value creation. The study finds that urban firms are more likely targets in takeover transactions, and deals involving urban targets yield higher acquirer announcement returns, even after controlling for target-acquirer proximity. Furthermore, an urban target location mitigates the negative effect of long distances between target and acquirer on returns. These findings reveal firm location as a significant, previously underexplored factor, alongside proximity, that influences takeover transactions by facilitating soft information dissemination and enhancing information-based synergies in M&A.

title: School Finance Toolkit: How to Create a Community Guide to Your School District's Budget
abstract: If your community-based organization would like to launch a school finance initiative in your community, you can use this toolkit as a starting point. The toolkit walks through the major steps organizations have gone through in their own initiatives, offering advice and examples of tools you can adapt for your own use. The toolkit explores the major challenges organizations have faced in this work, and how they have addressed those challenges. And the toolkit points you toward other resources that can help you find and analyze information about school finance. This toolkit is not itself a primer on school finance. Except in passing, it does not explain how school funding works in school districts. You will have to obtain this kind of background information from other resources (some listed in this toolkit) and as you go along.The toolkit contains five major sections:Get Started. This section helps you set a mission for your school finance initiative, organize your people to get the job done, and find the resources to get the job done.Engage the Public. This section discusses strategies for engaging the public up-front, finding out what citizens want to know about school finance -- and why.Crunch the Numbers. This section addresses the nitty-gritty work of creating a community guide to the school budget, offering helpful tips on finding, analyzing, and presenting information effectively.Put the Numbers to Work. This section talks about ways you can use the information you have gathered as a catalyst for community-wide discussions of school finance and its impact on school quality.Resources. This section contains a variety of tools used by community-based organizations in their school finance initiatives, everything from town meeting agendas to focus group questions to budget analysis spreadsheets. This section also contains references to many sources of data about school finance, many of them just a mouse-click or toll-free call away

summary: This toolkit guides community-based organizations in launching school finance initiatives. title: Seeking Rights, Not Rent: How Litigation Finance Can Help Break Music Copyright\u27s Precedent Gridlock
abstract: Since its inception, litigation finance has steadily grown in prevalence and popularity in the United States.  While many scholars have examined its merits, few have considered litigation finance specifically in the context of copyright law.  This is most unfortunate, for there, a vicious cycle has taken hold: high litigation costs discourage many market participants from taking cases to trial or summary judgment in order to vindicate their legal rights, even when they have strong cases. Thus, parties settle almost every case, which in turn prevents resolution of longstanding precedential questions in critical areas of copyright law.  The legal uncertainty resulting from this precedential gridlock generates higher avoidance costs and poses more financial risks for market participants, particularly less-heeled or less-established parties.       This Note proposes one way in which litigation finance could help break that cycle.  Specifically, rights holders and defendants alike can use litigation finance to fund strategic-litigation campaigns to pressure the development of precedent.  To illustrate how this might work, this Note examines litigation finance in the narrow context of music copyright, an area that perfectly illustrates the problems besetting copyright law writ large.  In doing so, this Note flips a popular criticism of litigation finance on its head: while some scholars argue that litigation finance can distort litigation strategy by encouraging litigants to reject mutually beneficial settlements, it is normatively desirable to do so given the unsettled state of music copyright law
summary: This Note explores how litigation finance can address the 'precedent gridlock' in United States copyright law, particularly within music copyright. High litigation costs lead to settlements, preventing the resolution of critical precedential questions and increasing legal uncertainty and financial risks for market participants. The author proposes that rights holders and defendants can use litigation finance to fund strategic-litigation campaigns, fostering precedent development. This approach reframes the criticism that litigation finance distorts strategy by encouraging rejections of settlements, arguing it is desirable given the unsettled state of music copyright law. The paper aims to provide a solution to high litigation costs and demands for greater legal clarity.

title: Even if it's not Bribery: The Case for Campaign Finance Reform
abstract:
We develop a dynamic multidimensional signaling model of campaign finance

in which candidates can signal their ability by enacting policy and/or by raising

and spending campaign funds, both of which are costly. Our model departs

from the existing literature in that candidates do not exchange policy influence

for campaign contributions; rather, they must decide how to allocate their

efforts between policymaking and fundraising. If high-ability candidates are

better policymakers and better fundraisers, then they will raise and spend

campaign funds even if voters care only about legislation. Campaign finance

reform alleviates this phenomenon and improves voter welfare at the expense

of politicians. Thus, we expect successful politicians to oppose true campaign

finance reform. We also show that our model is consistent with findings in the

empirical and theoretical campaign finance literature
summary: This paper develops a dynamic, multidimensional signaling model of campaign finance to understand how candidates allocate efforts between policymaking and fundraising. Departing from existing literature, the model posits that candidates do not exchange policy for contributions but signal ability through both costly activities. It finds that high-ability candidates will fundraise even if voters only care about legislation, as voters' inability to reward past policy allows fundraising to signal ability. Campaign finance reform is shown to improve voter welfare at politicians' expense, predicting opposition from successful politicians. The model's consistency with existing empirical and theoretical campaign finance literature is also demonstrated, offering insights into political economy and public choice.

title: Working Paper 118 - Assessment of the Trade Finance Market in Africa Post-Crisis
abstract: The financial crisis, which began to hit the trade finance markets in 2008, caused a sharp slow-down in trade in 2008 and 2009. The tightening of global credit reduced capital inflows and curtailed the availability of trade finance. This sudden shortage of trade finance negatively impacted African economies. In response, the African Development Bank (AfDB) established, on March 2009, a multiphase USD 1 billion Trade Finance Initiative (TFI). As part of the Trade Finance Initiative, AfDB commissioned a trade finance survey conducted three times between 2009 and 2010. The financial institutions contacted during these market surveys are listed at the end of this document. During this research, banks in Senegal, Burkina Faso, Ghana, Nigeria, Egypt, Morocco, Kenya, South Africa, Tanzania and Rwanda were contacted. In addition, financial institutions active in the international and regional trade finance markets based in the USA, UK, France, Germany and the Netherlands were contacted. Finally, development finance institutions active in supporting trade both within Africa and without were interviewed. Generally trade operations officers, international department management, treasury officers or senior commercial bankers were contacted. Participants were asked to: • Describe their trade finance related activities • Describe the state of the market for trade finance products • Describe how availability of facilities has changed •Describe how terms and conditions of facilities have changed •Discuss overall economic activity in their markets • Discuss potential roles for AfDB to play to facilitate access to trade finance The overall conclusions of these surveys are: • African trade grew rapidly during the pre-crisis period, spurred by growing south-south trade and the emergence of Asia as a major purchaser of African raw materials and primary products. Anecdotally, it appears that trade finance was increasingly available during this period. • The crisis has had a negative impact on African trade due to falling demand for African primary product exports. Trade finance availability was sharply constrained during the initial crisis period. • It is difficult to discern real trends in African trade finance as markets remain highly volatile. Liquidity and risk appetite vary widely across markets and counterparties. Across all markets, trade finance tenors have shortened. • There is an overall decrease in demand for trade products due to decreased economic activity but a higher proportion of the current transactions are using trade instruments. • International commercial banks that historically provided confirmation lines for trade instruments remain risk averse and seek to maintain/increase returns. • Low income countries and the smaller Regional Member Countries are hit hardest by the lack of availability of trade finance due to higher perceived risk, even for low risk transactions. • Basel II related capital allocation rules will have a negative impact on the cost and availability of trade finance across the continent. • Multilateral Development Banks in other regions play a variety of roles to support trade finance availability, from which AfDB could learn some lessons. • The African Development Bank can have a significant impact on trade finance availability and, consequently, RMC economic performance over the short/medium term.
fieldOfStudy: Business, Trade Finance, African Development Bank
summary: This study assesses the African trade finance market following the 2008 financial crisis, which severely impacted global trade and capital flows, particularly in Africa. The African Development Bank (AfDB) established a USD 1 billion Trade Finance Initiative (TFI) and commissioned a survey across various African and international financial institutions between 2009 and 2010. Key findings indicate rapid pre-crisis growth spurred by south-south trade, a sharp post-crisis constraint in trade finance availability, and ongoing market volatility. The report also highlights decreased demand for trade products, risk aversion among international commercial banks, and the disproportionate impact on low-income countries. It suggests potential roles for AfDB to enhance trade finance availability.
