title: Mezzanine finance and corporate bonds
abstract: The article deals with the problems of mezzanine finance in relation to corporate bonds. Firstly, attention is paid to definition of mezzanine finance. The term mezzanine finance is used as a term for hybrid forms of financing that combine elements of debt and equity financing. Mezzanine finance represents an alternative form of financing corporate activities. Secondly, possible forms of mezzanine finance are characterized. We can say that special types of corporate bonds (convertible bonds and option bonds) present instruments of mezzanin finance. Then, attention is focused on the problems of corporate bonds. Corporate bond is a security connected with the right to settlement of the sum owing and with the issuer’s obligation to meet this right. A corporate bond is one of the important instruments on the capital market, and at the same time it is a potential source of financial means for companies.mezzanine finance, corporate bonds, option bonds
summary: This article explores mezzanine finance, defining it as a hybrid form of corporate financing combining elements of debt and equity. It characterizes possible forms, specifically highlighting convertible and option bonds as instruments of mezzanine finance. The study then focuses on corporate bonds as important capital market instruments and potential financial sources for companies. The aim is to demonstrate the utility of corporate bonds within mezzanine finance for corporate financing processes. Keywords: mezzanine finance, corporate bonds, hybrid financing, convertible bonds, option bonds, capital market.

title: The private finance initiative (PFI) and finance capital: A note on gaps in the "accountability" debate
abstract: During recent years, a wide spectrum of research has questioned whether public services/infrastructure procurement through private finance, as exemplified by the UK Private Finance Initiative (PFI), meets minimum standard of democratic accountability. While broadly agreeing with some of these arguments, this paper suggests that this debate is flawed on two grounds. Firstly, PFI is not about effective procurement, or even about a pragmatic choice of procurement mechanisms which can potentially compromise public involvement and input; rather it is about a process where the state creates new profit opportunities at a time when the international financial system is increasingly lacking in safe investment opportunities. Secondly, because of its primary function as investment opportunity, PFI, by its very nature, prioritises the risk-return criteria of private finance over the needs of the public sector client and its stakeholders. Using two case studies of recent PFI projects, the paper illustrates some of the mechanisms through which finance capital exercises control over the PFI procurement process. The paper concludes that recent proposals aimed at “reforming” or “democratising” PFI fail to recognise the objective constraints which this type of state-finance capital nexus imposes on political process
publisher: Department of Management Studies, University of York
summary: This paper examines whether public services procurement through private finance, like the UK Private Finance Initiative (PFI), meets democratic accountability standards. It argues that PFI prioritizes creating new profit opportunities for finance capital over effective procurement or public needs. Using two case studies, the research illustrates how finance capital controls PFI processes, suggesting that PFI's fundamental nature as an investment opportunity for state-finance capital limits genuine reform or democratization efforts. Keywords: Private Finance Initiative, PFI, public procurement, finance capital, democratic accountability, investment opportunities, state-finance nexus.

title: Catalytic Finance
summary: This paper models debt crises stemming from creditor coordination failures, demonstrating that bailouts reducing ex post inefficiency can sometimes incentivize governments to undertake costly adjustment efforts. The research aims to clarify the debate surrounding the IMF's role in catalyzing lending to developing countries, where official assistance is theorized to strategically complement private sector funding. Key concepts include catalytic finance, debtor adjustment, moral hazard, and sovereign debt. This model helps to understand the conditions under which official assistance can galvanize private creditors to mitigate funding crises for debtor countries, contributing to discussions on international finance and economic policy.

title: Corporate finance in an interest free economy: An alternate approach to practiced Islamic Corporate Finance
abstract: This paper suggests an alternate approach to corporate finance in an interest free economy by looking beyond practiced Islamic finance and suggesting alternatives for corporate finance in sourcing funds i.e. i) Ijara with embedded options, ii) limited liability partnership, iii) equity modes like Musharakah and Mudarabah iv) income bonds and v) convertible income bonds. It also suggests alternatives for corporate finance in using funds i.e. i) Islamic income funds, ii) Islamic REITs, iii) Treasury Bonds, iv) income bonds v) convertible income bonds, vi) foreign currency reserves, vii) making strategic expansion, and viii) equity investments in other companies. It also suggests methods of valuation by suggesting an alternate means of pricing capital in interest free economy and use of appropriate discount rate i.e. Nominal GDP growth rate in public finance and corporate finance in CAPM, dividend discount model, project valuation, calculating NPV, valuing income bonds and stocks. It also discusses how the problems of scarcity of capital will be solved and alternatives for insurance in an interest free economy.Islamic corporate finance, pricing of capital, Islamic public finance, scarcity of capital, Interest free economy, Interest free finance, Zakat, Usury, Time value of money, CAPM, Project evaluation, NPV, FCF
fieldOfStudy: Business, Islamic corporate finance, pricing of capital, Islamic public finance, scarcity of capital, Interest free economy, Interest free finance
summary: This paper proposes an alternative approach to corporate finance within an interest-free economy, moving beyond conventional Islamic finance practices. It suggests various methods for sourcing funds, including Ijara with embedded options, limited liability partnerships, equity modes (Musharakah, Mudarabah), and income bonds. For using funds, it proposes Islamic income funds, REITs, Treasury Bonds, and strategic equity investments. The paper also addresses valuation by suggesting alternative capital pricing using the Nominal GDP growth rate as a discount rate in CAPM, dividend discount models, and project valuation. It also discusses solving capital scarcity and alternative insurance in an interest-free framework.

title: Consumer finance: challenges for operational research
abstract: Consumer finance has become one of the most important areas of banking, both because of the amount of money being lent and the impact of such credit on global economy and the realisation that the credit crunch of 2008 was partly due to incorrect modelling of the risks in such lending. This paper reviews the development of credit scoring—the way of assessing risk in consumer finance—and what is meant by a credit score. It then outlines 10 challenges for Operational Research to support modelling in consumer finance. Some of these involve developing more robust risk assessment systems, whereas others are to expand the use of such modelling to deal with the current objectives of lenders and the new decisions they have to make in consumer finance. <br/
summary: This paper reviews the evolution of credit scoring, a critical component in assessing risk within consumer finance. Triggered by the 2008 credit crunch, which highlighted flaws in risk modeling, the study outlines ten key challenges for Operational Research to enhance consumer finance modeling. These challenges include developing more robust risk assessment systems and expanding modeling applications to address current lender objectives and emerging decision-making needs in the sector. The paper emphasizes the growing importance of consumer finance and the necessity for advanced analytical support to manage its inherent risks effectively.

abstract: The finance industry in New Jersey employs over 200,000 people. Many more workers benefit from the state's proximity to the finance industry in New York City. title: Monitoring Climate Finance in Developing Countries: Challenges and Next Steps
abstract: At the 18th Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), the parties agreed to a standard format for developed countries to follow when reporting on the climate finance they provide to developing countries. Developed countries will use these formats for the first time when they submit their Biennial Reports to the UNFCCC in early 2014. Later in 2014, developing countries are expected to submit Biennial Update Reports showing the financial support that they have received. From initial attempts to measure and report climate finance by developed and developing countries, it is already apparent that information on finance provided is unlikely to match information on finance received.Aside from the reporting requirements of the UNFCCC, better financial data can help decision makers in developing countries identify gaps, improve coordination and management, and raise funds to mitigate and adapt to climate change. Better climate finance information can also enable countries to draw lessons from the use of different financial instruments and develop strategies and policies that aim to expand finance for climate change. Improved data will allow the information reported by developed countries to be cross-checked, thus promoting transparency, completeness, and accuracy. Finally, it can contribute to a more comprehensive picture of climate financial flows in relation to development assistance at the national and international levels. This working paper reports on three workshops in Asia, Africa, and Latin America, in which participants discussed some of the steps that developing countries and their international partners can take toward monitoring and tracking climate finance more effectively. More than 40 representatives from 20 developing countries, regional development banks, and national organizations attended the three workshops. Participants shared information on the limits of existing legislation and mandates, national planning and approval processes, financial management systems, efforts to coordinate among ministries and development partners, and many other unique challenges faced by the participating countries. WRI obtained additional information via a questionnaire, follow-up correspondence, and interviews with representatives of the countries
summary: This paper reports on three workshops in Asia, Africa, and Latin America, discussing steps for developing countries and international partners to monitor and track climate finance more effectively. Following the UNFCCC's agreement on reporting standards for climate finance, the study highlights the challenges in reconciling reported finance provided versus received. Improved financial data can help developing countries identify gaps, improve coordination, and raise funds for climate change mitigation and adaptation, while also promoting transparency and accuracy in climate financial flows. Participants shared insights on existing legislation, national planning, financial management, and inter-ministerial coordination.

title: Inflation in Western Europe and Japan
abstract: Inflation (Finance) - Western Europe ; Inflation (Finance) - Japan
summary: This article examines the cyclical upswing in economic activity and accompanying inflation in Western Europe and Japan, which continued into 1970 despite the US economic slowdown. It highlights that while initial inflation was demand-driven, cost-push elements, particularly rising labor costs, increasingly predominated. The authors discuss the restrictive monetary and fiscal policies adopted by these nations to combat inflation and assess their effectiveness. They also suggest that trade liberalization and timely exchange-rate actions could mitigate inflationary pressures, emphasizing the importance of international cooperation and information exchange among policymakers to address global inflation. Keywords: inflation, Western Europe, Japan, monetary policy, fiscal policy, cost-push, demand-pull, exchange rates, international cooperation.

title: France\u27s Financial Crisis: Analyzing the Role of the Finance Minister
abstract: The downfall of France\u27s Old Regime and the beginning of the French Revolution were largely caused by the financial crisis plaguing France. Since the Seven Year\u27s War, France\u27s finances had suffered and were spiraling out of control. The finances were kept largely by the country\u27s appointed finance minister. France would go through a host of these finance ministers up to the Revolution. The most notable was Jacques Necker who receives more detailed analysis. Tracing the administrations of these finance ministers helps explain an important factor leading to the French Revolution
summary: This article investigates the financial crisis that precipitated the downfall of France's Old Regime and ignited the French Revolution, tracing its origins back to the Seven Years' War. It examines the crucial role of appointed finance ministers in managing the country's finances, which were spiraling out of control. The study provides a detailed analysis of notable figures such as Jacques Necker, arguing that understanding the administrations of these finance ministers is key to explaining a significant factor leading to the French Revolution. Keywords: French Revolution, Old Regime, financial crisis, finance ministers, Jacques Necker, Seven Years' War.

title: The unofficial economy in Croatia: causes, size and consequences
abstract: This Occasional Paper reports the research results of a project on the unofficial economy in Croatia conducted by the Institute of Public Finance in Zagreb for the Croatian Ministry of Finance. The project team report was finalized in early 1997 and it includes some 15 papers which can be obtained both in Croatian (“Financijska praksa”, Vol. 21, No. 1-2, June 1997) and English (http://www.ijf.hr/finpraksa/eng/97/1-2/index.htm). This paper is the summary of the project written by Ivo Bićanić (University of Zagreb) and Katarina Ott (Institute of Public Finance)
summary: This Occasional Paper summarizes a research project on the unofficial economy in Croatia, conducted by the Institute of Public Finance for the Croatian Ministry of Finance. The study investigates the causes, size, and consequences of economic activities not included in official statistics. Key findings indicate that the unofficial economy in Croatia was likely at least 25% of GDP in 1995, and its size increased significantly between 1990 and 1993. The paper provides an overview of the project's extensive report, finalized in early 1997, which includes 15 detailed papers. This research is crucial for understanding economic dynamics beyond official measurements.

title: The role of Islamic finance in economic development
abstract: Islamic financial institutions have been growing rapidly in the past few years. Islamic finance refers to investments that are permissible in accordance with Sharia, the Islamic law. Sharia law views money as a measuring tool for value and not an “asset” itself. “It does not permit receipt and payment of riba(interest), gharar(excessive uncertainty), maysir(gambling), short sales or financing activities that it considers harmful to society” (IMF website). Interest, a form of income from money, is therefore prohibited. For example, the income obtained from banks must come from the gain or loss of the enterprises they underwrite and not from interest obtained from loans granted. Sharia-compliant finance is thus often viewed as a unique form of socially responsible investment. Islamic finance exists to further the socio-economic goals of Islam. The question is: How can Islamic finance contribute to economic development? This essay explores its contribution to economic development through microfinance and the use of sukuk(Islamic bond). It will also explore the main opportunities and challenges for Islamic finance today. In order to facilitate the following reading, all Islamic terms used in this essay will be defined in the glossary (Appendix I)
fieldOfStudy: Business, Finance, Financial Management, Islamic Finance
summary: This essay examines how Islamic finance can contribute to economic development. It explores Sharia-compliant investments, which prohibit interest (riba), excessive uncertainty (gharar), gambling (maysir), and harmful activities. The paper investigates its contribution through microfinance and the use of sukuk (Islamic bonds), highlighting their role in long-term financing, especially for infrastructure projects. It also discusses the main opportunities and challenges facing Islamic finance today, noting its rapid growth and appeal to investors seeking religiously compliant options. Key findings include sukuk's significant contribution to funding government and corporate projects, attracting a distinct segment of investors.

title: Markets and Housing Finance
abstract: We examine the extent to which markets enable the provision of housing finance across a wide range of countries. Housing is a major purchase requiring a long-term financing, and the factors that are associated with well functioning housing finance systems are those that enable the provision of long-term finance. Across all countries, controlling for country size, we find that countries with stronger legal rights for borrowers and lenders (through collateral and bankruptcy laws), deeper credit information systems, and a more stable macroeconomic environment have deeper housing finance systems. These same factors also help explain the variation in housing finance across emerging market economies. Across developed countries, which tend to have low macroeconomic volatility and relatively extensive credit information systems, variation in the strength of legal rights helps explain the extent of housing finance. We also examine another potential factor—the existence of sizeable government securities markets—that might enable the development of emerging markets’ housing finance systems, but we find no evidence supporting that.mortgage, housing finance, emerging markets
summary: This paper investigates the factors enabling housing finance provision across diverse countries. Housing, being a significant long-term purchase, necessitates robust financing systems. The study finds that stronger legal rights for borrowers and lenders (via collateral and bankruptcy laws), deeper credit information systems, and a stable macroeconomic environment significantly contribute to deeper housing finance systems globally and within emerging market economies. In developed countries, variations in legal rights explain housing finance extent. The authors found no evidence that sizeable government securities markets enable emerging markets' housing finance systems. Keywords: housing finance, mortgage, emerging markets, legal rights, credit information, macroeconomic stability.

title: Repositioning Chinese development finance in Latin America: opportunities for green finance
abstract: This repository item contains a policy brief from the Boston University Global Economic Governance Initiative. The Global Economic Governance Initiative (GEGI) is a research program of the Center for Finance, Law & Policy, the Frederick S. Pardee Center for the Study of the Longer-Range Future, and the Frederick S. Pardee School of Global Studies. It was founded in 2008 to advance policy-relevant knowledge about governance for financial stability, human development, and the environment.China is one of the largest creditors of Latin American and the Caribbean and has loaned the region more than $125 billion since 2005. However, the composition of China’s financing in the region has been concentrated in commodity related sectors that are currently on the decline. This policy brief notes the extent to which Chinese finance is concentrated in new green economy sectors, and finds that China is not taking full opportunity of the potential in this sector. Moreover, as the global commodity boom has declined, much of China’s investments in the region have been exposed to significant risk, including prominent environmental and social risks. Despite great strides whereby the Chinese government has established a series of guidelines on greening overseas investment over the last few years, China’s development banks and companies are lacking the policies and staffing to identify and fully mitigate such risks. This policy brief reviews the green profile of Chinese development finance in LAC and analyzes environment related risks and policies for Chinese overseas investment. It also outlines the opportunities of green finance in LAC and how blending instruments can mobilize green financial flows that are beneficial for both China and LAC
publisher: Boston University Global Economic Governance Initiative
summary: This policy brief examines Chinese development finance in Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC), highlighting its concentration in declining commodity sectors and limited engagement with the green economy. Despite China's guidelines for greening overseas investment, its development banks lack policies and staffing to mitigate environmental and social risks effectively. The brief reviews the green profile of Chinese finance in LAC, analyzes associated risks, and outlines opportunities for green finance, suggesting how blended instruments can mobilize beneficial green financial flows for both China and LAC. This research is crucial for understanding sustainable investment and risk mitigation in global economic governance.

title: Public Finance in China since the Late Qing Dynasty
abstract: How is "public finance" organized in China? Is Chinaâ€™s public finance system different from that of other countries? Can we detect features which link todayâ€™s system to the past?Public finance refers to more than annual state budgets and constitutional procedures. It includes foreign debt, state monopolies or monetary policies, all of which played a crucial role in Chinaâ€™s public finance during the last hundred years. A purely legislative definition obscures the fact that changes in public finance have contributed to the collapse of political regimes such as Imperial China (1911), Republican China (1927), and KMT-China (1945), as well engendered regime changes in 1949, 1961 and 1978. From a more comprehensive economic perspective public finance in China encompasses institutions, organizations and policies.public finance;China;KMT-China;imperial China;republican China
summary: This paper investigates the organization and unique characteristics of public finance in China, examining how its system differs from other countries and tracing historical links. It moves beyond a purely legislative definition, considering foreign debt, state monopolies, and monetary policies, which have significantly influenced China's public finance over the last century. The research highlights how changes in public finance contributed to the collapse of various political regimes, including Imperial China (1911), Republican China (1927), and KMT-China (1945), and engendered subsequent regime changes. The study adopts a comprehensive economic perspective, analyzing the institutions, organizations, and policies integral to China's public finance system.

title: External financing of US corporations: Are loans and securities complements or substitutes?
abstract:
“Multiple avenues of intermediation” (Greenspan 2000) suggest substitutability of
corporate loan and bond finance which smooths external financing flows. Holmstrom and
Tirole (1997) stress complementarity; for most firms bank finance and consequent monitoring
is essential for bond finance. Econometric work based on their model is consistent with
complementarity both on average over time and during financial crises, and for levels and
volatilities. It implies that “multiple avenues” may not be effective as a buffer in a bank credit
crunch, and hence supply-side blockages of bank credit may impact on real activity. There are
important implications for regulation, not least Basel II
summary: This paper investigates whether corporate loan and bond finance are complements or substitutes in smoothing external financing flows for US corporations. While "multiple avenues of intermediation" suggest substitutability, the study, building on Holmstrom and Tirole (1997), presents econometric evidence consistent with complementarity. Bank finance and monitoring are found essential for bond finance, both over time and during financial crises. The findings imply that multiple financing avenues may not effectively buffer bank credit crunches, potentially impacting real economic activity and having significant implications for financial regulation, including Basel II. Keywords include financial markets, macroeconomy, and corporate finance.

title: the finance-growth perspective
abstract: This paper explores the impact of antiquity on capitalism through the finance-growth nexus. We define antiquity as the length of established statehood (i.e., state history) and agricultural years. We argue that extractive institutions and deeply entrenched interest groups may prevail in societies with ancient roots. The paper offers an in-depth analysis of one particular channel through which extractive institutions may impair economic growth: the finance-growth channel. We propose that in countries with ancient statehood, the financial sector might be captured by powerful economic and political elites leading to a distorted finance-growth relationship. We build a model in which the equilibrium relationship between companies and banks depends on the entrenchment of the economic elites and the length of established statehood. To validate our argument empirically, we run panel-threshold regressions on a global sample between 1970 and 2014. The regression results are supportive and show that financial development – measured by the outstanding amount of credit – is negative for growth in states with ancient institutional origins, while it is positive in relatively younger ones
summary: This paper investigates the influence of antiquity, defined as the length of established statehood and agricultural history, on capitalism through the finance-growth nexus. It posits that societies with ancient roots may exhibit extractive institutions and entrenched interest groups, leading to a distorted finance-growth relationship where powerful elites capture the financial sector. The authors develop a model detailing the bank-company relationship's dependence on elite entrenchment and statehood length. Empirical panel-threshold regressions on global data from 1970-2014 support the hypothesis, showing that financial development negatively impacts growth in states with ancient institutional origins but positively in younger ones.

title: Is deflation coming?
abstract: Deflation (Finance) ; Inflation (Finance)
summary: This article addresses growing concerns among analysts about the possibility of sustained deflation, last seen during the Great Depression. It clarifies that disinflation, a slower rate of price increase, differs from deflation, which is an ongoing decrease in the aggregate price level. The author argues that current evidence, such as changes in relative prices or declines in the Producer Price Index, does not necessarily indicate economy-wide deflation. Projections from the Congressional Budget Office and private-sector forecasters anticipate modest upward drift in Consumer Price Index and GDP price indexes, not deflation. The study concludes that while brief periods of deflation are possible in a low-inflation environment, they are unlikely to be sustained. Keywords: deflation, inflation, disinflation, economic trends, monetary policy, price indexes.

title: Tracking REDD+ Finance: 2009-2012 - Finance Flows in Seven REDD+ Countries
abstract: Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation (REDD). This REDDX report tracks the 2009-2012 flow of REDD+ finance from a variety of donors to seven tropical forest countries for various types of REDD+ activities. It is based on the hard work and dedication of seven teams of national partners and other experts who surveyed donors, government agencies, implementing agencies, NGOs, and consulting firms involved in the management of REDD+ finance in key REDD+ recipient countries
fieldOfStudy: Business, finance, environmental policy, forest conservation
summary: This REDDX report tracks the flow of REDD+ finance from 2009-2012, examining various donors and recipient tropical forest countries. The study relies on extensive surveys conducted by national partners and experts across government agencies, NGOs, and consulting firms involved in REDD+ finance management. It highlights the purpose of Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation, focusing on transparency and accountability in financial practices for forest conservation. The report aims to catalyze integrated carbon, water, and biodiversity incentives, promoting sustainable forest management and benefits for local communities through market and policy analysis and new financial tools.

title: Why Has the U.S. Financial Sector Grown so Much? The Role of Corporate Finance.
abstract: The share of finance in U.S. GDP has been multiplied by more than three over the postwar period. I argue, using evidence and theory, that corporate finance is a key factor behind this evolution. Inside the finance industry, credit intermediation and corporate finance are more important than globalization, increased trading, or the development of mutual funds for explaining the trend. In the non financial sector, firms with low cash flows account for a growing share of total investment. I build a simple equilibrium model to capture these salient features and I use it to interpret the data. I find that corporate demand is the main contributor to the growth of the finance industry, but also that efficiency gains in finance have been important to limit credit rationing. Overall, the model can account for a bit more than half of the financial sector's growth.
summary: This paper investigates the significant increase in finance's share of U.S. GDP over the postwar period, arguing that corporate finance is a primary driver. It posits that credit intermediation and corporate finance within the industry, and a growing share of investment from non-financial firms with low cash flows, are key factors. The author develops an equilibrium model to interpret data, finding corporate demand as the main contributor to the finance industry's growth, while efficiency gains in finance limited credit rationing. The model accounts for over half of the financial sector's expansion, offering insights into financial sector growth, corporate finance, and credit markets.

title: Do microfinance institutions reach the poorest?
abstract: The question raised in the title is an important one to the microfinance sector, especially since the Microcredit Summit held in Washington, DC, in 1997. In order to gain more transparency on the depth of poverty outreach, the Consultative Group to Assist the Poorest (CGAP) supported research at IFPRI during 1999 and 2000 to design and test a simple, low-cost operational tool to measure the poverty level of MFI clients relative to nonclients. This policy brief informs about the results from recent case studies on the poverty outreach of four selected microfinance institutions. The case studies were conducted for four MFIs world-wide: MFI A (Central America), MFI B (East Africa), MFI C (Southern Africa), and MFI D (South Asia).Microenterprises Finance. ,Finance Developing countries. ,Financial institutions. ,Finance Southern Africa. ,Finance Central America. ,Finance South Asia. Finance Africa, East. ,
fieldOfStudy: Business, Microfinance, Financial Institutions, Poverty Measurement
summary: This policy brief discusses research supported by the Consultative Group to Assist the Poorest (CGAP) and IFPRI, conducted between 1999 and 2000, to develop and test a low-cost tool for measuring the poverty level of microfinance institution (MFI) clients relative to non-clients. The study presents results from case studies of four selected MFIs across Central America, East Africa, Southern Africa, and South Asia. The tool aims to increase transparency in microfinance's poverty outreach. Findings were credible and consistent with the MFIs' missions, supporting its potential for broader application in assessing poverty among MFI clients and informing rural financial policies for food security among the poor.

title: Markets and Housing Finance
abstract: We examine the extent to which markets enable the provision of housing finance across a wide range of countries. Housing is a major purchase requiring long-term financing, and the factors that are associated with well functioning housing finance systems are those that enable the provision of long-term finance. Across all countries, controlling for country size, we find that countries with stronger legal rights for borrowers and lenders (through collateral and bankruptcy laws), deeper credit information systems, and a more stable macroeconomic environment have deeper housing finance systems. These same factors also help explain the variation in housing finance across emerging market economies. Across developed countries, which tend to have low macroeconomic volatility and relatively extensive credit information systems, variation in the strength of legal rights helps explain the extent of housing finance. We also examine another potential factor--the existence of sizeable government securities markets--that might enable the development of emerging markets' housing finance systems, but we find no evidence supporting that.
summary: This paper investigates how markets facilitate housing finance across a diverse set of countries, focusing on the factors enabling long-term financing. The study finds that stronger legal rights for borrowers and lenders (collateral and bankruptcy laws), deeper credit information systems, and stable macroeconomic environments are associated with deeper housing finance systems globally and in emerging markets. In developed countries, variations in legal rights are key. The authors also explored the impact of government securities markets on emerging markets' housing finance but found no supporting evidence. Keywords: housing finance, financial markets, legal rights, credit information, macroeconomic stability.

title: A Framework to Use Public-Private Partnership for Smart City Projects
abstract: The concept of Smart City has been emerging as a strategic set of integrated initiatives encompassing infrastructures, technology and digital services for the purpose of enhancing the quality of life of citizens. However, the development and implementation of Smart City projects require considerable investments that are difficult to fund with traditional public finance. In this context, Public-Private-Partnerships (PPP) appear to be suitable solutions to overcome the shortage of public finance and cuts on public spending. However, the adoption of PPP forms for Smart City projects has not been fully explored and only experimentally applied so far. In order to promote the usage of PPP to finance Smart City initiatives, this paper proposes some PPP financial instruments and discusses the associated strengths and weaknesses. In particular, the use of Project Finance, Revenue Sharing and Social Impact Bonds are suggested as sound alternatives and suitable sources of financing for Smart City project
summary: This paper investigates the use of Public-Private Partnerships (PPP) as a solution for financing Smart City initiatives, which typically require significant investments beyond traditional public funding. The authors propose and analyze various PPP financial instruments, including Project Finance, Revenue Sharing, and Social Impact Bonds, discussing their strengths and weaknesses. The goal is to promote the adoption of these alternatives to overcome public finance shortages and facilitate the development and implementation of Smart City projects aimed at enhancing citizens' quality of life through integrated infrastructures, technology, and digital services. This research is relevant for urban development and sustainable finance.

title: Stochastic Volatility in a Macro-Finance Model of the US Term Structure of Interest Rates 1961-2004.
abstract: This paper generalizes the standard homoscedastic macro-finance model by allowing for stochastic volatility, using the ‘square root’ specification of the mainstreamfinance literature. Empirically, this specification dominates the standard model because it is consistent with the square root volatility found in macroeconomic time series. Thus it establishes an important connection between the stochastic volatility of the mainstream finance model and macroeconomic volatility of the Okun (1971) - Friedman (1977) type. This research opens the way to a richer specification of both macroeconomic and term structure models, incorporating the best features of both macro-finance and mainstream-finance models.Macro-finance, affine term structure, heteroscedasticity
summary: This paper generalizes the standard homoscedastic macro-finance model by incorporating stochastic volatility using the 'square root' specification prevalent in mainstream finance. This empirical approach is superior as it aligns with the square root volatility observed in macroeconomic time series, thereby linking mainstream finance's stochastic volatility with Okun-Friedman type macroeconomic volatility. The research aims to enrich macroeconomic and term structure models by integrating the strengths of both macro-finance and mainstream finance frameworks, paving the way for more sophisticated specifications. Keywords include macro-finance, affine term structure, and heteroscedasticity.

title: Finance matters
abstract: We present a model in which the importance of financial intermediation for development can be measured. We generate financial differences by varying the degree to which contracts can be enforced. Economies where enforcement is poor employ less capital and less efficient technologies. Yet, accounting for all the observed dispersion output requires a higher capital share or a lower elasticity of substitution between capital and labor than usually assumed. We find that the effects of changes in those technological parameters on output are markedly larger when financial frictions are present. Finance, that is, matters.Financial markets ; Productivity
summary: This paper presents a model to measure the importance of financial intermediation for economic development, focusing on how contract enforceability influences financial differences. The authors demonstrate that economies with poor contract enforcement utilize less capital and less efficient technologies. Calibrated simulations reveal these effects are significant. The study finds that explaining observed output dispersion necessitates a higher capital share or lower elasticity of substitution between capital and labor than typically assumed. Crucially, the impact of technological parameter changes on output is markedly greater when financial frictions are present, emphasizing that finance matters. Keywords: financial intermediation, economic development, contract enforcement, capital share, elasticity of substitution, financial frictions.

title: Business financing in early 1957
abstract: Business enterprises - Finance ; Corporations - Finance
summary: This document analyzes business financing trends in early 1957, noting continued high spending and borrowing but shifts in composition. It highlights maintained plant and equipment expenditures, curtailed inventory purchasing, and smaller corporate income tax payments compared to 1956. Profits and depreciation allowances provided a larger share of funds, alongside record-level capital market borrowing. Bank borrowing moderated, and corporate liquid asset balance reductions were smaller. The paper also discusses the narrow spread between stock and bond yields, influencing investment flow into the corporate bond market, and changes in yield spreads throughout the period.

title: Applied Computational Intelligence for finance and economics
abstract: This article introduces some relevant research works on computational intelligence applied to finance and economics. The objective is to offer an appropriate context and a starting point for those who are new to computational intelligence in finance and economics and to give an overview of the most recent works. A classification with five different main areas is presented. Those areas are related with different applications of the most modern computational intelligence techniques showing a new perspective for approaching finance and economics problems. Each research area is described with several works and applications. Finally, a review of the research works selected for this special issue is given.Publicad
summary: This article provides an overview of relevant research in computational intelligence applied to finance and economics. It aims to offer a foundational context and starting point for newcomers, while also surveying the most recent advancements. The authors present a classification system comprising five main application areas that utilize modern computational intelligence techniques to address financial and economic problems, detailing several works and applications within each. The paper concludes with a review of selected research works featured in this special issue, focusing on computational intelligence, finance, economics, and their applications.

title: Online Personal Finance Learning
abstract: True Potential PUFin’s trilogy of free, online personal finance modules is designed to give adults the knowledge and tools they need to make better financial decisions, in bite-size chunks of learning. Between May 2014 and May 2016, a total of 53,770 people registered for Managing My Money, the first course in the trilogy, which gives people the foundations for good personal finance management. This paper looks in detail at Managing My Money: what the course covers, who has taken the course, and what impact the course has had
publisher: True Potential Centre for the Public Understanding of Finance, Open University
summary:
This paper examines "Managing My Money," the first module in True Potential PUFin
h	s trilogy of free, online personal finance courses. Designed to equip adults with financial literacy, the course covers foundational personal finance management. The study details the course content, participant demographics (53,770 registrants between May 2014 and May 2016), and its impact. This analysis provides insights into effective online learning in personal finance, targeting improved financial decision-making among the adult population, and is useful for understanding financial education and online learning platforms.

title: Housing finance in transition economies : the early years in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union
abstract: The transition to markets dominates the development agenda of the 1990s. Financial sector reforms are central to a successful transition to a market economy. The author focuses on one dimension of these reforms: the development of housing finance institutions and services. He presents a progress report for the years since 1989, when the road to change opened with the collapse of communist regimes in most countries. Rather than a detailed account of reform in 25 countries, he offers a general framework for analyzing change and evaluating the prospects for rapid development of market-based housing finance systems. To understand why sound housing finance systems have not yet developed, one must consider factors in four key reform areas: the macroeconomic policies adopted to liberalize the economy and stabilize prices; privatization policies, in particular in housing and real estate; the strategies adopted - whether by design or by default - to reform the financial sector; the nature of the financial priorities and institutional constraints affecting housing finance reform strategies followed in different countries. Housing finance policy development has been somewhat haphazard in many countries. But the evidence suggests that the transition economiesthat have achieved low inflation, have adopted radical banking reforms, and seriously reformed and liberalized their real estate sector should be among the first to develop a modern system of housing finance.Non Bank Financial Institutions,Banks&Banking Reform,Payment Systems&Infrastructure,Housing Finance,Public Sector Economics&Finance,Banks&Banking Reform,Housing Finance,Public Sector Economics&Finance,Non Bank Financial Institutions,Municipal Financial Management
fieldOfStudy: Business, Housing Finance, Financial Sector Reforms
summary: This report examines the development of housing finance institutions and services in transition economies since 1989, following the collapse of communist regimes. Instead of a detailed country-by-country account, the author provides a general framework to analyze change and assess the prospects for market-based housing finance systems. Key factors inhibiting development include macroeconomic policies, privatization (especially in housing), financial sector reform strategies, and institutional constraints. The evidence suggests that transition economies with low inflation, radical banking reforms, and liberalized real estate sectors are best positioned to develop modern housing finance systems. This study highlights the importance of comprehensive reform for housing finance development.

title: Project Finance as a Driver of Economic Growth in Low-Income Countries
abstract: This study investigates the role of project finance as a driver of economic growth. We hypothesize that project finance is beneficial to the least developed economies as it compensates for any lack of domestic financial development. The contractual structure unique to project finance should lead to better investment management and governance. Investigating 90 countries from 1991 to 2005, we find support for our hypothesis. Project finance indeed fosters economic growth and this effect is strongest in low-income countries, where financial development and governance is weak.financial economics and financial management ;
summary: This study investigates the critical role of project finance in driving economic growth, particularly in least developed economies. The authors hypothesize that project finance effectively compensates for a lack of domestic financial development due to its unique contractual structure, which fosters superior investment management and governance. Analyzing data from 90 countries between 1991 and 2005, the research confirms this hypothesis. The findings indicate that project finance significantly promotes economic growth, with the strongest positive impact observed in low-income countries characterized by weak financial development and governance. This research is important for understanding economic development and financial strategies.

title: Ownership Characteristics and Access to Finance: Evidence from a Survey of Large Privatised Companies in Hungary and Poland
abstract: We examine financial constraints and forms of finance used for investment, by analysing survey data on 157 large privatised companies in Hungary and Poland for the period 1998 – 2000. The Bayesian analysis using Gibbs sampling is carried out to obtain inferences about the sample companies’ access to finance from a model for categorical outcome. By applying alternative measures of financial constraints we find that foreign companies, companies that are part of domestic industrial groups and enterprises with concentrated ownership are all less constrained in their access to finance. Moreover, we identify alternative modes of finance since different corporate control and past performance characteristics influence the sample firms’ choice of finance source. In particular, while being industry-specific, the access to domestic credit is positively associated with company size and past profitability. Industrial group members tend to favour bond issues as well as sells-offs of assets as appropriate types of finance for their investment programmes. Preferences for raising finance in the form of equity are associated with share concentration in a non-monotonic way, being most prevalent in those companies where the dominant owner holds 25%-49% of shares. Close links with a leading bank not only increase the possibility of bond issues but also appear to facilitate access to non-banking sources of funds, in particular, to finance supplied by industrial partners. Finally, reliance on state finance is less likely for the companies whose profiles resemble the case of unconstrained finance, namely, for companies with foreign partners, companies that are part of domestic industrial groups and companies with a strategic investor. Model implications also include that the use of state funds is less likely for Polish than for Hungarian companies.financial constraints, investment, enterprises, foreign ownership, industrial groups, concentrated ownership, leading bank, proportional-odds model, Bayesian updating.
fieldOfStudy: Business, Finance, Investment, Enterprises, Foreign Ownership, Industrial Groups, Concentrated Ownership, Leading Bank, Proportional Odds Model, Bayesian Updating
summary:
This study examines financial constraints and various forms of finance utilized for investment by analyzing survey data from 157 large privatized companies in Hungary and Poland (1998

2000). Employing Bayesian analysis with Gibbs sampling, the research identifies that foreign companies, those within domestic industrial groups, and enterprises with concentrated ownership face fewer financial constraints. Different corporate control and past performance characteristics influence finance source choices, with domestic credit linked to company size and profitability. Industrial group members favor bond issues and asset sell-offs, while equity raising is most prevalent with 25%-49% share concentration. Links with leading banks facilitate bond issues and access to non-banking funds, particularly from industrial partners. Reliance on state finance is less likely for unconstrained companies.

title: Real Estate, the External Finance Premium and Business Investment: A Quantitative Dynamic General Equilibrium Analysis
abstract: This paper studies the connection between the capital market and the real estate market. Empirically, we find that positive real house price shocks lower the external finance premium and stimulate nonresidential investment and real GDP. Our theoretical framework is able to mimic the volatility of the external finance premium, the relative price of real estate and capital, and the investment in real estate and capital. It also captures the cyclicality of the external finance premium and of real estate prices. The contribution of real estate price fluctuations to the variability of the external finance premium and the GDP is confirmed to be significant.External Finance Premium, Residential and Corporate Real Estate, Capital Market Imperfections, Equilibrium Default, Real Estate Price Volatility.
summary: This paper investigates the relationship between the capital market and the real estate market. The authors empirically demonstrate that positive real house price shocks decrease the external finance premium and stimulate nonresidential investment and real GDP. A theoretical framework is developed to model the volatility of the external finance premium, the relative price of real estate and capital, and investment in both markets. The study confirms the significant contribution of real estate price fluctuations to the variability of the external finance premium and GDP, offering insights into capital market imperfections and real estate price volatility.

title: "Money in Finance"
abstract: This paper begins by defining, and distinguishing between, money and finance, and addresses alternative ways of financing spending. We next examine the role played by financial institutions (e.g., banks) in the provision of finance. The role of government as both regulator of private institutions and provider of finance is also discussed, and related topics such as liquidity and saving are explored. We conclude with a look at some of the new innovations in finance, and at the global financial crisis, which could be blamed on excessive financialization of the economy.Money; Money of Account; Finance; Financial Instruments; Financial Institutions; Financial Innovation; Financialization; Liquidity; Saving; State Money; Chartalism; Shadow Bank; Hyman Minsky; Securitization; Robert Clower
summary: This paper defines and distinguishes between money and finance, exploring alternative financing methods. It examines the pivotal role of financial institutions, government as a regulator and provider of finance, and related concepts like liquidity and saving. The study also discusses financial innovations and attributes the global financial crisis to excessive financialization, drawing parallels with the 1929 Great Depression. Key topics include Money of Account, Financial Instruments, Financial Innovation, Securitization, and the views of Hyman Minsky and Robert Clower, highlighting issues of debt, income flows, and economic stability.

title: Financialisation and Capitalist Accumulation : Structural Accounts of the Crisis of 2007-9
abstract: The crisis of 2007-9 resulted from a financial bubble marked by weak production, expanding bank assets, and growing household indebtedness. For these reasons the crisis casts light on the financialisation of capitalist economies. The literature on financialisation generally links weak production with booming finance; according to some, causation runs from weak production to booming finance, while for others it runs in the opposite direction. This article argues that there is no direct causation between booming finance and weak production. Rather, financialisation represents systemic transformation of capitalist production and finance, which ultimately accounts for the crisis of 2007-9, and has three main features. First, less reliance of large corporations on banks; second, banks shifting their activities toward mediating in open markets and transacting with individuals; third, increasing implication of individuals in the operations of finance.
fieldOfStudy: Business, Financialization, Capitalist Accumulation, Financial Crisis, Political Economy
summary: This article examines the 2007-9 financial crisis, arguing it stemmed from the systemic transformation of capitalist production and finance, rather than direct causation between booming finance and weak production. The study identifies three key features of financialisation: reduced reliance of large corporations on banks, banks shifting to open market mediation and individual transactions, and increased individual involvement in finance. This transformation ultimately explains the crisis, highlighting the financialization of capitalist economies, household indebtedness, and bank asset expansion.

title: Measuring the Impact of Trade Finance on South African Export Flows
abstract: Trade finance (or short-term credit) plays a crucial role in facilitating international trade yet is particularly vulnerable to financial crises as banks increase the pricing on all trade finance transactions to cover increased funding costs and higher credit risks. Whereas South Africa’s financial institutions largely managed to strengthen their capital positions during the global financial crisis, the country’s trade flows and access to capital (in particular trade finance and its costs) were hit hard by the crisis. Little is known about the extent of shortages or ‘gaps’ in trade finance and the impact of this on South Africa’s recent trade performance. Whilst our research recognises that access to trade finance is not the main cause of South Africa’s trade contraction, our research suggests that a one percentage point increase in the interbank lending rate of our trade partner could reduce exports by approximately ten percent, all else equal.exports trade finance crisis
summary: This research investigates the impact of trade finance on South African export flows, specifically exploring how financial crises affect the availability and cost of short-term credit essential for international trade. The study acknowledges that while trade finance access is not the sole cause of South Africa's trade contraction, it demonstrates a significant sensitivity. Key methods involve analyzing economic data to quantify the relationship between interbank lending rates and export performance. Findings suggest that a one percentage point increase in a trade partner's interbank lending rate could reduce South African exports by approximately ten percent. Keywords include trade finance, exports, financial crisis, South Africa, interbank lending rate.

title: Gauge theory of Finance?
abstract:
Some problems with the recent stimulating proposal of a ``Gauge Theory of
Finance'' by Ilinski and collaborators are outlined. First, the derivation of
the log-normal distribution is shown equivalent both in information and
mathematical content to the simpler and well-known derivation, dating back from
Bachelier and Samuelson. Similarly, the re-derivation of Black-Scholes equation
is shown equivalent to the standard one because the limit of no uncertainty is
equivalent to the standard risk-free replication argument. Both re-derivations
of the log-normality and Black-Scholes result do not provide a test of the
theory because it is degenerate in the limits where these results apply. Third,
the choice of the exponential form a la Boltzmann, of the weight of a given
market configuration, is a key postulate that requires justification. In
addition, the ``Gauge Theory of Finance'' seems to lead to ``virtual''
arbitrage opportunities for pure Markov random walk market when there should be
none. These remarks are offered in the hope to improve the formulation of the
``Gauge Theory of Finance'' into a coherent and useful framework.Comment: 4 page
fieldOfStudy: Business, Finance, Financial Mathematics, Quantitative Finance
summary: This paper critically evaluates the recent "Gauge Theory of Finance" proposal by Ilinski and collaborators. It argues that the derivations of log-normal distribution and Black-Scholes equation are equivalent to established methods by Bachelier and Samuelson, and do not offer a valid test of the new theory due to degeneracy. The authors also question the justification for the Boltzmann-like exponential form of market configuration weight, and point out that the theory seems to predict "virtual" arbitrage opportunities in pure Markov random walk markets where none should exist. These critiques aim to refine the theory into a more coherent framework.

title: Impact of the Financial Crisis on Finance Sector Workers
abstract: [Excerpt] The purpose of this paper is to briefly review the background, causes, characteristics and trajectory of the ongoing financial and economic crisis; to define the financial services sector, its occupations and their educational requirements, as well as recent important trends; to provide a preliminary assessment of the impact of the crisis on finance sector jobs; and to give suggestions on possible policy responses to address the effects of the crisis on finance sector workers
summary: This paper reviews the background, causes, characteristics, and trajectory of the ongoing financial and economic crisis, defining the financial services sector, its occupations, and educational requirements. It assesses the crisis's impact on finance sector jobs and suggests policy responses to support affected workers. Findings indicate a permanent decline in finance sector activity, leading to job losses and income stagnation. Policy recommendations include unemployment benefits, social protection, activation policies, public employment services, and re-training programs for finance sector workers to facilitate transitions and reduce long-term unemployment.

title: Institutional arrangements for public debt management
abstract: This paper analyzes institutional arrangements for public debt management by reviewing the experience of OECD countries during the late 1980s and 1990s. It discusses principal-agent issues arising from the delegation of authority from the Minister of Finance to the debt management office and describes how countries have designed governance structures and control and monitoring mechanisms to deal with these issues. The paper also discusses what lessons emerging market countries and transition countries can draw from the experience of advanced OECD countries. The OECD experience clearly indicates that-regardless of whether the debt management office is located inside or outside the Ministry of Finance-four issues are of vital importance: 1) Giving priority to strategic public policy objectives rather than tactical trading objectives. 2) Strengthening the institutional capacity to deal with financial portfolio management and with the public policy aspects of debt management. 3) Modernizing debt management. 4) Creating mechanisms to ensure successful delegation and accountability to the Ministry of Finance and Parliament.Public Sector Economics&Finance,Public&Municipal Finance,Strategic Debt Management,Payment Systems&Infrastructure,Urban Economics,Public Sector Economics&Finance,Strategic Debt Management,Urban Economics,Public&Municipal Finance,Banks&Banking Reform
fieldOfStudy: Business, Public Sector Economics & Finance, Public & Municipal Finance, Strategic Debt Management, Payment Systems & Infrastructure, Urban Economics, Banks & Banking Reform
summary: This paper analyzes institutional arrangements for public debt management, drawing lessons from OECD countries' experiences in the late 1980s and 1990s. It focuses on principal-agent issues arising from delegating authority from the Minister of Finance to debt management offices and examines governance structures and control mechanisms. The study identifies four critical issues: prioritizing strategic public policy over tactical trading objectives, strengthening institutional capacity for financial portfolio and public policy aspects of debt management, modernizing debt management, and establishing mechanisms for accountability. These findings offer valuable insights for emerging market and transition economies regarding public debt and financial management.

title: Enhancing the Capability of Central Finance Agencies
abstract: A well-organized and effective finance ministry and its associated central finance agencies (CFAs) are essential to good fiscal outcomes. Recent studies of CFAs in selected low-income countries demonstrate that their organizational structure varies widely and that decision making on public finance is strongly influenced by political economy factors. This note presents some common themes arising from the case studies and provides some descriptive evidence about the organizational structure of the CFAs. This note also includes evidence of a “U-curve” pattern in the development of the organizational structure of CFAs over the long term. It confirms that political economy analysis, though difficult to apply in practice, is highly relevant in the development of reform strategies for strengthening CFAs and public financial management systems.finance ministry, central finance agencies, fiscal, public finance, political economy, low-income countries, development, reform, public financial management, World Bank
fieldOfStudy: Business, Finance, Public Financial Management, Political Economy
summary: This note examines the organizational structure and decision-making processes of central finance agencies (CFAs) in low-income countries, highlighting their essential role in achieving good fiscal outcomes. Drawing on case studies, it identifies common themes and provides descriptive evidence about CFA structures, observing a "U-curve" pattern in their long-term development. The study confirms that political economy analysis, despite practical challenges, is crucial for developing effective reform strategies to strengthen CFAs and public financial management systems. Keywords include finance ministry, public finance, political economy, and fiscal management.

title: International money and international inflation, 1958-1973
abstract: Inflation (Finance) ; United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference ; Monetary theory ; International finance
fieldOfStudy: Business, Finance, Monetary Theory, International Finance
summary: This paper analyzes the prolonged surge of international inflation from the early 1960s to 1973-74, arguing it was primarily a monetary phenomenon rather than solely due to commodity supply shocks or social conflict. The author attributes excessive money supply, leading to a decay in purchasing power, mainly to the fiscal-monetary policies of the United States. Specifically, American government fiscal deficits generated Treasury debt, which was then absorbed by central banks, increasing the global money supply. The Bretton Woods system linked monetary systems, making smaller economies subservient to American policies, propagating inflation globally and fostering a form of seignorage.

title: Household External Finance and Consumption
abstract: This paper uses mortgage data to construct a measure of terms on which households access to external finance, and relates it to consumption at both the aggregate and cohort levels. The Household External Finance (HEF) index is based on the spread paid by risky borrowers in the mortgage market. There is evidence that the terms of access to external finance matter more for the consumption of young cohorts in UK data. Results are robust to a wide variety of specifications.external finance; terms of access; household consumption; birth cohorts; pseudo panels
fieldOfStudy: Business, External Finance, Household Consumption, Birth Cohorts, Pseudo Panels
summary: This paper investigates the relationship between the terms of household external finance and consumption at both aggregate and cohort levels in the UK. The authors construct a Household External Finance (HEF) index based on mortgage market spreads paid by risky borrowers. Their analysis reveals that the terms of access to external finance significantly impact the consumption of younger cohorts, with results demonstrating robustness across various specifications. This study provides insights into household consumption dynamics and the role of financial access, utilizing mortgage data and pseudo panels for analysis.

title: MARKETING (RULES OF MARKETING)
summary: This text explores key marketing rules for business improvement, drawing on examples from prominent American businessmen. It highlights three main principles: embracing business change (Howard Schultz, Starbucks), understanding a product's true nature (Patrick Doyle, Domino's Pizza), and eliminating unnecessary elements (Alan Roger Mulally, Ford). The document details how Schultz adapted Starbucks' offerings, Doyle admitted Domino's pizza quality issues in a campaign, and Mulally streamlined Ford's operations with the "One Ford" strategy. These case studies provide practical insights into effective marketing and strategic business management.

title: From physical marketing to web marketing
abstract: Reviews the criticism of the 4P marketing mix framework as the basis of traditional and virtual marketing planning. Argues that the customary marketing management approach, based on the popular marketing mix 4Ps paradigm, is inadequate in the case of virtual marketing. Identifies two main limitations of the marketing mix when applied in online environments namely the role of the Ps in a virtual commercial setting and the lack of any strategic elements in the model. Identifies the critical factors of the Web marketing and argues that the basis for successful e-commerce is the full integration of virtual activities into the company's physical strategy, marketing plan and organisational processes. The 4S elements of the Web marketing mix framework offer the basis for developing and commercialising business to consumer online projects. The model was originally developed for educational purposes and has been tested and refined by means of three case studies
fieldOfStudy: Business, E-Commerce Strategy, Internet Commerce, E-Commerce Marketing, Web Marketing, E-Commerce Business Models
summary: This paper critically reviews the traditional 4P marketing mix framework, arguing its inadequacy for virtual marketing. It identifies limitations, including the role of the Ps in online settings and the absence of strategic elements. The authors propose that successful e-commerce necessitates fully integrating virtual activities into a company's physical strategy, marketing plan, and organizational processes. They introduce the 4S elements of the Web marketing mix framework for developing and commercializing Business-to-Consumer online projects, a model initially designed for educational purposes and refined through three case studies. Key concepts include E-Commerce Strategy, Web Marketing, and E-Commerce Business Models.

title: Call for Papers: Transnational Marketing Journal
abstract: Transnational Marketing Journal invites practitioners, consultants, and academics to submit papers worthy of contribution to the literature. We invite papers that model marketing, critically discuss marketing practices, investigate consumer experiences, and the dynamics of the marketing organisation with regards to the transnational context and relevance. We also invite papers that study consumer preferences, marketing environment, marketing strategy, segmentation analysis, consumer reference points, marketing theory, modelling and so on. Critical and novel approaches and methods are particularly welcome.Transnational Marketing, Consumption, Mobile Consumers, Multinational Organisations, Transnational Firms
summary: The Transnational Marketing Journal (TMJ) invites practitioners, consultants, and academics to submit papers on transnational marketing practices and scholarship, encouraging critical approaches. It welcomes submissions on modeling marketing, consumer experiences, organizational dynamics, consumer preferences, marketing environment, strategy, segmentation, reference points, and theory. The journal particularly seeks critical and novel approaches and methods, including interdisciplinary and mixed-method work. Submissions can be research papers, theoretical/conceptual papers, case studies, debates, viewpoints, research notes, or data presentations, focusing on global marketing challenges.
