abstract: Ideal for those new to the topic of marketing, this book discusses the eight elements of the marketing mix with direct reference to the specifics of the hospitality industry.Part A: Introduction: Introduction to hospitality marketing; Part B: Pre-encounter marketing; Marketing research; Understanding and segmenting customers; Competitive strategies; Developing the offer; Locating the offer; Pricing the offer; Distributing the offer; Communicating the offer; Part C: Encounter marketing; Managing the physical environment; Managing service processes; Managing customer-contact employees; Part D: Post-encounter marketing; Managing customer satisfaction; Relationship marketing; Part E: The marketing plan; Marketing Planning.434 page(s)2nd ed
summary: This book provides an introduction to marketing principles, specifically tailored for the hospitality industry. It covers the eight elements of the marketing mix across five parts: introduction, pre-encounter, encounter, post-encounter marketing, and marketing planning. Key topics include marketing research, customer segmentation, competitive strategies, developing, locating, pricing, distributing, and communicating the offer, as well as managing the physical environment, service processes, customer-contact employees, satisfaction, and relationship marketing. Despite aiming for an alternative approach to traditional American marketing textbooks, the review suggests it leans more towards management studies than celebrating marketing theory and international hospitality practices.

title: Marketing
abstract: Marketing is a human activity aimed at customer satisfaction through exchange. The main objective of the course is a formation of a system of knowledge about the nature and content marketing as a philosophy of business activity in the market economy and competition in preparation for the adoption of qualified decisions in marketing
summary: These methodical instructions for practical marketing lessons aim to provide full-time students in specialties like Finance, Banking and Insurance, Management, and Entrepreneurship with a comprehensive understanding of marketing. The course focuses on developing a system of knowledge about marketing's nature and content as a business philosophy in a market economy, preparing students for qualified decision-making. Key topics include pricing strategies, marketing communications, and distribution policy, essential for future market leaders and professionals.

title: Marketing space : a conceptual framework for marketing events
abstract:
Despite the growing resonance of events within the marketing domain, they continue to receive scant coverage in academic literature, and remain a poor relation to other forms of marketing communication. This detracts from them realising their potential as a relevant and pervasive marketing delivery method.

Couched between the authors previous and future (ongoing) empirical work in this area, this article provides much needed conceptual development.  The paper introduces the core construct of ‘marketing space’ and associated framework.  Marketing space represents the distinctive environment a marketing event creates, which is unlike that cultivated by other communication methods.  Marketing space is a transient reality where representatives of an organisation come together physically, and in a planned manner, with a gathering of existing and future customer’s, clients, and wider stakeholders.

Marketing events are a grouping that comprises a wide and rich variety of event types, which can be termed ‘marketing event platforms’.  These range from the largest of congresses or trade shows, to the smallest and most intimate of seminars or hospitality events.  The conceptual framework of marketing space, with associated concepts provides the basis of a new lexicon for practitioners and academics interested in, and utilising, events for marketing purpose.

The paper also explores the rationale for the growing resonance of marketing events; examining the characteristics of events, including experiential, interactive, targeted, and relational.  The paper ends with the introduction of two dichotomies to the lexicon of marketing events’ direct and indirect events, and exclusive and non exclusive events
summary: This article addresses the underexplored area of marketing events in academic literature, proposing a conceptual framework centered on “marketing space.” Marketing space defines the unique, transient environment created by planned physical gatherings of organizations with customers and stakeholders, distinct from other communication methods. The paper categorizes marketing event platforms, ranging from congresses to intimate seminars, and explores their increasing relevance due to characteristics like being experiential, interactive, targeted, and relational. It also introduces dichotomies of direct/indirect and exclusive/non-exclusive events, aiming to provide a new lexicon for practitioners and academics utilizing events for marketing purposes.

title: Cooperative International Direct Marketing:  An Alternative for Asian-Pacific Countries to Increase Exports to Industrial Market Economies
abstract: Exporters from Asian-Pacific Countries can successfully establish marketing presence in Industrial Market Economies by directly marketing products in these country markets. Direct marketing potential in Industrial Marketing Economies can be determined by examining two critical factors: the direct marketing infrastructure and emerging environmental changes. Although the resource requirement for direct marketing is quite substantial, exporters, who combine their resources to engage in cooperative international direct marketing, will find it easier to establish marketing presence in Industrial Market Economics
summary: This article examines the potential for exporters from Asian-Pacific Countries to establish a marketing presence in Industrial Market Economies through direct marketing. It identifies two critical factors for determining direct marketing potential: the existing infrastructure and emerging environmental changes. The authors note the substantial resource requirements for direct marketing but propose cooperative international direct marketing as an effective alternative for exporters. This approach allows businesses to combine resources, thereby simplifying the process of establishing a market presence and increasing exports. Key concepts include direct marketing, international trade, and cooperative strategies.

title: MARKETING IN SOCIAL NETWORKS
summary: This document explores the phenomenon of social network marketing, highlighting its growing importance given the extensive time people spend on platforms like Facebook and VKontakte. It discusses key metrics for evaluating social networks, such as user count and unique visits, and outlines strategies for increasing these figures, including advertising, quality improvement, and new service integration. The text differentiates between commercial (paid banners) and free advertising methods, detailing factors influencing banner pricing. It concludes by asserting the efficiency and cost-effectiveness of social network advertising, offering a perspective on the Ukrainian market and future growth.

title: ANALISIS STRATEGI MARKETING COMMUNICATION  DALAM MENINGKATKAN OKUPANSI DI GRAND MERCURE MALANG MIRAMA
abstract:
In the hotel industry, marketing communications is an important component in the marketing strategy of a good or service. The type of research used by researchers is descriptive research with a qualitative approach. The data collection techniques used were observation, interviews and documentation. The informants taken for data analysis were assistant marketing communications manager, guest experience manager, revenue executive at Grand Mercure Malang Mirama. Grand Mercure Malang Mirama's marketing strategy is running well because of a plan and marketing support activities which are driven by integrated marketing communication.

The results of this research are about the marketing communication strategy carried out by Grand Mercure Malang Mirama which is quite effective but needs ongoing evaluation. The marketing communication activities carried out by Grand Mercure Malang Mirama are media advertising, public relations, relationship management. customers (Customer Relationship Management), sales promotions (sales promotions), direct sales (personal selling), direct marketing (direct marketing), direct experiences to customers (event & experience). customer relationship management (customer relationship management).

Keywords: marketing strategy, integrated marketing, hote
summary: This research employs a descriptive qualitative approach to investigate the marketing communication strategies of Grand Mercure Malang Mirama in the hotel industry. Data collected through observation, interviews, and documentation with key marketing personnel revealed that integrated marketing communication drives a well-executed marketing strategy. The study identifies effective activities such as media advertising, public relations, customer relationship management, sales promotions, personal selling, direct marketing, and event experiences. While the strategy is effective, the findings suggest a need for ongoing evaluation. Keywords include marketing strategy, integrated marketing, and hotel industry marketing.

title: MARKETING OF LOYALTY
fieldOfStudy: Business, Marketing, Customer Loyalty, Loyalty Programs
summary: This text explores the concept of loyalty marketing, focusing on the development and implementation of loyalty programs to foster long-term customer relationships. It outlines basic tools such as discount programs, prize draws, accumulative discounts, and bonus incentives, alongside gift certificates and plastic cards. The document emphasizes "12 laws of customer loyalty," including staff loyalty, the 80/20 rule, staged loyalty, and centralized customer data management. It highlights the importance of offering valuable privileges, both tangible and intangible, advocating for a value-oriented customer approach in privilege selection across three stages: creative development, pilot study, and large-scale survey. The core message is that customer loyalty cannot be bought, but rather diversified through excellent service and special treatment, with discounts serving a targeted strategy benefiting both company and customer.

title: Marketing to Get Better Mileage from Your Resource: Kaynağınızdan Daha İyi Randıman Almak için Pazarlama
abstract: The article gives us an insight in marketing in the library. It shows why marketing is necessary and how the competition is growing even in our surroundings. This paper argues from a marketing point of view why it should be involved in all library routines. The article shows the difference between internal and external marketing. The article discusses some marketing tools, which are especially suitable for libraries. It also emphasises that everybody at the library should be involved directly or indirectly in the marketing
fieldOfStudy: Business, Library marketing, Internal marketing, External marketing, Boston Matrix, SWOT analysis, Marketing tools
summary: This article explores the necessity of marketing within libraries, highlighting growing competition and arguing for its integration into all library routines. It differentiates between internal and external marketing strategies and proposes specific marketing tools suitable for library environments. The paper emphasizes the importance of involving all library staff, directly or indirectly, in marketing efforts. Key concepts include library marketing, internal marketing, external marketing, Boston Matrix, and SWOT analysis, providing a framework for enhancing resource utilization and engagement in libraries.

title: TRICKY MARKETING: HISTORY OF BRILLIANT MARKETING MOVES
summary: This work explores the historical marketing strategies of successful global corporations to identify common features leading to prosperity. It investigates how companies like Timberland, Camel cigarettes, and De Beers achieved significant success by strategically altering their marketing policies, often by understanding consumer psychology and perceived value. The research aims to provide insights into building successful businesses amid modern market competition by examining historical examples of brilliant marketing moves and their impact on consumer demand and brand perception.

title: TRICKY MARKETING: HISTORY OF BRILLIANT MARKETING MOVES
summary: This work explores the history of several giant corporations, including Timberland, Camel cigarettes, and De Beers, to identify general features of successful marketing strategies. The study aims to understand how changing marketing policies contributed to their global success, focusing on practical implications for modern market economics and high competition. Key findings suggest that understanding consumer psychology and making bold strategic decisions, such as raising prices or creating intriguing campaigns, are crucial for achieving prosperity and satisfying human needs in a competitive landscape.

title: MARKETING AS WAR
summary: This text explores the concept of "Marketing as War," emphasizing a future where marketing plans heavily focus on competitive analysis, tactical planning, and strategic operations akin to military campaigns. It highlights the importance of understanding competitors' strengths and weaknesses, developing defensive and offensive strategies, and employing "guerrilla tactics" for smaller firms. The document provides examples like Michael Dell's flank attack in the computer industry and Grenada's "non-spoilt island" strategy in tourism to illustrate successful competitive approaches, advocating for continuous effort against competitors' weaknesses.

title: Internet-induced marketing techniques: Critical factors in viral marketing campaigns
abstract: The rapid diffusion of the Internet and the emergence of various social constructs facilitated by Internet technologies are changing the drivers that define how marketing techniques are developed and refined. This paper identifies critical factors for viral marketing, an Internet-based ‘word-of-mouth’ marketing technique. Based on existing knowledge, five types of viral marketing factors that may critically influence the success of viral marketing campaigns are identified. These factors are the overall structure of the campaign, the characteristics of the product or service, the content of the message, the characteristics of the diffusion and, the peer-to-peer information conduit. The paper discusses three examples of viral marketing campaigns and identifies the specific factors in each case that influence its success. The paper concludes with a viral marketing typology differentiating between viral marketing communications, unintended viral marketing and commercial viral marketing. This is still a rapidly evolving area and further research is clearly needed to monitor new developments and make sense of the radical changes these developments bring to the market

This paper identifies critical factors influencing the success of viral marketing campaigns, an Internet-based 
'word-of-mouth' marketing technique. Based on existing knowledge, five types of factors are identified: campaign 
structure, product/service characteristics, message content, diffusion characteristics, and peer-to-peer information conduit. The study discusses three examples of campaigns, highlighting specific success factors, and proposes a viral 
marketing typology differentiating between viral marketing communications, unintended viral marketing, and 
commercial viral marketing. Keywords: viral marketing, Internet marketing, word-of-mouth, marketing campaigns, 
digital marketing.

title: INTERNET MARKETING
summary: This text explores the growing importance and extensive applications of Internet marketing in the modern business landscape. It highlights how e-commerce and Internet marketing have become integral to profitable campaigns for both consumer and B2B sectors, especially in Ukraine. The discussion covers the core elements of the marketing mix—price, product, place, and promotion—as applied online. Key benefits include efficient feedback management, adaptability to market changes, identification of international partners, reduced overhead costs, and clearer statistical evaluation of campaign effectiveness. Internet marketing is presented as crucial for small companies' success and overall business efficiency.

title: TACTICAL MARKETING
summary: This text explores tactical marketing, defining it as the regular activity of drafting and realizing optimal combinations of marketing instruments. It emphasizes its role in planning immediate actions using concrete marketing tools, communicating with clients, managing prices, products, and distribution channels. Key stages include choosing a target segment, clarifying objectives, drafting the marketing mix, and executing action plans. The document differentiates tactical marketing from strategic marketing, highlighting its focus on sales promotion, assortment and pricing policies, distributor management, merchandising, advertising campaigns, and loyalty programs, ultimately aiming to attract clients and drive sales.

title: INTERACTIVE MARKETING
fieldOfStudy: Business, Interactive Marketing, Housing Management, Ukrainian Law
summary: This text examines the evolving landscape of housing management in Ukraine, highlighting the persistent monopoly of municipal companies despite the rise of private management firms and homeowners' associations (OSBB). It details legal changes, particularly the Law of Ukraine of 14.05.2015 number 417-VIII, which empowered condominiums to delegate management functions and saw a significant increase in OSBB registrations. The text also transitions to discuss the advantages of interactive marketing for both consumers and producers, outlining tools like SEO, social media, content marketing, mobile marketing, and e-commerce, citing major brands as successful implementers.

title:
Imputing unknown competitor marketing activity with a Hidden Markov
  Chain
abstract:
We demonstrate on a case study with two competing products at a bank how one
can use a Hidden Markov Chain (HMC) to estimate missing information on a
competitor's marketing activity. The idea is that given time series with sales
volumes for products A and B and marketing expenditures for product A, as well
as suitable predictors of sales for products A and B, we can infer at each
point in time whether it is likely or not that marketing activities took place
for product B. The method is successful in identifying the presence or absence
of marketing activity for product B about 84% of the time. We allude to the
issue of whether, if one can infer marketing activity about product B from
knowledge of marketing activity for product A and of sales volumes of both
products, the reverse might be possible and one might be able to impute
marketing activity for product A from knowledge of that of product B. This
leads to a concept of symmetric imputation of competing marketing activity. The
exposition in this paper aims to be accessible and relevant to practitioners
summary: This study demonstrates how a Hidden Markov Chain (HMC) can infer a competitor's missing marketing activity using a case study of two competing bank products. By analyzing time series of sales volumes for both products and known marketing expenditures for one, the HMC successfully identifies the presence or absence of the competitor's marketing efforts with 84% accuracy. The paper also introduces the concept of symmetric imputation, exploring if marketing activity for one product can be inferred from the competitor's, suggesting broader applications for marketing intelligence and strategic decision-making in competitive markets.

title: Integrating R&D and marketing in new product development
abstract: R&D - marketing integration is considered to be a critical activity within New Product Development (NPD). A theoretical framework for the study of R&D - marketing integration levels developed by Gupta et al (1986) is one of the most widely cited R&D - marketing integration frameworks in scientific literature. It is based on the presumption that strategy, environmental, organizational and individual factors are those determining R&D - marketing integration levels and consequently NPD success. Several empirical studies have been conducted to test this framework, however most of them have dealt only with portions of Gupta et al (1986)'s model. This paper is an attempt to put forward and test an integrated research protocol for the study of R&D - marketing integration, based on this theoretical framework. Empirical evidence gained from a questionnaire survey and two company case studies show, that people active within the R&D - marketing interface perceive the studied constructs as relevant for R&D - marketing integration, thus giving confirmation to Gupta et al (1986)’s model. The presented research protocol can therefore be considered as a valid start into R&D - marketing integration research within an integrated framework
fieldOfStudy: Business, New Product Development, Marketing, Research and Development
summary: This paper presents and tests an integrated research protocol for studying R&D-marketing integration levels in New Product Development (NPD), building on Gupta et al.'s (1986) theoretical framework. The framework posits that strategic, environmental, organizational, and individual factors determine integration levels and NPD success. Empirical evidence from a questionnaire survey and two company case studies confirms that practitioners perceive these constructs as relevant. The findings validate Gupta et al.'s model and establish the proposed protocol as a sound foundation for future R&D-marketing integration research within an integrated framework. Keywords: R&D-marketing integration, New Product Development, theoretical framework, empirical study, research protocol.

title: Effects of Participation in a Simulation Game on Marketing Students' Numeracy and Financial Skills
abstract: The need to endow marketing graduates with skills relevant to employability grows ever more important. Marketing math and elementary financial understanding are essential employability skills, particularly given the contemporary emphasis on marketing metrics, but the evidence is that marketing graduates are often relatively weak in such skills. This article suggests that one educational strategy to improve numeracy and financial skills may be through the use of a marketing simulation game. Through the simulation game, students are exposed to marketing calculations and financial data in an engaging context that simulates the real world. It is hypothesized that marketing students’ numeracy and financial skills, and their self-efficacy with respect to marketing calculations, will improve following participation in a simulation game where numerical and financial analysis are necessary activities. Using a quasi-experimental research design, it is found that there are substantial and significant improvements in numerical and financial performance after participating in a simulation game, but that there is no improvement (and possibly a small decline) in self-efficacy related to these tasks. Marketing educators are advised that a marketing simulation game is a viable option to consider when seeking to improve students’ numeracy and financial skillsPeer reviewe
fieldOfStudy: Business, Marketing Education, Educational Measurement, Financial Literacy
summary: This study investigates the effectiveness of marketing simulation games in improving marketing graduates' numeracy and financial skills, which are crucial for employability in a metrics-driven environment. Employing a quasi-experimental design, the research hypothesizes that participation in such games will enhance students' skills and self-efficacy. Findings indicate substantial and significant improvements in numerical and financial performance after game participation. However, self-efficacy related to these tasks did not improve, and possibly declined. The study concludes that marketing simulation games are a viable option for educators to enhance students' quantitative and financial literacy, despite no observed improvement in self-efficacy.

title: Marketing career transitions: women marketers embedded in the profession?
abstract: This qualitative study explores a UK sample of 25 women marketing professionals and how their career paths are reached and moderated over time. The research addresses the women‟s reasons for moving from corporate marketing careers to self-employment in marketing and discovers that their career anchor is their embeddedness in the marketing profession which remains a constant throughout their career. This suggests that marketing talent is being lost to the corporate environment but not necessarily to the profession. It also suggests that the profession needs to acknowledge these career transitions when offering support to those practicing marketing
summary: This qualitative study investigates the career paths of 25 UK women marketing professionals, focusing on their transitions from corporate roles to self-employment. The research reveals that their career anchor is a deep embeddedness in the marketing profession, which remains constant despite changes in employment status. This suggests that while marketing talent may be shifting from corporate environments, it is not lost to the profession itself. The study emphasizes the need for the marketing profession to recognize and support these career transitions. Keywords: women in marketing, career transitions, self-employment, marketing professionals, career anchor, qualitative study.

title: MARKETING STRATEGIES
summary: This document outlines the concept of marketing strategy, defining it as a process that enables organizations to focus resources on opportunities to boost sales and gain a sustainable competitive advantage. It covers foundational and long-term activities, including strategic situation analysis, formulation, evaluation, and selection of market-oriented strategies. Key components include a clear positioning statement, encompassing product, pricing, promotion, and distribution. The text emphasizes internal and external environmental scanning, including customer and competitor analysis, and aligns marketing with a company's mission. It also touches on managing diverse product portfolios and life cycles.

title: Marketing Percolation
abstract:
A percolation model is presented, with computer simulations for
illustrations, to show how the sales of a new product may penetrate the
consumer market. We review the traditional approach in the marketing
literature, which is based on differential or difference equations similar to
the logistic equation (Bass 1969). This mean field approach is contrasted with
the discrete percolation on a lattice, with simulations of "social percolation"
(Solomon et al 2000) in two to five dimensions giving power laws instead of
exponential growth, and strong fluctuations right at the percolation threshold.Comment: to appear in Physica
fieldOfStudy: Business, Marketing, Statistical Mechanics, Percolation Theory
summary: This paper presents a percolation model, supported by computer simulations, to illustrate how new product sales penetrate consumer markets. It contrasts the traditional marketing approach, based on differential/difference equations like the logistic equation, with discrete percolation on a lattice. Simulations of "social percolation" in two to five dimensions reveal power laws instead of exponential growth, along with strong fluctuations at the percolation threshold. This research provides insights into diffusion of innovations, market penetration, and social dynamics relevant to marketing strategy and theoretical physics.

title: Consumer Marketing and the Airline Industry
abstract: The fundamentals of consumer marketing as applied to the airline industry are considered. An attempt is made to boil down the mystique and jargon which frequently surround the subject of marketing. Topics covered include: (1) The marketing concept; (2) consumer expectations from airlines; (3) planning of marketing strategy; and (4) the roles of advertising, sales, and middlemen
summary: This paper examines the fundamental principles of consumer marketing specifically as they relate to the airline industry, aiming to demystify its jargon. It covers key topics including the marketing concept, understanding consumer expectations from airlines, developing effective marketing strategies, and the roles played by advertising, sales, and middlemen. The author emphasizes that successful marketing starts with the customer, requiring research, analysis, and strategic development of products, pricing, distribution, and promotion to meet consumer needs. It concludes by noting the growing interest in marketing within the airline sector, predicting significant future growth in consumer-oriented marketing approaches for airlines.

title: The interface between transactional and relational orientation in small service firm's marketing behaviour
abstract: This paper presents and discusses findings of a cross-country study of small service firm marketing behavior. These findings demonstrate that small service firms are flexible in the marketing approaches that they adopt. They reveal that such firms are transactional and relational orientated in their marketing activities and that for growing firms, marketing activities are used to create short-term transactions and form relations with key stakeholders. This finding implies that transactional and relationship marketing should be regarded as complementary. The findings presented also demonstrate that the marketing approach selected by participating small firms is determined by a range of customer characteristics of which repeat business is only one. An integrated framework containing elements of transactional and relational approaches is proposed as an appropriate way of describing the marketing behaviours of investigated firms
summary: This paper examines the marketing behavior of small service firms through a cross-country study. It finds that these firms exhibit flexibility, adopting both transactional and relational marketing approaches. For growing firms, marketing activities simultaneously facilitate short-term transactions and foster relations with key stakeholders, implying that transactional and relationship marketing are complementary. The study also reveals that customer characteristics, including repeat business, influence the chosen marketing approach. An integrated framework combining transactional and relational elements is proposed to describe these marketing behaviors. Key concepts include small service firms, marketing behavior, transactional marketing, relationship marketing, and customer characteristics.

title: OUTRAGEOUS MARKETING
summary: This document explores various forms of rarity and their application to luxury goods marketing. It delineates natural, technological, limited edition, and information-based rarity, and introduces a six-factor marketing complex for luxury items, including product quality, price, sales personnel, passion (knowledge), and pleasure in purchasing. The text also touches upon "outrageous marketing" strategies, emphasizing their suitability for certain markets (e.g., youth products, fashion) and potential risks in serious sectors like finance, stressing the importance of quality ideas and audience understanding for effective implementation. The document also briefly discusses 'goods-awards' as a sales promotion tool.

title: An agent-based fuzzy cognitive map approach to the strategic marketing planning for industrial firms
abstract: This is the post-print version of the final paper published in Industrial Marketing Management. The published article is available from the link below. Changes resulting from the publishing process, such as peer review, editing, corrections, structural formatting, and other quality control mechanisms may not be reflected in this document. Changes may have been made to this work since it was submitted for publication. Copyright @ 2013 Elsevier B.V.Industrial marketing planning is a typical example of an unstructured decision making problem due to the large number of variables to consider and the uncertainty imposed on those variables. Although abundant studies identified barriers and facilitators of effective industrial marketing planning in practice, the literature still lacks practical tools and methods that marketing managers can use for the task. This paper applies fuzzy cognitive maps (FCM) to industrial marketing planning. In particular, agent based inference method is proposed to overcome dynamic relationships, time lags, and reusability issues of FCM evaluation. MACOM simulator also is developed to help marketing managers conduct what-if scenarios to see the impacts of possible changes on the variables defined in an FCM that represents industrial marketing planning problem. The simulator is applied to an industrial marketing planning problem for a global software service company in South Korea. This study has practical implication as it supports marketing managers for industrial marketing planning that has large number of variables and their cause–effect relationships. It also contributes to FCM theory by providing an agent based method for the inference of FCM. Finally, MACOM also provides academics in the industrial marketing management discipline with a tool for developing and pre-verifying a conceptual model based on qualitative knowledge of marketing practitioners.Ministry of Education, Science and Technology (Korea
summary: This paper addresses the unstructured decision-making problem of industrial marketing planning, characterized by numerous variables and uncertainties. It proposes applying fuzzy cognitive maps (FCM) to this challenge, introducing an agent-based inference method to handle dynamic relationships, time lags, and reusability in FCM evaluation. The MACOM simulator is developed to allow marketing managers to conduct 'what-if' scenarios, assessing the impact of changes on FCM variables. The approach is demonstrated through an industrial marketing planning problem for a global software service company in South Korea, offering practical support for managers and contributing to FCM theory.

title: Recommendations for Responsible Food Marketing to Children
abstract: The marketing of unhealthy foods to children and youth is a major public health concern. Children in the United States grow up surrounded by food and beverage marketing, which primarily promotes products with excessive amounts of added sugar, salt, and fat, and inadequate amounts of fruits, vegetables, and whole grains. This document provides a comprehensive set of model definitions for food marketing practices directed to children. The recommendations, developed by a national panel of experts convened by Healthy Eating Research, define the child audience range as birth to 14 years of age; address the range of food marketing practices aimed at children; and specify the strategies, techniques, media platforms, and venues used to target children. When paired with sound nutrition criteria, these recommendations will help support responsible food marketing to children by addressing current loopholes in food marketing definitions and self-regulatory efforts that allow companies to market unhealthy foods and beverages to children
summary: This document addresses the major public health concern of marketing unhealthy foods to children and youth. Developed by a national panel of experts convened by Healthy Eating Research, it provides a comprehensive set of model definitions for food marketing practices targeting children aged birth to 14 years. The recommendations specify strategies, techniques, media platforms, and venues used to target children. When combined with sound nutrition criteria, these definitions aim to support responsible food marketing by closing loopholes in current self-regulatory efforts that allow companies to promote unhealthy products to children. Keywords: food marketing, child health, public health, nutrition, unhealthy foods.

title: INTERNET MARKETING
summary: This text explores internet marketing, defining it as a boundless field encompassing online, email, and wireless media marketing, often integrating digital customer data and ECRM systems. It combines creative and technical internet aspects like design, development, advertising, and sales. Key business models discussed include e-commerce, lead-based websites, affiliate marketing, and local internet marketing. The text also highlights consumer concerns regarding information privacy and transaction security in online business, and the strategies merchants and payment systems employ to build trust and assure reliability through strong branding, feedback systems, and buyer protection.

title: The Marketing of Political Candidates: Current Tactics and Future Strategies
abstract: Alexander Haig, Jr., a 1988 presidential hopeful, remarked, concerning campaign politics:  I have learned the secret of life--it\u27s in marketing  (1986). The emergence of marketing in non-business organizations, so well documented in recent writings, is accented by its ascendancy in politics (Laczniak and Caywood 1987;  Four More years  1985; Mauser 1983; Rothschild 1978). Any campaign manager interested in applying orthodox marketing principles to his or her craft will find the use of marketing techniques in the political sphere particularly instructive
fieldOfStudy: Business, Marketing, Political Campaigns, Public Relations
summary: This article explores the application of marketing principles in political campaigns, noting its increasing ascendancy in non-business organizations. It traces the introduction of marketing tools into the political process, particularly through public relations in the early 1950s. The authors highlight the importance of applying orthodox marketing principles to campaign management, advocating for ethical and strategically correct applications. The paper concludes by emphasizing the need for voluntary effective mechanisms to control political marketing practices, stressing that the ethical implications of political marketing will continue to be a subject of public discussion and research. Keywords: political marketing, campaign management, public relations, ethics.

title: RESTAURANT MARKETING
summary: This text outlines effective restaurant marketing strategies, emphasizing the need for comprehensive planning beyond traditional 4P's. It critiques common budget allocations towards new customer acquisition as inefficient, instead advocating for brand-building by aligning promises with delivery, and strategic positioning through a Unique Selling Proposition. Key components include profitability analysis, competitive menu analysis, and continuous staff training to foster 'ambassadors'. The text also advises allocating 3%-6% of sales to marketing, proportionally to sales volume, and highlights McDonald's as a successful example of aligning marketing with customer desires like speed, quality, and value.

title: VIRAL MARKETING
summary: This document explores viral marketing, a low-cost technique leveraging user-shared entertaining content to build brand awareness. It involves various formats like videos, games, and texts, aiming to generate positive word-of-mouth recommendations and avoid spam. The internet has greatly facilitated its success, enabling rapid dissemination. Key strategies include email marketing, free digital content, blogs, and discussion boards, all designed to encourage high pass-along rates. Viral marketing is attractive due to its ease of execution, low cost, good targeting, and high, rapid response rates, often creating media coverage disproportionate to advertising budgets. Keywords: viral marketing, digital marketing, brand awareness, word-of-mouth, internet marketing.

title: INBOUND MARKETING
summary: This article introduces and explains the concept of "inbound marketing" as a modern marketing strategy. It highlights inbound marketing's focus on creating free, useful content to build customer loyalty and trust, contrasting it with traditional aggressive advertising. The author emphasizes that this approach leads to more stable demand and efficient budget allocation. Key principles include SEO/SEM, blogging, social media use, RSS feeds, podcasts, eBooks, and free e-commerce tools, all centered on high-quality content to engage users and increase product awareness.

title: GREEN MARKETING
fieldOfStudy: Business, Marketing Research, Green Marketing, International Trade
summary: This text discusses the importance of marketing research in foreign trade, focusing on consumer segmentation and target market selection to enhance competitiveness and product development. It highlights the critical role of quality information in marketing and commercial activities, emphasizing data collection, storage, and processing. The document also touches upon the challenges and growth of green marketing, particularly concerning the lack of consensus on what constitutes "green" despite increasing global concern over climate change. Additionally, it briefly addresses Ukrainian marketing research issues amidst economic crises and market restructuring, notably the impact on effective market relations.

title: International sport marketing : practical and future research implications
abstract: Purpose – Sport is a global product and service that many people around the world enjoy playing, watching and participating in. Whilst there has been an abundance of global media attention on sporting events such as the Olympics and World Football Cup, there seems to be a lack of integration between the sports marketing and international business disciplines both from a practical and also academic standpoint. This paper aims to discuss international sport marketing and why it is an important attribute of business-to-business marketing. Design/methodology/approach – The aim of the paper is to provide practical implications and research avenues for those seeking to further investigate international sport marketing as a unique area of academic research. The introduction to the paper focuses on the importance of sport to the global economy and how entrepreneurship is ingrained in many sport businesses and organizations. Next, different areas of international business management that relate to entrepreneurial sport marketing ventures are discussed in terms of future research directions and practical implications. These include how entrepreneurial sport ventures affect internationalization, branding, corporate social responsibility, tourism, regional development, marketing and action sports.Findings – The paper concludes by finding that there are numerous research avenues for future research on international sport marketing that combine different areas of marketing together with the sport marketing and international business literature. In addition, there is enormous potential for linking the sports marketing and international business literature through focusing on entrepreneurial sport ventures that occur worldwide.Research limitations/implications – The authors demonstrate the need to take an international perspective of sports marketing and business-to-business relationships.Practical implications – The paper discusses how and why sport firms interact in the international marketplace and how future competition will benefit from more sport-based business-to-business partnerships.Originality/value – The paper examines the important area of international sports marketing and how businesses that are both profit and non-profit orientated collaborate. The paper explores the concept of international sports marketing, and discusses the practical and future research implications of this exciting new field of marketing research.<br /
fieldOfStudy: Business, Marketing, Sports Marketing, International Business
summary: This paper addresses the notable absence of integration between sports marketing and international business disciplines, aiming to highlight international sport marketing as a crucial aspect of business-to-business marketing. It adopts a conceptual approach, reviewing existing literature to identify practical implications and future research avenues. The discussion emphasizes the global economic importance of sport and the ingrained entrepreneurship within sport organizations, linking entrepreneurial sport ventures to internationalization, branding, corporate social responsibility, tourism, regional development, marketing, and action sports. The findings reveal extensive research potential in combining marketing areas with sport marketing and international business literature, particularly through entrepreneurial sport ventures worldwide.

title: An O ( n log n ) algorithm for the two-machine ow shop problem with controllable machine speeds
abstract: There appear to be some problems in defining direct marketing. Bauer and Miglautsch (1992) present direct marketing as a relational marketing process. According to Schofield (1995: 36), "Such a definition excludes much marketing work which employs individual direct marketing techniques on a pragmatic and eclectic basis, alongside nondirect marketing elements, and in which the use of such techniques is normally seen as direct marketing". He suggests that two definitions may be needed: a general, inclusive definition of direct marketing, e.g. the DMA-definition, which allows any use of any direct marketing technique to be recognized as an instance of direct marketing, and a definition of a direct marketing system, e.g. Bauer and Miglautsch''s definition, covering cases where a product or service is marketed exclusively by direct marketing methods (Schofield 1995: 37). This distinction suggests that several levels of direct marketing can be distinguished. The definition of direct marketing as proposed by Raaijmaakers et al. (1992) allows for distinguishing several levels of direct marketing without the need for more than one definition. They stress the importance of direct relationships and the specific use of marketing instruments. Based on their definition, four levels of direct marketing can be distinguished (Hoekstra 1994). Three of them concern strategic decisions and one is at the operational level (see table 1). These types cover the ever broadening field of direct marketing, including the direct marketing system as well as the use of direct marketing methods.marketing ;
summary: This paper addresses the definitional challenges of direct marketing, proposing that a single, comprehensive definition is sufficient to distinguish various levels of direct marketing. It critically examines existing definitions, such as those by Bauer and Miglautsch (1992) and Schofield (1995), highlighting their limitations in encompassing the full scope of direct marketing practices. The authors advocate for Raaijmaakers et al.'s (1992) definition, which emphasizes direct relationships and specific marketing instrument usage, allowing for the distinction of four levels, covering both strategic and operational aspects, and integrating both direct marketing systems and individual direct marketing methods.

title: Marketing in Higher Education: A Stage Model Concerning Where It\u27s Been and Where It\u27s Going
abstract: The ideas of Williford (1987) are used to propose a four-stage model describing the evolution of marketing in many colleges and universities. It elaborates on the thinking endemic to strategic marketing management and frameworks drawn from business marketing which will likely become more prominent in higher education. (Author/GLR
summary: This paper proposes a four-stage model illustrating the evolution of marketing in colleges and universities, building upon Williford's 1987 work. It explores the principles of strategic marketing management and frameworks from business marketing that are expected to gain prominence in higher education. The authors argue that marketing plays a central and critical role in efficient and effective university management, similar to human resources and finance. This research highlights the increasing importance of marketing strategy and management within educational institutions, drawing parallels with established business practices.

title: MARKETING IN PUBLISHING BUSINESS
summary: This study explores marketing in the publishing business, distinguishing between publishing marketing (publisher-author relations) and book marketing (commercializing products to satisfy intellectual needs). It highlights the unique challenges of marketing books, which are spiritual works rather than daily necessities, leading to a significant decline in book publishing in Ukraine over the last two decades. The research emphasizes the need for specific, creative marketing approaches in this industry, showcasing successful examples like literary festivals and author presentations to engage consumers. Keywords: publishing marketing, book marketing, intellectual needs, book industry, Ukraine, literary events, consumer engagement.

title: Denial at the top table: status attributions and implications for marketing
abstract: Senior marketing management is seldom represented on the Board of Directors nowadays, reflecting a deteriorating status of the marketing profession. We examine some of the key reasons for marketing’s demise, and discuss how the status of marketing may be restored by demonstrating the value of marketing to the business community. We attribute marketing’s demise to several related key factors: narrow typecasting, marginalisation and limited involvement in product development, questionable marketing curricula, insensitivity toward environmental change, questionable professional standards and roles, and marketing’s apparent lack of accountability to CEOs. Each of these leads to failure to communicate, create, or deliver value within marketing. We argue that a continued inability to deal with marketing’s crisis of representation will further erode the status of the discipline both academically and professionally
summary: This paper examines the diminishing presence of senior marketing management on Boards of Directors, attributing it to a deteriorating status of the marketing profession. It identifies key reasons for this decline, including narrow typecasting, marginalisation in product development, questionable curricula, insensitivity to environmental change, and a lack of accountability. The authors propose restoring marketing's status by demonstrating its value to the business community, arguing that failure to address this crisis of representation will further erode the discipline's academic and professional standing. The study emphasizes strategies for enhancing marketing's perceived value and strategic involvement.

title: Misunderstood or lacking legitimacy?
abstract: In spite of the rising interest in marketing within professional service firms in the last twenty years, past research has identified a reluctant acceptance and application of marketing within these organisations. The present paper will debate whether this is due to lack of understanding of the role of marketing, lack of acceptance as a valid management discipline suitable for professional services or lack of legitimacy as a profession in its own right. A brief overview of the role of marketing will be followed by a discussion on the professions, professional legitimacy and the professional organisation. Qualitative research was done in the form of in-depth interviews with marketing executives and accountancy and law professionals in fourteen firms across the UK. The research has revealed generational differences, misconceptions and outright conflict leading to resistance in the introduction and application of marketing, although the professionals have individually practiced a wide variety of marketing activities in their pursuit of gaining and maintaining clients.  There has been a conspicuous resistance to the acceptance of marketing as a management tool within certain firms. The findings have opened up the spectre of inter-professional competition on legitimacy grounds
summary: This paper investigates the reluctant acceptance and application of marketing within professional service firms despite rising interest. It debates whether this resistance stems from a lack of understanding, acceptance as a valid management discipline, or professional legitimacy. Employing qualitative research through in-depth interviews with marketing executives and professionals in fourteen UK firms, the study reveals generational differences, misconceptions, and conflicts hindering marketing integration. While professionals individually practice marketing, there's significant resistance to accepting it as a management tool, raising questions about inter-professional competition on legitimacy grounds. Keywords: Marketing, Professional Service Firms, Professional Organization, Professional Legitimacy, Qualitative Research.

title: Offensive and Defensive Marketing in Spatial Competition
abstract: While it is well-established that travel costs impact on customer preference toward local service providers, research about how this situation affects competitive marketing strategies remains sparse. This paper investigates, in a local market with two competing service providers, whether service providers should undertake defensive marketing, targeted at the nearest customers who typically prefer their offering for convenience and/or offensive marketing, directed to relatively remote customers who favor the rival as the closest alternative. We find that the service providers can exclusively undertake either defensive marketing or offensive marketing or combine the two in a full differentiated strategy at the equilibrium. We compare the outcomes of these three strategic options to identify the conditions under which they are worth implementing. Main findings suggest that service providers are better off undertaking offensive marketing alone when their rival’s retaliatory offensive capacity is weak and customers incur small travel costs. Otherwise, service providers may exclusively undertake defensive marketing or combine it with offensive marketing when travel costs become significant. Also, service providers should not invest in any marketing activity when they have no market power, like in the case of two adjacent outlets in a mall. Finally, the implications of these findings are discussed.MEC under projects ECO2014-52343-P and ECO2017-82227-P (AEI) and by Junta de Castilla y León under projects VA024P17 and VA105G18, co-financed by FEDER fund
fieldOfStudy: Business, Marketing, Spatial Competition, Resource Allocation, Travel Costs
summary: This paper investigates competitive marketing strategies in a local market with two service providers, considering the impact of travel costs on customer preference. It explores whether providers should use defensive marketing (targeting nearby customers) or offensive marketing (targeting remote customers), or a combination. The study finds that service providers may undertake exclusive defensive, exclusive offensive, or a fully differentiated strategy. Key findings suggest offensive marketing is best when a rival's offensive capacity is weak and travel costs are small. When travel costs are significant, defensive marketing, possibly combined with offensive, is preferable. The research also highlights that no marketing is advisable without market power.

title: Modern marketing,determinant concept in the reappraisal of business and organizational professions and of training professionals in the new economy
abstract: The content of marketing is countinously redefined and reflected in new concepts, therefore leading to the development of a new concept the modern marketing. The modern marketing has as orientation and tendency the concept of internal marketing, understood as an extension of the vision, marketing philosophy on persons and networks within companies. The concept, at large, is reflected by the apparition and development of specific instruments: integrated marketing, integrated marketing communication, management of the supply-sales relationship. Integrated marketing is the concept that is based on defining marketing as a philosophy, optic, vision on all activities of the company and especially the difficulty and inefficiency of cooperation as a modality to implement this concept. This assessment raises the problem of using the modern marketing in education, as a necessity to modernize the management system and also the educational system.marketing evolution, marketing capabilities, marketing education
fieldOfStudy: Business, Marketing Evolution, Marketing Capabilities, Marketing Education
summary: This paper examines the evolution of marketing concepts, highlighting the emergence of 'modern marketing' and its orientation towards 'internal marketing.' The authors propose that modern marketing extends philosophical principles to individuals and networks within companies, manifesting through tools like integrated marketing and supply-sales relationship management. It defines marketing as a pervasive company philosophy, emphasizing the challenges of cooperation in its implementation. The study advocates for applying modern marketing principles in education to modernize both management and educational systems, addressing marketing evolution, capabilities, and education. It also notes the historical necessity to reestablish a professional marketing association in Romania.

title: Student Attitudes Toward Client Sponsors and Learning: An Analysis of the Effects of Incorporating a Client Sponsored Project in an Introductory Marketing Course
abstract: This study examines i) the effects of a client-sponsored project (CSP) on student attitudes toward a sponsoring client, ii) the effects of a CSP on student attitudes toward learning core marketing concepts, and iii) moderators of student attitudes toward learning core marketing concepts. Introductory marketing course students prepared marketing plans for a client-sponsor who awarded cash prizes. The CSP yielded i) positive student attitudes toward client sponsors and ii) beliefs that CSPs enhance learning of core marketing concepts and increase confidence in academic ability. Positive attitudes toward competition and instructor helpfulness strengthened student perceptions that the CSP enhanced learning
summary: This study investigated the impact of client-sponsored projects (CSPs) on student attitudes in introductory marketing courses. Students developed marketing plans for a sponsor, yielding positive attitudes towards the clients and a belief that CSPs enhance learning of core marketing concepts and boost academic confidence. The research identified that positive attitudes towards competition and instructor helpfulness moderated student perceptions of enhanced learning. This highlights the effectiveness of experiential learning approaches and competition in improving student engagement and educational outcomes in marketing education.

title: The Marketing of Small Enterprises, Guerilla Marketing
abstract: The work is focused on approaches and techniques used by companies for identifying and fulfilling of the consumers’ needs and expectations, while making profit with little or limited resources in various stages of firm development (start-up stage) or in small enterprises. Basic marketing principles and categories of conventional marketing shall be compared with the demands of the unconventional one, which is focused on practical and financially limited marketing (guerilla marketing). In this work, the accent will be put on direct marketing, new marketing paradigm, faceto- face marketing, relationship marketing, and most notably on guerilla marketing, which sole purpose is to achieve maximal goals with minimal resources.guerilla marketing, new marketing paradigm, direct marketing
fieldOfStudy: Business, Marketing, Guerilla Marketing, Direct Marketing
summary: This work explores various marketing approaches for small enterprises and start-ups operating with limited resources. It compares conventional marketing principles with unconventional strategies, emphasizing practical and financially constrained methods like guerilla marketing. The paper focuses on direct marketing, new marketing paradigms, face-to-face marketing, relationship marketing, and particularly guerilla marketing, which aims to maximize results with minimal investment. It highlights how guerilla marketing provides advantages to small companies, offering definition, economy, simplicity, and marketing awareness in a complex and competitive landscape.

title: MARKETING CHALLENGES IN UKRAINE
summary: This text examines marketing challenges in Ukraine, characterizing most enterprise activities as spontaneous or entrepreneurial. It highlights issues such as a lack of understanding regarding marketing's role in development and its link to profit, low status of marketing departments, delayed consideration of consumer preferences, and the presence of informal sectors and dumping. Despite these hurdles, there is a growing recognition of the need for comprehensive market research, exemplified by companies like "Trading Systems" that saw significant revenue growth after implementing such strategies to adjust production and product range. Keywords: marketing challenges, Ukraine, spontaneous marketing, market research, enterprise development, consumer preferences, competitive environment.

title: CONTROL OF MARKETING
summary: This text explores the psychological effects of advertising on children and its manipulative techniques, emphasizing that advertising, often biased and lacking objectivity, acts as a hidden instrument against free will. It discusses the critical role of marketing control in modern competitive markets, focusing on optimizing organizational relationships with the environment, ensuring long-term stability, and enhancing competitiveness. Additionally, the text defines cooperative advertising as a form of commercial advertising where two or more independent companies fund promotional efforts for a common communication goal, often seen in major partnerships like McDonald's and Coca-Cola, highlighting its importance in achieving marketing objectives.

title: Ethics of Marketing
summary: This publication systematically examines the application of moral standards to marketing decisions, behaviors, and institutions, positioning marketing ethics as a subset of broader business ethics. It distinguishes between positive marketing ethics, which describes current practices (e.g., prevalence of ethical codes, deceptive advertising violations), and normative marketing ethics, which prescribes how marketing "ought" to operate based on moral standards. The discussion emphasizes the use of moral theories in marketing situations. This work is crucial for understanding the ethical dimensions of marketing, business ethics, and corporate social responsibility.

title: Marketing applications: from Angry Birds to happy marketers
abstract: This marketing teaching case is focussed on the rapidly emergent industry associated with Apps for mobile devices. After setting the context in respect of the awe-inspiring numbers associated with these markets the case is made that innovative marketing is happening across all parts of the basic marketing framework – the 4Ps. The case presents many specific examples of marketing related decision making and outcomes, focussing on games-Apps such as Rovio’s best-selling Angry Birds game
summary: This marketing teaching case explores the rapidly growing mobile app industry, focusing on innovative marketing strategies within the 4Ps framework. It presents specific examples of marketing decision-making and outcomes, particularly in games-Apps like Rovio's "Angry Birds." The document highlights the significant numbers associated with these markets and discusses how marketing is evolving across product, price, place, and promotion. Keywords include mobile apps, marketing, 4Ps, game apps, and "Angry Birds."

title: Study of Rice Marketing System in Iran
abstract: Rice comes second after wheat in Iran`s food consumption economy. Rising population and recent growth in GDP has made Iran one of the greatest rice importer countries all over the world. That is why rice marketing has always been a controversial issue in Iran`s agricultural economics. To study rice marketing system in Iran, this paper aims to calculate rice marketing margin, market efficiency and marketing cost coefficient in seaside Mazandaran province( where 70 percent of domestic rice production is obtained )Over the period 2000-2010. Results show that firstly HYV`s wholesale marketing margin is less than local varieties in 2000 while this trend is reversed in 2010. Secondly, retail marketing margin, total marketing margin, market efficiency and cost marketing coefficient for local varieties are all greater than HYV. Consequently, agricultural cooperative`s encouragement would lead to decrease in rice marketing margin and role of traders and raises rice farmers earningsMazandaran Province, Marketing Margin, Rice, Marketing, Q13,
summary: This paper investigates the rice marketing system in Iran, focusing on Mazandaran province (a major domestic rice producer) between 2000 and 2010. The study aims to calculate rice marketing margin, market efficiency, and marketing cost coefficients. Key findings indicate that in 2000, high-yielding varieties (HYV) had lower wholesale marketing margins than local varieties, a trend reversed by 2010. Additionally, retail and total marketing margins, market efficiency, and cost marketing coefficients were greater for local varieties. The research concludes that encouraging agricultural cooperatives could reduce rice marketing margins, diminish the role of traders, and ultimately increase farmers' earnings, thereby improving marketing efficiency.

title: Leeds and the Northern Arts Prize
abstract:
Purpose - This paper aims to look at the nature of the relationship between the marketing of the contemporary visual arts, cultural tourism and city and urban regeneration. This exploratory study of the marketing of the contemporary visual arts in Leeds has, as its background narrative, the emergence of BritArt.



Design/methodology/approach - The growth of contemporary visual arts provides the context for a case study of the Northern Art Prize, which was first awarded in 2007.



Findings - The study found a number of factors for success that can aid urban renewal and city regeneration. Private sector marketing expertise levered into the management of the project was one critical success factor. Another was that private sector funding freed up marketers and artists and allowed risk-taking. Participants highlighted a lack of vision for the contemporary visual arts in the city and region and a strong desire for new collaborative working and new governance structures for the delivery of arts marketing and cultural tourism.



Originality/value - The Northern Art Prize offers much for the marketing of contemporary visual arts, cultural tourism, city branding and urban renewal. Investing in and marketing of the arts is argued to serve as a stimulus that can bring a range of benefits for the business and wider community. Marketing, especially arts marketing, can help deliver social, economic and urban regeneration
fieldOfStudy: Business, Marketing, Urban Regeneration, Cultural Tourism
summary: This exploratory study investigates the relationship between contemporary visual arts marketing, cultural tourism, and urban regeneration, set against the backdrop of BritArt and focusing on Leeds. Using a case study of the Northern Art Prize, established in 2007, the research identified key success factors for urban renewal, including private sector marketing expertise and funding enabling risk-taking. Participants noted a lack of vision for contemporary visual arts in the region, advocating for new collaborative working and governance structures for arts marketing and cultural tourism. The Northern Art Prize offers a model for city branding and economic development, highlighting the arts' role as a stimulus for broader community benefits.

title: Antecedent of Innovation and Marketing Performance In Batik Industry
abstract:
Batik is one of the important industries and the pride of Indonesia. Batik is a world cultural heritage which is originally Indonesia. In batik industry, innovation is one of the important factors that will improve marketing

performance. This study wanted to test some of the main drivers of innovation and marketing performance on Batik SMEs. The purpose of this study is (1) Testing the influence of social capital on innovation and marketing

performance; (2) Testing the effect of entrepreneurial orientation on innovation and marketing performance;

and (3) Testing the influence of co-creation on innovation and marketing performance. The research sample

consisted of 161 batik businesses in the city of Sragen and Purwodadi. Data were analyzed using SEM PLS

and processed using WarpPls with version 5. The results of this study indicate that only some of the hypotheses

are accepted, such as (1) entrepreneurial orientation is able to significantly improve innovation, (2) co-creation

is able to significantly increase innovation, (3) market capability is able to significantly improve innovation, and (4) market capability is able to significantly improve marketing performance



Keywords: Entrepreneurial Orientation, Social Capital, Market Capabilities, Co-Creation, Innovation, Marketing Performanc
summary: This study examines the drivers of innovation and marketing performance within Batik Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs) in Sragen and Purwodadi, Indonesia. Employing SEM PLS analysis on a sample of 161 businesses, the research investigated the impact of social capital, entrepreneurial orientation, and co-creation on these outcomes. Key findings indicate that entrepreneurial orientation, co-creation, and market capability significantly enhance innovation, and market capability also improves marketing performance. These insights are crucial for understanding and fostering growth in traditional craft industries through strategic business practices.

title: From search engine optimisation to search engine marketing management: development of a new area for information systems research
abstract:
Search Engine Optimisation was a term used by web developers in the late 90s to highlight the importance of increasing a website’s position in search engines’ results. Further development of the Internet in terms of the diversity of its users and uses such as e-commerce, blogging and wikis have highlighted the need for technical staff to work more closely with marketing professionals resulting in a new area of work – Search Engine Marketing Management. 



The paper highlights the emerging role of Search Engine Marketing Management as a new and increasingly important area for future information systems researchers and research. Reaching beyond the 'simple' undifferentiated goal of increasing visitors to a website, a mature perspective of marketing is developing - that of realising strategic marketing objectives. The practical contribution of this paper is found in the development of awareness among management roles of the importance and nuances of search engines and the tactics required to harness the benefits of multiple online communication channels within organisational marketing strategy
summary: This paper highlights the evolution from Search Engine Optimisation (SEO) to Search Engine Marketing Management (SEMM) as a critical area for information systems research. It argues that SEMM moves beyond simply increasing website visitors to achieving strategic marketing objectives by integrating technical and marketing expertise. The authors emphasize the importance of understanding search engines and leveraging multiple online communication channels within an organizational marketing strategy. This study contributes to developing management awareness regarding the nuances of online marketing tactics. Keywords: Search Engine Optimisation, SEO, Search Engine Marketing Management, SEMM, information systems, marketing strategy, online communication channels.

title: DO PROFITABLE GRAIN MARKETING STRATEGIES EXIST FOR KANSAS CROPS?
abstract: The issue of whether profitable preharvest and postharvest marketing strategies exist relative to harvest sales for Kansas crops for the 1985-1998 marketing years is addressed. Practical application of market efficiency concepts is discussed. Nonharvest wheat marketing strategies offered less opportunity relative to harvest sales than for feedgrains and especially soybeans.Grain marketing, efficient markets, futures, options, marketing strategies, Crop Production/Industries, Marketing,
fieldOfStudy: Business, Marketing, Crop Production, Industries, Efficient Markets, Futures, Options
summary: This paper investigates the profitability of preharvest and postharvest marketing strategies for Kansas crops, specifically corn, grain sorghum, soybeans, and wheat, relative to harvest sales between 1985 and 1998. The study evaluates various strategies using Kansas cash prices, commodity loan rates, and futures/options prices. While some studies suggest profitable preharvest strategies exist, others, based on efficient markets theory, disagree. Key methods involved constructing and analyzing marketing strategies, considering factors like futures hedges and options. Findings indicate that nonharvest wheat marketing strategies offered fewer opportunities compared to feedgrains and soybeans, highlighting differences in market efficiency across crops.

title: SOCIALLY RESPONSIBLE MARKETING
summary: This text explores socially responsible marketing, highlighting its instruments and benefits for companies of all sizes. It discusses how firms can attract consumers and influence loyalty through charity events or social project investments, citing David D'Alesandro's "Brand Warfare" and Nike as examples. The article emphasizes that socially responsible marketing, unlike legal liability, is not mandatory but significantly improves reputation, strengthens customer relationships, boosts loyalty, offers competitive advantages, and serves as a cost-effective branding and social problem-solving tool. Keywords: socially responsible marketing, brand loyalty, corporate social responsibility, charity, PR, branding.

title: Re-enchanting the Chinese Sport Spectator - A Postmodern perspective on Sport Marketing in China
abstract: The cultural and philosophical heritage of modernism underpinning general marketing management theory imparts profound implications for organisations operating in professional sport. This theoretical paper uses the context of China’s professional football industry to argue that marketing may benefit from a more postmodern approach to marketing management
summary: This theoretical paper explores the implications of modernism in general marketing management theory for professional sport organizations, particularly within China's professional football industry. It argues for the benefits of adopting a more postmodern approach to marketing management in this context. The study aims to "re-enchant" the Chinese sport spectator by shifting from traditional modernist marketing paradigms. Key concepts include modernism, postmodernism, sport marketing, professional football, and consumer engagement, offering a new perspective for marketing strategy in developing sport markets.

title:
Combining Traditional Marketing and Viral Marketing with Amphibious
  Influence Maximization
abstract:
In this paper, we propose the amphibious influence maximization (AIM) model
that combines traditional marketing via content providers and viral marketing
to consumers in social networks in a single framework. In AIM, a set of content
providers and consumers form a bipartite network while consumers also form
their social network, and influence propagates from the content providers to
consumers and among consumers in the social network following the independent
cascade model. An advertiser needs to select a subset of seed content providers
and a subset of seed consumers, such that the influence from the seed providers
passing through the seed consumers could reach a large number of consumers in
the social network in expectation.
  We prove that the AIM problem is NP-hard to approximate to within any
constant factor via a reduction from Feige's k-prover proof system for 3-SAT5.
We also give evidence that even when the social network graph is trivial (i.e.
has no edges), a polynomial time constant factor approximation for AIM is
unlikely. However, when we assume that the weighted bi-adjacency matrix that
describes the influence of content providers on consumers is of constant rank,
a common assumption often used in recommender systems, we provide a
polynomial-time algorithm that achieves approximation ratio of
$(1-1/e-\epsilon)^3$ for any (polynomially small) $\epsilon > 0$. Our
algorithmic results still hold for a more general model where cascades in
social network follow a general monotone and submodular function.Comment: An extended abstract appeared in the Proceedings of the 16th ACM
  Conference on Economics and Computation (EC), 201
summary: This paper introduces the amphibious influence maximization (AIM) model, integrating traditional marketing via content providers and viral marketing within social networks. The AIM framework uses a bipartite network between content providers and consumers, with consumers also forming a social network where influence propagates. The study addresses the advertiser's problem of selecting seed content providers and consumers to maximize influence spread. It proves the AIM problem is NP-hard to approximate and, under the assumption of a constant-rank weighted bi-adjacency matrix, provides a polynomial-time approximation algorithm with a ratio of $(1-1/e-\epsilon)^3$. These algorithmic results generalize to models with monotone and submodular cascade functions.

title: The student practitioner: developing skills through the marketing research consultancy project
abstract:
This paper examines the perceptions of a group of undergraduate students undertaking marketing research consultancy projects for employers. The projects are informed by action learning. The author’s intention is to demonstrate that this method of learning facilitates a level of student skill development that more traditional marketing courses find difficult to achieve.

Design/methodology/approach

The study is underpinned by an interpretivist approach. Research involved students taking part in two focus groups during the consultancy and the completion of pre consultancy and post consultancy open ended questionnaires. 

Findings

Findings suggest that the marketing consultancy project represents a way to help develop the general skills required by novice marketers. Students show an understanding of the importance of acquiring communicative, interpersonal, creative and team based skills. These assist them in developing a practical knowledge neglected by much existing marketing teaching.
