EEE has a wider influence on personal development and career planning than simply the intention to create new ventures. This paper builds on a prior study of international postgraduate students’ orientation to entrepreneurship education in their expectations of UK Higher Education, which confirmed that career development is a major motivator for international study in the UK (Rae & Woodier-Harris, 2012). The paper contributes new understanding of the relationships between EEE and graduate career intentions, especially at PG and international levels. The paper explores personal growth, confidence and identity development, formation of new career intentions and the application of learning. The international dimension is considerable and this is discussed.



Implications

The paper has implications for the marketing, design and delivery of EEE at international and HE institutional levels, as well as for the practices of educators in designing, validating and delivering programmes for entrepreneurial career development, at national and international levels.



Originality/Value

The paper contributes new understanding to the role of EEE in postgraduate career initiation at international level in a period of significant and complex economic transformation
fieldOfStudy: Business, Entrepreneurship, Higher Education, Careers, Internationalisation
summary: This paper explores how Enterprise & Entrepreneurship Education (EEE) influences postgraduate students' entrepreneurial intentions and career plans, particularly in the post-2008 'New Era' economy at an international level. It analyzes the learning experiences of 60 international postgraduate students on an Entrepreneurship program at the University of Lincoln, utilizing personal learning narratives and a validating survey. The study found that EEE significantly impacts personal development and career planning beyond just new venture creation, contributing new understanding to the relationships between EEE and graduate career intentions, especially for international postgraduate students. Implications for marketing, design, and delivery of international EEE programs are discussed.

title: Entrepreneurship Education: Embedding Practitioner Experience
abstract: In a report recently produced by the National Council for Graduate Entrepreneurship (NCGE), the National Endowment for Science, Technology and the Arts (NESTA) and the Council for Industry and Higher Education (CIHE) concluded that ‘Entrepreneurship education is currently taught primarily through modules in business school courses and extra-curricular activities. HEIs need to enhance the perception and relevance of entrepreneurship education, so students and staff recognise the value of its combination of innovation, creativity, collaboration and risk-taking skills to a wide range of disciplines’. This paper focuses on a ground breaking programme specifically designed to address these criticisms of the way in which enterprise and entrepreneurship is taught in universities. There are a huge number of programmes on offer across within European Higher Education with the words ‘enterprise’ and ‘entrepreneurship’ in the title, but what makes the BA (Hons) Enterprise and Entrepreneurial Management unique is the close involvement of entrepreneurs right from the outset, including course design, module content and delivery. This is achieved through an ‘entrepreneur in residence’ network, with Walter Herriot, Managing Director of St John’s Innovation Centre, Cambridge, one of the world’s leading incubation centres, as Director. This enables leading entrepreneurs to be embedded in fabric of the programme through playing a very active role in the continued development of the curriculum, content, and delivery of the pathway. Additionally, each student is allocated an entrepreneur as mentor for the duration of the three year programme. This paper will firstly explore the key issues raised by the policy community and others calling into question the appropriateness of the way in which enterprise and entrepreneurship is taught. It will then look at the way in which UK universities are responding to these comments. The paper concludes with a case study of an academic programme developed and delivered jointly by academics and practitioners.entrepreneurship; education; enterprise education.
summary: This paper addresses criticisms of entrepreneurship education in universities, advocating for enhanced perception and relevance by integrating innovation, creativity, collaboration, and risk-taking skills across disciplines. It details a unique BA (Hons) Enterprise and Entrepreneurial Management program that embeds entrepreneurs directly into course design, content, and delivery through an "entrepreneur in residence" network and student mentorships. The paper explores policy issues, UK university responses, and presents this program as a case study of academic-practitioner collaboration in entrepreneurship and enterprise education.

title: Attitudes of Higher Education students to new venture creation: a preliminary approach to the Portuguese case
abstract: Institutions of higher education have an important role in the generation of high tech ‘entrepreneurial capacity’. Being entrepreneurship in Portugal an emergent phenomenon there is an urgent need to better understand and develop this area not only by analysing the ‘supply side’ (i.e., the courses taught in this field) but also the ‘demand side’, that is, the attitudes of students, future potential entrepreneurs, to new venture creation. Based on 4413 responses of students enrolled in Portuguese higher education institutions, gathered in June-July 2008, we found, using a multivariate model, that students who had already created a firm although, on average, possess larger entrepreneurial experience and knowledge, they do not reveal high risk propensity or creativity. Those students that have taken some steps to create new businesses and, to a larger extent, those foreseeing their future career as owning their business have higher risk and creative profiles. Students who live in an environment which ‘breads’ entrepreneurship have stronger desire to become entrepreneurs. This supports the contention that entrepreneurship is a learned process and that school, teachers, and other institutions and individuals may encourage entrepreneurial behaviours. ‘Role models’ seem indeed to constitute a key factor fostering entrepreneurship among Portuguese higher education students – in the Portuguese case, the entrepreneur and entrepreneurial company references are, respectively, Belmiro de Azevedo and Sonae. Although in a descriptive analysis students enrolled in non-university (e.g., polytechnics) and private higher education institutions reveal higher effective and potential entrepreneurial propensities, when we (simultaneously) control for a vast number of factors which are likely to affect entrepreneurship propensity, such differences cease to be statistically relevant. Students’ personality (risk, creativity) and demographic traits (gender and age), competencies and familiarity with entrepreneurship (entrepreneurial experience, knowledge, awareness, interest), and contextual factors (professional experience, role models) are important determinants of entrepreneurial propensity, whereas the type of higher education institutions (public vs private, non-university vs university), and, to some extent, the degree (postgraduate vs undergraduate), and the scientific area, fail to emerge as key determinants.students; entrepreneurship; attitudes
summary: This study examines the role of higher education institutions in fostering entrepreneurial capacity in Portugal, an emergent phenomenon. Using a multivariate model on 4413 student responses from 2008, the research found that students who had already created a firm showed greater experience but not higher risk propensity or creativity. Conversely, those pursuing new ventures or aspiring to business ownership demonstrated higher risk and creative profiles. Living in an entrepreneurial environment also strengthened students' desire to become entrepreneurs, supporting the idea of entrepreneurship as a learned process influenced by role models. Student personality, demographics, competencies, and contextual factors were key determinants, while institutional type, degree, and scientific area were not significant.

title: Liquidity, Risk, and Occupational Choices.
abstract: We explore which financial constraints matter the most in the choice of becoming an entrepreneur. We consider a randomly assigned welfare program in rural Mexico and show that cash transfers signi cantly increase entry into entrepreneurship. We then exploit the cross-household variation in the timing of these transfers and nd that current occupational choices are signi cantly more responsive to the transfers expected for the future than to those currently received. Guided by a simple occu- pational choice model, we argue that the program has promoted entrepreneurship by enhancing the willingness to bear risk as opposed to simply relaxing current liquidity constraints.insurance; entrepreneurship; Financial constraints; liquidity;
summary: This study investigates the role of financial constraints in the decision to become an entrepreneur, utilizing a randomly assigned welfare program involving cash transfers in rural Mexico. The research demonstrates that these transfers significantly increase entrepreneurial entry. By analyzing cross-household variations in transfer timing, the authors find that future expected transfers have a greater impact on current occupational choices than currently received ones. A simple occupational choice model suggests that the program fosters entrepreneurship by enhancing risk-bearing willingness, rather than merely alleviating current liquidity constraints. Keywords include financial constraints, entrepreneurship, insurance, and liquidity.

title: Latent entrepreneurship across nations
abstract: The paper studies latent entrepreneurship across nations. There are three main findings. First, large numbers of people in the industrial countries say they would prefer to be self-employed. Top of the international ranking of entrepreneurial spirit come Poland (with 80% saying so), Portugal and the USA; bottom of the table come Norway (with 27% saying so), Denmark and Russia. Second, for individuals the probability of preferring to be self-employed is strongly decreasing with age, while the probability of being self-employed is strongly increasing with age. Third, we show that self-employed individuals have noticeably higher job satisfaction than the employed, so people's expressed wish to run their business cannot easily be written off as mistaken. We speculate on why so much entrepreneurial spirit lies dormant
summary: This paper investigates latent entrepreneurship across various nations, identifying three key findings. Firstly, a significant portion of the population in industrial countries expresses a preference for self-employment, with Poland, Portugal, and the USA showing high entrepreneurial spirit, while Norway, Denmark, and Russia rank lower. Secondly, the probability of desiring self-employment decreases with age, yet the probability of actually being self-employed increases with age. Thirdly, self-employed individuals report higher job satisfaction compared to employed counterparts, suggesting that the wish to run a business is not misguided. The study speculates on reasons for dormant entrepreneurial spirit.

title: Entrepreneurship Summit Executive Summary
abstract: Summarizes discussions from an April 2008 conference on the core components of an effective entrepreneurship support program, policy options for building an infrastructure that fosters innovation, and concepts to be explored, such as "economic gardening.
summary: This executive summary from the September 2008 Entrepreneurship Summit, sponsored by the Kauffman Foundation and the International Economic Development Council, synthesizes discussions from an April 2008 conference. It identifies core components of effective entrepreneurship support programs, explores policy options for building an innovation-fostering infrastructure, and introduces concepts like "economic gardening." The document highlights the Ewing Marion Kauffman Foundation's commitment to advancing entrepreneurship and innovation through research, education, and policy advocacy. Key themes include entrepreneurial ecosystem development, innovation policy, and economic growth strategies.

title: Entrepreneurial Activity, Self-Perception and Gender
abstract: Drawing on Bem's psychological theory of self-perception, this paper presents and tests a model that examines the impact of gender and entrepreneurial activity on entrepreneurial self-perception. Based on a sample of alumni of a large Midwestern U.S. university, regression techniques are used to identify those activities associated with self-perceptions of entrepreneurship, as well as direct and indirect effects of gender. Results support the model of both direct and indirect effects of gender. The paper provides insights into gender issues in entrepreneurship as well as the definition of entrepreneurship in general.entrepreneurship;gender;behavior;self-perception
summary: This paper investigates the influence of gender and entrepreneurial activity on entrepreneurial self-perception, drawing on Bem's psychological theory. Using regression techniques on a sample of alumni from a large Midwestern U.S. university, the study identifies activities linked to self-perceptions of entrepreneurship and analyzes the direct and indirect effects of gender. The results confirm the model, showing both direct and indirect gender effects. This research offers valuable insights into gender dynamics within entrepreneurship and contributes to the broader definition of entrepreneurship itself, with key terms like entrepreneurship, gender, behavior, and self-perception.

title: What does"entrepreneurship"data really show ? a comparison of the global entrepreneurship monitor and World Bank group datasets
abstract: This paper compares two datasets designed to measure entrepreneurship. The Global Entrepreneurship Monitor dataset captures early-stage entrepreneurial activity; the World Bank Group Entrepreneurship Survey dataset captures formal business registration. There are a number of important differences when the data are compared. First, GEM data tend to report significantly greater levels of early-stage entrepreneurship in developing economies than do the World Bank data. The World Bank data tend to be greater than GEM data for developed countries. Second, the magnitude of the difference between the datasets across countries is related to the local institutional and environmental conditions for entrepreneurs, after controlling for levels of economic development. A possible explanation for this is that the World Bank data measure rates of entry in the formal economy, whereas GEM data are reflective of entrepreneurial intent and capture informality of entrepreneurship. This is particularly true for developing countries. Therefore, this discrepancy can be interpreted as the spread between individuals who could potentially operate businesses in the formal sector - and those that actually do so: In other words, GEM data may represent the potential supply of entrepreneurs, whereas the World Bank data may represent the actual rate of entrepreneurship. The findings suggest that entrepreneurs in developed countries have greater ease and incentives to incorporate, both for the benefits of greater access to formal financing and labor contracts, as well as for tax and other purposes not directly related to business activities.Banks&Banking Reform,E-Business,Access to Finance,Microfinance,Information Security&Privacy
fieldOfStudy: Business, Banks & Banking Reform, E-Business, Access to Finance, Microfinance, Information Security & Privacy, Entrepreneurship
summary: This paper compares the Global Entrepreneurship Monitor (GEM) and World Bank Group Entrepreneurship Survey datasets, both designed to measure entrepreneurship. It identifies significant differences: GEM reports higher early-stage entrepreneurship in developing economies, while World Bank data is greater for developed countries. The discrepancy is linked to local institutional conditions and economic development, suggesting World Bank data measures formal economy entry rates and GEM captures entrepreneurial intent and informality. Findings indicate developed country entrepreneurs have greater incentives to incorporate for financing, labor contracts, and tax benefits.

title: High growth entrepreneurs, public policies and economic growth
abstract: This paper investigates whether the presence of ambitious entrepreneurs is a more important determinant of national economic growth than entrepreneurial activity in general. We use data from the Global Entrepreneurship Monitor to test the extent to which high growth ambitions of entrepreneurs affect GDP growth for a sample of 36 countries. Our results suggest that ambitious entrepreneurship contributes more strongly to macro-economic growth than entrepreneurial activity in general. We find a particularly strong effect of highexpectation entrepreneurship for transition countries. These results are interpreted in light of the ongoing debate about public policies designed to stimulate high growth start-ups.
summary: This paper examines whether ambitious entrepreneurship is a more significant driver of national economic growth than general entrepreneurial activity. Utilizing Global Entrepreneurship Monitor data from 36 countries, the study investigates the impact of entrepreneurs' high growth ambitions on GDP growth. Findings indicate that ambitious entrepreneurship contributes more substantially to macroeconomic growth, with a particularly strong effect observed in transition countries. These results inform the ongoing discussion regarding public policies designed to stimulate high-growth start-ups and their role in economic development.

title: The impact of export-oriented entrepreneurship on regional economic growth
abstract: Although export-oriented new ventures and the field of international entrepreneurship have received considerable attention by scholars during the last decade (Oviatt and McDougla, 2005), their potential economic impact has not been sufficiently analyzed yet. To the best of our knowledge, no studies on this issue have been carried out at regional level. Despite the increasing impact of globalization, regions have emerged as the essential and active unit of economic development process (Scott and Stopper, 2003). Regions are influential environments fostering entrepreneurship (Feldman, 2000). This is especially true for knowledge-based entrepreneurship since proximity to knowledge sources matters in order to discover opportunities and exploit them (Audretsch, 1998). Moreover, regions differ culturally and economically, and such differences encourage or discourage people to venture in entrepreneurial activity. We analyze the impact of export-oriented entrepreneurship on regional growth using data provided by the Global Entrepreneurship Monitor project and the Spanish Institute of Statistics, for 17 NUTS-2 Spanish regions over a period of six years. After controlling for catching-up effects (van Stel et al., 2005), as well as, other drivers of economic growth (e.g. change in technology capability and human capital), we found evidence that those regions with a higher percentage of adult population involved in export-oriented entrepreneurship experience a higher GDP growth. This relationship is greater as the level of foreign customers served by the entrepreneurial initiatives is substantially higher (i.e., at least 1%, 25% or 75% of customers located abroad). These results support those found at national level by Hessels and van Stel (2009). However, our paper adds to the extant literature on entrepreneurship by analyzing the role of entrepreneurial activity with different levels of export intensity on regional growth under a longitudinal context. Policy implications derived from these results suggest that trade policies for export promotion among new ventures should be carried out at regional level. Otherwise, exporting new ventures may concentrate only on certain regions, which would help to increase differences on growth within a nation.
fieldOfStudy: Business, Entrepreneurial Activity, Economic Growth, International Trade, Regional Studies
summary: This study analyzes the economic impact of export-oriented entrepreneurship on regional growth, addressing a gap in regional-level analysis despite increasing globalization. The research utilizes data from the Global Entrepreneurship Monitor project and the Spanish Institute of Statistics for 17 NUTS-2 Spanish regions over six years. Controlling for catching-up effects and other economic growth drivers, the authors found that regions with higher export-oriented entrepreneurial activity exhibit greater GDP growth, especially when the intensity of foreign customers served is high. These findings support national-level results and emphasize the role of varying export intensity on regional growth within a longitudinal context. Policy implications suggest that trade policies for export promotion should be implemented at the regional level to prevent increasing growth disparities.

title: Entrepreneurial Ventures and the Developmental State: Lessons from the Advanced Economies
abstract: A basic intellectual challenge for those concerned with the poverty of nations is to come to grips with the nature and causes of the wealth of the world?s wealthier nations. One might then be in a position to inform the poorer nations how they might achieve similar outcomes. This paper is organized around what I call ?the theory of innovative enterprise?, a perspective derived from the historical and comparative study of the development of the advanced economies. The theory of innovative enterprise provides the essential analytical link between entrepreneurship and development. Section 2 offers, as a point of departure, a contrast between entrepreneurship in rich and poor nations. Section 3 outlines the theory of the innovating firm in which entrepreneurship has a role to play. Section 4 identifies the roles of entrepreneurship in new firm formation in terms of the types of strategy, organization, and finance that innovation requires, and emphasizes the ?disappearance? of entrepreneurship with the growth of the firm. In Section 5 I argue that, in the advanced economies, successful entrepreneurship in knowledge intensive industries has depended heavily upon a combination of business allocation of resources to innovative investment strategies, and government investment in the knowledge base, state sponsored protection of markets and intellectual property rights, and state subsidies to support these business strategies. One cannot understand national economic development without understanding the role of the developmental state. At the same time, the specific agenda and ultimate success of the developmental state cannot be understood in abstraction from the dynamics of innovative enterprise. It is through the interaction of the innovative enterprise and the developmental state that entrepreneurial activity inserts itself into the economic system to contribute to the process of economic development.entrepreneurship, innovative enterprise, developmental state
summary: This paper introduces the "theory of innovative enterprise," derived from historical and comparative studies of advanced economies, to link entrepreneurship and development. It contrasts entrepreneurship in rich versus poor nations, outlines the theory of the innovating firm, and identifies entrepreneurial roles in new firm formation concerning strategy, organization, and finance. The author argues that in advanced economies, successful entrepreneurship in knowledge-intensive industries depends on business investment, government investment in knowledge, market protection, intellectual property rights, and state subsidies. The study emphasizes the critical interaction between innovative enterprise and the developmental state for economic development. Keywords: entrepreneurship, innovative enterprise, developmental state, economic development.

title: Enterprise and employability: to conflate or not to conflate?
abstract: Back in 1992, Watts and Hawthorn provided definitions of ‘enterprise’ that could subsume the concept of employability. They argued that enterprise may be about: helping students set up a business; working within an enterprise (organisation); or being enterprising, innovating and creative. Their comments were made in the context of the Enterprise in Higher Education programme, which ran for eight years until 1996. This predated the nomenclature ‘employability’, but ran alongside traditional employability elements such as career development learning. More recent enterprise initiatives (for example the National Centre for Graduate Entrepreneurship) have focused more specifically on entrepreneurship, innovation and knowledge transfer, not on employability
summary: This paper examines the historical development and evolving definitions of 'enterprise' and 'employability' in higher education, tracing concepts from 1992 through recent initiatives. It highlights how initial definitions of enterprise encompassed employability aspects like business creation, organizational work, and innovation. The discussion notes a shift where enterprise initiatives increasingly focus on entrepreneurship, innovation, and knowledge transfer, distinct from employability which has grown as a separate concept. The article also touches on public perceptions of enterprise and offers a more open definition. Key terms include enterprise, employability, entrepreneurship, higher education, career development, and innovation.

title: From nascent to actual entrepreneurship: the effect of entry barriers
abstract: This exploratory study focuses on the convention from nascent to actual entrepreneurship and the role of entry barriers in this process. Evidence is found for a strong conversion from nascent to actual entrepreneurship. Also positive effects are found on entrepreneurial activity rates of labour flexibility and tertiary enrollment and a negative effect of social expenditure.
summary: This exploratory study investigates the conversion from nascent to actual entrepreneurship, focusing on the influence of entry barriers. The research provides evidence for a strong conversion rate from nascent to actual entrepreneurship. Furthermore, the study identifies positive effects of labor flexibility and tertiary enrollment on entrepreneurial activity rates, while social expenditure is found to have a negative impact. Key findings also highlight the role of various factors in shaping entrepreneurial outcomes, offering insights for policy and economic development.

title: Do Regions with Entrepreneurial Neighbors Perform Better?: A Spatial Econometric Approach for German Regions
abstract: We use a neoclassical production function to analyze the effects of knowledge spillovers via entrepreneurship on economic performance of 337 German districts. To take the spatial dependence structure of the data into account, we estimate a spatial Durbin model. We highlight the importance of the choice of the appropriate weight matrix. We find positive knowledge spillover effects via entrepreneurship within a certain region. Between regions, entrepreneurship as a vehicle by which knowledge spills over and contributes to economic performance depends largely on the choice of the weight matrix. We see this as evidence for regionally bounded knowledge spillover effects via entrepreneurship.Entrepreneurship capital, regional output, spatial weight matrix
fieldOfStudy: Business, Entrepreneurship, Spatial Econometrics, Economic Performance
summary: This study employs a neoclassical production function and a spatial Durbin model to analyze knowledge spillovers via entrepreneurship on the economic performance of 337 German districts. The authors highlight the critical role of the spatial weight matrix choice. Findings indicate positive intra-regional knowledge spillover effects through entrepreneurship, while inter-regional effects are highly dependent on the chosen weight matrix. This suggests regionally bounded knowledge spillover effects, emphasizing entrepreneurship capital, regional output, and spatial econometric approaches for understanding economic dynamics.

title: Connecting Passion and Purpose: Q&A with Changemaker Fellow Amanda Calderon ’18
abstract: Mario J. Gabelli School of Business junior selected for fellowship program that integrates student leaders into Rhode Island’s entrepreneurship scene
summary: This news article features an interview with Amanda Calderon '18, a Mario J. Gabelli School of Business junior and marketing major, who was selected for the Changemaker Fellow program. The program integrates student leaders into Rhode Island's entrepreneurship scene. Calderon discusses her role in fostering entrepreneurship on campus and connecting students with resources and small businesses in Rhode Island. She highlights the importance of leveraging academic resources and taking risks as a student entrepreneur. The article emphasizes her passion for helping students turn their ideas into reality by connecting them with relevant professionals and opportunities.

title: Early Development of Entrepreneurial Qualities: the Role of Initial Education
abstract: This study attempts to create a better understanding of the role of entrepreneurship education in developing entrepreneurial qualities.�Theory and practice are confronted.�The�paper�discusses the extent to which entrepreneurship can be taught, and the way in which it should be taught. The focus is on the phase of initial education.
summary: This study investigates the role of entrepreneurship education in fostering entrepreneurial qualities, confronting theoretical concepts with practical application. The paper explores the teachability of entrepreneurship and optimal teaching methodologies, specifically focusing on initial education phases. Key aspects include entrepreneurial qualities, teaching entrepreneurship, initial education, and pedagogical approaches. This research aims to contribute to a deeper understanding of how educational interventions can cultivate entrepreneurial traits in early developmental stages, offering insights for curriculum design and policy.

title: The HIV Epidemic in Tanzania Mainland:Where have we come from, Where is it Going, and how are we responding?
summary: This report examines the HIV epidemic in Tanzania Mainland, analyzing its historical trajectory, current status, and the national response. It investigates HIV prevalence trends over time, highlighting heterogeneity across demographics such as gender, age groups, education levels, and wealth. The study, prepared by ASAP (a UNAIDS service), provides a comprehensive overview of the epidemic's dynamics and societal impact, aiming to inform ongoing intervention strategies and future public health planning. Key aspects include epidemiological patterns, demographic disparities, and the effectiveness of existing responses, crucial for targeted health initiatives.

title: Differentiating KMS Strategy from Business Strategy, KM Strategy and IS/IT Strategy
abstract: The era of the new millennium has witnessed a wide range of the revolutionized technology that affects our lives and the way an organization is conducted. The contemporary business sectors start to recognize the potential use of knowledge management in the new organizational processes. As a result, increasing numbers of organizations pay attention to the creative value of leveraging knowledge as one of their potential assets. Therefore, organizations start to focus on knowledge as one of the important elements in competitive advantage that needs to be utilized efficiently and effectively. They have shown a great attention of knowledge management in their business strategy incorporated with technology. The role of technological tools and applications is essential in supporting and enhancing knowledge management strategy. There has been a transition from traditional information system to new a concept of knowledge management system employed by organization to sustain competitive advantage in dynamic and unstable environment. Further, to shift the paradigm of knowledge management systems concept from business sectors, this study focused on the KMS applications and tools particularly in Institutions of Higher Education (IHE) environment. The purpose of this study is to (a) identify the relationship of business strategy, knowledge management (KM) Strategy, knowledge management systems (KMS) strategy, information system (IS) strategy and information technology (IT) strategy, particularly in the context of IHE,  (b) describe those strategies and their relationship based on the context of IHE. This will provide guidance and effective methods for formulating the KMS strategy with the aim to align it with business strategies and ensuring success of its implementation
summary: This study investigates the relationship between business strategy, knowledge management (KM) strategy, knowledge management systems (KMS) strategy, information system (IS) strategy, and information technology (IT) strategy, particularly within Institutions of Higher Education (IHE). It aims to describe these strategies and their interconnections to provide guidance for formulating and aligning KMS strategy with overarching business objectives. The research emphasizes leveraging knowledge as a competitive asset in dynamic environments, facilitated by technological tools and the transition from traditional information systems to contemporary knowledge management systems to ensure successful implementation and sustained advantage.

title: A US strategy for IFRS adoption
abstract: The US Securities and Exchange Commission has conducted a public consultation on a â??roadmap" it proposed late last year to adopt International Financial Reporting Standards in America. This debate takes particular relevance as the crisis has highlighted the importance of accounting standards as an instrument of economic policymaking, with a high-profile controversy about â??mark-to-market" accounting. Nicolas Véron responds with suggestions about how the SEC should both support IFRS, and push for reforms of standard-setting governance and globally consistent enforcement.
fieldOfStudy: Business, International Financial Reporting Standards, Accounting Standards, SEC
summary: This document outlines a response to the US Securities and Exchange Commission's (SEC) consultation on adopting International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) in America. The author, Nicolas Véron, emphasizes the economic importance of accounting standards, particularly highlighted by the 'mark-to-market' controversy. He suggests the SEC should support IFRS adoption by the end of the next decade, provided three conditions are met: clarification of the international standard-setter's mandate and governance reform, maintaining high standards without compromising US GAAP convergence, and consistent enforcement across jurisdictions. This policy contribution serves as a critical input for the debate on IFRS recognition in the U.S. and financial governance.

title: Character Education Strategy Through Integrated Islamic Religious Education in SMPN 01 Kedungbanteng Purwokerto
abstract: Artikel ini menyimpulkan bahwa nilai, sikap dan perilaku yang positif seperti jujur,amanah,optimistisdanlain-lain,sertamenjauhiperilakuyangnegatifsepertibohong,boros, dengki dan sebagainya merupakan bagian dari akhlak. Artinya,nilai-nilai tersebut juga diajarkan dalam pokok bahasan akhlak yang terdapat dalampendidikanagama.Pembelajarantanpadiikutiolehfaktorlingkunganyangmendukungtidak menjamin dapat tercapai tujuan. Faktor lingkungan sekolahbisa berwujud budaya sekolah maupun kegiatan ekstrakurikuler sekolah. Nilainilaimoral agama terintegrasi dengan mata pelajaran lain, budaya sekolah dankegiatan sekolah yang mendukung akan semakin mempengaruhi akhlak atau sikapsiswa. Dengan model integrasi dengan pelajaran lain, maka siswa akanmemperoleh pengetahuan dan keterampilan secara utuh, sehingga pembelajaranmenjadi bermakna bagi siswa. Selain integrasi dengan mata pelajaran lain, pembentukannilai-nilai di sekolah juga sangat tergantung budaya sekolah dankegiatan sekolah
publisher: Sekolah Tinggi Agama Islam Negeri Pamekasan
summary: This article concludes that positive values and behaviors (e.g., honesty, optimism) and avoiding negative ones (e.g., lying, envy) are integral to akhlak (morality) and taught in religious education. It argues that a supportive school environment, including school culture and extracurricular activities, is crucial for character development. Integrating religious moral values with other subjects, school culture, and activities significantly influences students' attitudes. This integrated approach provides students with holistic knowledge and skills, making learning meaningful. The formation of values in schools heavily depends on both curriculum integration and the school's overall culture and activities, achieving positive student responses to character education.

title: Rethinking Strategy
abstract: Business Administratio
fieldOfStudy: Business Administration, Organizational Management, Political Economy
summary: This review discusses research on new-generation cooperatives (NGCs), highlighting the need to examine the social processes and forms of authority that sustain them, especially in individualist-oriented contexts. It also summarizes a book by Jone Pearce, "Organization and Management in the Embrace of Government," which argues that governments significantly shape organizational dynamics. Pearce distinguishes between facilitative governments (supportive, predictable, strong) and nonfacilitative governments (hostile, erratic, weak), illustrating how the latter creates complex dependencies for managers, particularly in transitional economies like China and Hungary, where personal relationships and official good graces become crucial. The review emphasizes understanding organizations within their broader governmental context.

title: Strategy publication
summary: This document outlines the COGENT Strategy, a critical framework for securing international genebank funding and enhancing the participatory approach in coconut genetic resource management. It details the extensive editorial process for chapters 1, 2, and 3, involving scientific editing, validation by various stakeholders, and publication. Key objectives include strengthening communication and commitment to conservation, promoting in situ conservation of landraces, identifying and addressing gaps in ex situ collections, and developing mechanisms for safe international germplasm movements. The strategy also focuses on enhancing germplasm characterization, preparing for coconut genomics, improving germplasm databases, and reinforcing COGENT as a collaborative platform.

title: Connecting up strategy: are senior strategy directors a missing link?
abstract: With companies being exhorted to become more strategically agile and internally connected, this article examines the role of the Senior Strategy Director, the executive tasked specifically with internal strategy. In particular, it explores what they do, what specific capabilities they deploy to enable effective contribution to the company, and in what ways they facilitate the connectedness of strategy. An analysis of multiple interviews over time with Senior Strategy Directors of large companies shows the vital and challenging role these executives play in both shaping, connecting up, and executing strategy. This article identifies the particular capabilities necessary for Senior Strategy Directors to perform their role and shows how it all depends upon their skilful deployment. These findings have significant implications for understanding unfolding micro-processes of strategy in large organizations, for assumptions about the skills and capabilities necessary to be an effective Senior Strategy Director, and for business schools in terms of the content and style of strategy courses they provide
fieldOfStudy: Business, Strategy, Organizational Strategy, Strategic Management
summary: This article examines the critical role of Senior Strategy Directors (SSDs) within large companies, specifically exploring their activities, essential capabilities, and contribution to strategic connectedness. Through analyzing multiple interviews, the study reveals the challenging nature of their role in shaping, connecting, and executing strategy. It identifies the specific capabilities necessary for SSDs to be effective, emphasizing their skillful deployment. These findings offer significant insights into the micro-processes of strategy in large organizations, the required skills for effective SSDs, and implications for business schools in designing relevant strategy courses and developing future strategists.

title: Strategy and slaughter
abstract: Colin Gray's ‘Clausewitz Rules, OK’ was the one contribution to the Interregnum special issue of this Review that engaged the problem of modern war in general. Issues of war and peace were represented only patchily in a volume aiming to reflect on the ‘post-Cold War’ decade, but put together before ‘9/11’ brought it to an abrupt end. The Balkans didn't play a large part in William Wallace's account of Europe; unstable Asian great-power rivalries and local wars, which could make Rosemary Foot and Andrew Walter's ‘Pacific Century’ anything but pacific were barely noted; while Caroline Thomas wrote about the Third World without mentioning Africa's wars. The Middle East, Rwanda and genocide were not covered. Bruce Cumings' wise reflections on the military bases of American liberalism, a brief discussion of the ‘new interventionism’ by Geoffrey Hawthorn, and dutiful mentions of Kosovo across the chapters, hardly compensated for these omissions
fieldOfStudy: Business International Studies Strategic Thought Warfare Cold War Nuclear Proliferation
summary: This article, a draft version published in the Review of International Studies, critiques Colin Gray's defense of strategic thought, particularly his views on "eternal verities" in modern warfare. It examines Gray's career, including his role as a presidential advisor during the Reagan administration, and discusses how his book can be interpreted as a partial apologia for his life's work. The author challenges Gray's reliance on Cold War-era strategic concepts, arguing that while classic strategic wisdom may serve as a fallback, human society is increasingly recognizing limits to the valid use of force, shifting towards a more peaceful world order.

title: A European Exit Strategy
abstract: This Policy Brief was adapted from a paper written by the three authors and presented by Bruegel Director Jean Pisani-Ferry at the informal ECOFIN Council meetings in Gothenburg, Sweden, on 1 Oct. In the brief, the authors argue that bank recapitalisation and restructuring should be a matter of urgency for EU member states and that governments should not undertake the necessary fiscal and monetary policy exit until problems within the financial sector are addressed. The authors also recommend that European states set debt targets to be reached by the end of 2014 and explain that proper incentives are necessary to ensure that an exit strategy, once implemented, is done so in coordination between various institutional actors. Such a policy framework should be in place by summer 2010, the authors say, in order to avoid a buildup of financial instability during the process.
fieldOfStudy: Business, European Union, Banking, Monetary Policy, Fiscal Policy, Financial Stability
summary: This policy brief argues that bank recapitalization and restructuring are urgent for EU member states, recommending that governments delay fiscal and monetary policy exit until financial sector problems are resolved. The authors propose European states set debt targets for 2014 and emphasize the need for proper incentives and coordination among institutional actors for a successful exit strategy. A policy framework should be in place by summer 2010 to prevent financial instability during the process, ensuring a coordinated, credible, and sequenced exit from the current crisis mode, involving recapitalization of banks and medium-term budgetary plans.

title: CONTENT MARKETING STRATEGY
summary: This text outlines an eight-step content marketing strategy designed to boost sales by 40% and cut advertising costs by 15%. Key steps include creating a specialized blog with fresh, relevant information, developing an online library of useful resources like books and webinars, distributing regular press releases through electronic media, and actively promoting content across social networks and Twitter. The strategy emphasizes setting strategic goals, identifying target keywords for SEO, and making content accessible and engaging for a broad audience to maximize brand awareness and reach.

title: MCDONALD’S MARKETING STRATEGY
summary: This text explores McDonald's marketing strategy, examining how it became the largest global fast-food chain despite health concerns. Key methods include pioneering the quick service restaurant industry, creating a strong brand image through successful advertising and corporate symbols, and emphasizing consistent product value. The strategy targets children and focuses on human resources, customer satisfaction, and employee well-being. McDonald's "Plan to Win" aims for excellence, utilizing marketing mix elements like extended hours, value meals, and drive-thru efficiency, demonstrating strategic resilience against competitive threats and operational weaknesses. Keywords: McDonald's, marketing strategy, fast food, brand image, quick service restaurant, advertising.

title: DTEK – Development Strategy 2030
fieldOfStudy: Business, Corporate Strategy, Energy Company, DTEK, Ukraine
summary: This document outlines DTEK's long-term development strategy from 2013 to 2030, aiming to transform it into a diversified energy company expanding into neighboring markets. The strategy unfolds in three stages: "Integration. Infrastructure. Reform" (2013-2015) focusing on new management models and operational efficiency; "Efficiency" (2015-2020) emphasizing LEAN concepts and international investment; and "Innovation" (2020-2030) prioritizing new technologies, automation, and continued geographical diversification. DTEK seeks to lead Ukrainian business by promoting industrial safety and environmental protection, focusing on electricity sales and related services.

title: Women's Economic Empowerment Strategy
abstract: In this document the William and Flora Hewlett Foundation outlines its strategy and motivation for supporting a focused agenda on women's economic empowerment
summary: This document from the William and Flora Hewlett Foundation outlines its strategy for promoting women's economic empowerment, recognizing its fundamental role in social and economic development. The foundation aims to address systemic disadvantages faced by women globally, including limited access to credit, exclusion from profitable sectors, and unrecognized labor. The strategy emphasizes supporting advocacy efforts at international and national levels, strengthening partners focused on gender, and integrating gender concerns into broader economic policies through robust data and research. This initiative seeks to empower women, improve family well-being, and foster stable, sustainable societies by enhancing economic equality.

title: An alternative regional strategy
abstract: Regions, this extract suggests, cannot bring about regional inequality without significant national level action. The key, it is claimed, is a ‘national commitment to decentre the economy’. As well as re-examining some current regional policy – such as whether knowledge transfer needs to happen locally or how foreign investment might be better harnessed – this manifesto argues that national policy needs to be made far more sensitive to the regional agenda
summary: This extract proposes that regions alone cannot generate regional inequality without substantial national intervention, emphasizing the necessity of a 'national commitment to decentre the economy'. It critiques current regional policies, such as the localization of knowledge transfer and the harnessing of foreign investment, advocating for national policies to become more attuned to regional agendas. The authors recommend a strategy that integrates national policy with regional development, highlighting the importance of high-quality data and intelligence for effective regional policy-making and promoting collaboration among regional organizations and agencies.

title: Degree Sequence Index Strategy
abstract:
We introduce a procedure, called the Degree Sequence Index Strategy (DSI), by
which to bound graph invariants by certain indices in the ordered degree
sequence. As an illustration of the DSI strategy, we show how it can be used to
give new upper and lower bounds on the $k$-independence and the $k$-domination
numbers. These include, among other things, a double generalization of the
annihilation number, a recently introduced upper bound on the independence
number. Next, we use the DSI strategy in conjunction with planarity, to
generalize some results of Caro and Roddity about independence number in planar
graphs. Lastly, for claw-free and $K_{1,r}$-free graphs, we use DSI to
generalize some results of Faudree, Gould, Jacobson, Lesniak and Lindquester
fieldOfStudy: Business, graph theory, mathematics, computer science
summary: This paper introduces the Degree Sequence Index Strategy (DSI), a novel procedure for bounding graph invariants using indices within the ordered degree sequence. The DSI strategy is demonstrated to provide new upper and lower bounds for k-independence and k-domination numbers, including a double generalization of the annihilation number. Furthermore, the DSI strategy is applied with planarity to generalize results on independence numbers in planar graphs and for claw-free and K1,r-free graphs, extending previous work by various researchers. Keywords include graph invariants, degree sequence, k-independence, k-domination, planar graphs.

title: DEVELOPMENT STRATEGY: CO-BRANDING
summary: This text explores co-branding, a marketing strategy where two or more companies form an alliance to create synergy and strengthen brand preference or purchase intention. It defines co-branding as associating a single product or service with multiple brand names, often involving shared logos or identifiers. The objective is to combine brand strengths, potentially increasing consumer willingness to pay. The document outlines various forms of co-branding, including strategic alliances for product presentation and multiple sponsor collaborations. It also details the advantages, such as risk-sharing, increased sales, customer trust, and technological benefits, alongside potential disadvantages like market mismatches or damage to brand equity.

title: From Strategy to Practice
abstract:
{Excerpt} Strategic reversals are quite commonly failures of execution. In many cases, a strategy is abandoned out of impatience or because of pressure for an instant payoff before it has had a chance to take root and yield results. Or its focal point is allowed to drift overtime. To navigate a strategy, one must maintain a balance between strategizing and learning modes of thinking.
Despite worldwide attention to strategic planning, the notion of strategic practice is surprisingly new. This owes to widespread perception that strategic reversals owe to strategic miscalculations—the strategy was not sufficiently perceptive, imaginative, or visionary. Alternatively, it was too much of a good thing. But the truth is that strategic reversals are quite commonly failures of execution. In many cases, a strategy is abandoned out of impatience or because of pressure for an instant payoff before it has had a chance to take root and yield results. Or, its focal point is allowed to drift over time.
To draw a strategy is relatively easy but to execute it is difficult. Strategy is both a macro and a micro phenomenon that depends on synchronization. For that reason, it is worthwhile to examine a few elements of a disciplined process for systematically reviewing, evaluating, prioritizing, sequencing, managing, redirecting, and, if necessary,even canceling strategic initiatives
summary: This document explores the critical transition from strategic planning to effective strategic practice, arguing that many strategic reversals are due to failures of execution rather than flawed initial strategy. It highlights the importance of balancing strategizing and learning, and suggests that strategies are often abandoned prematurely or allowed to drift. The paper advocates for a disciplined process to systematically review, evaluate, and manage strategic initiatives to ensure their success, emphasizing the need for synchronization between macro and micro phenomena in strategy implementation. Keywords: strategic practice, strategy execution, strategic reversals, strategic management, organizational learning.

title: The Justices of Strategy
summary: This book review, "The Justices of Strategy" by Frank B. Cross, examines Lee Epstein and Jack Knight's work "The Choices Justices Make." The review challenges the traditional view of judges as "naif, simple-minded men," arguing instead that Supreme Court Justices are sophisticated and strategic. They are depicted as maximizing personal public policy preferences while maintaining the Court's perceived legitimacy within legal boundaries. The review highlights the overlooked concept of judicial strategy in legal scholarship, contrasting it with the common understanding of litigator strategizing. It concludes by suggesting increased transparency for the Court, perhaps through public press conferences, to enhance discipline in legal decision-making, despite potential reductions in the Court's functional role and public respect.

title: China's geoeconomic strategy: China’s strategy towards the financial crisis and economic reform
abstract: China’s pragmatic attitude towards its own 30 years of reform can be used to similarly characterise its attitude toward the global fi nancial crisis of 2008 and the resultant push for further economic reforms. China was able to manage the downturn following 2008, and has a good chance of managing the consequences of Europe’s slowdown by undertaking fiscal and monetary stimulus. The debate over global imbalances has increased the need for nations to re-balance their economies, including China. The Chinese economy requires rebalancing to sustain strong growth rates in the coming decades, with the slowdown in the West making the re-orientation towards growth by domestic demand an even greater imperative
publisher: LSE IDEAS, The London School of Economics and Political Science
fieldOfStudy: Business, Geoeconomic Strategy, Economic Reform, Financial Crisis
summary: This report characterizes China's pragmatic approach to its economic reforms and its response to the 2008 global financial crisis. It argues that China successfully navigated the post-2008 downturn and can manage Europe's slowdown through fiscal and monetary stimulus. The paper highlights the imperative for China to rebalance its economy towards domestic demand to sustain growth, particularly given Western slowdowns. Key recommendations include reforming exchange and interest rates to boost consumption, managing trade surpluses, and carefully regulating capital flows to achieve a stable and prosperous economy and contribute to global economic rebalancing, moving away from export-led growth.

title: Implementing a learning technology strategy: top-down strategy meets bottom-up culture
abstract: Using interview-based 'insider case study' research, this paper outlines why the University of Salford has adopted a Learning Technologies Strategy and examines the factors which are likely to lead to its successful implementation. External reasons for the adoption focused on the need to: respond to 'increased Higher Education (HE) competition', meet student expectations of learning technology use, provide more flexibility and access to the curriculum, address the possible determining effect of technology and establish a Virtual Learning Environment (VLE) presence in this 'particular area of the HE landscape'. Internal drivers centred on the need to: continue a 'bottom-up' e-learning pilot project initiative, particularly given that a VLE is a 'complex tool' which requires effective strategic implementation, and promote the idea that learning technology will play an important role in determining the type of HE institution that the University of Salford wishes to become. Likely success factors highlighted the need to: create 'time and space' for innovation, maintain effective communication and consultation at all levels of the organization, emphasize the operational aspects of the strategy, establish a variety of staff development processes and recognize the negotiatory processes involved in understanding the term 'web presence' in local teaching cultures. Fundamentally, the paper argues that policy makers should acknowledge the correct 'cultural configuration' of HE institutions when seeking to manage and achieve organizational change. Thus, it is not just a question of establishing 'success factors' per se but also whether they are contextualized appropriately within a 'correct' characterization of the organizational culture
fieldOfStudy: Business, Higher Education Strategy, Learning Technologies
summary: This paper uses interview-based 'insider case study' research to explore the University of Salford's adoption and implementation of a Learning Technologies Strategy. It outlines external drivers like increased HE competition, student expectations, and the need for a Virtual Learning Environment (VLE) presence, alongside internal drivers such as continuing e-learning pilot projects and promoting learning technology's role in institutional identity. Key success factors include creating time for innovation, effective communication, operational emphasis, staff development, and understanding local teaching cultures. The paper fundamentally argues that successful organizational change requires acknowledging the correct 'cultural configuration' of higher education institutions.

title: Creating strategy by design
summary: This article, "Creating strategy by design" by James R. Carlopio, explores the intersection of design principles and strategic formulation. The author discusses how adopting a design-centric approach can enhance the process of strategy creation, emphasizing elements like iteration, user-centeredness, and holistic thinking. It suggests that viewing strategy as a dynamic design challenge, rather than a rigid planning exercise, can lead to more adaptable and innovative organizational outcomes. Key insights include the integration of design thinking methodologies into strategic management frameworks to foster competitive advantage and organizational agility.

title: MOBILE MARKETING STRATEGY: BRANDED GAMES
fieldOfStudy: Business, Marketing Strategy, Mobile Marketing, Branded Games
summary: This research investigates mobile marketing strategies, specifically focusing on branded games, in response to the growing need for emotional consumer engagement in a technologically advanced market. It explores the physiological impact of games, the rise of mobile gaming on smartphones (with 15 million in Ukraine and growing), and the two main approaches to developing branded games: creating new ones or branding existing ones. The study highlights the importance of game quality for popularity and predicts a significant future for mobile gaming as a "blue ocean" opportunity for brand promotion given the increasing user base of smartphones and tablets.

title: Donor Advisors and Philanthropic Strategy
abstract: Based on a literature review and interviews, explores how donor advisors shape the philanthropic strategies of the wealthy. Looks at the key activities and elements of effective advising, the need for training, and the potential for collaboration
summary: This study explores how donor advisors influence the philanthropic strategies of wealthy individuals, focusing on their activities, effective advising elements, training needs, and collaboration potential. Through interviews with 75 professionals including accountants, wealth managers, and philanthropic advisors, and a comprehensive literature review, the research adopts a psychological perspective. It highlights that shaping philanthropic strategy requires addressing deeply-held personal values, identifying meaningful causes, and managing complex family dynamics. The study aims to provide insights into how advisors prepare for and execute this crucial work, ultimately supporting donors in making impactful decisions for the public good.

title: MARKETING STRATEGY - "HANDBOOK IN INSTALLMENT"
summary: This article discusses the evolving landscape of marketing strategy, moving from mass marketing to targeted information and customer-centric approaches. It highlights the shift from traditional, intact products to individualized, information-rich offerings and the end of consumer indifference. The authors propose a "handbook in installment" strategy for textbook printing, where content is delivered in parts over time for prepaid orders. This approach aims to provide publishers with guaranteed income and insights into consumer needs, while universities receive timely training materials. The strategy aligns with relational marketing, offering stable income for publishers and cost savings for customers by allowing them to pay only for needed information parts, reducing production costs.

title: The integration approach: Integrating technology strategy with business strategy in the airline industry
abstract:
Technology has emerged as a key component in solving complex strategic issues. Much of the relevant literature recognises technology as the driving force behind the fast rate of change in many markets. Consequently, organisations are becoming increasingly dependent on advanced technology to improve their performance. At the same time organisations need to be extremely flexible in order to meet the demands of customers quickly, accurately and cost-effectively. To benefit from the potential of technology in highly dynamic environments, there is a need to integrate technology strategy with business strategy. This research explores the integration between technology strategy and business strategy in the airline industry.
The literature on technology, technology strategy, corporate strategy, business strategy, competitive advantage and the integration of technology strategy with business strategy is critically evaluated and shortcomings of the literature are identified. The literature review was evaluated and identifies gaps and possible future directions. This indicated a need for a systematic way of linking technology and business strategies. Thus an Integration Model is proposed consisting of three stages involving business strategy, competitive strategy and technology strategy. The literature review and the Integration Model identified the importance of technology assessment in formulating a technology strategy and the need for a supportive tool to aid this process
fieldOfStudy: Business, Technology Strategy, Corporate Strategy, Competitive Advantage
summary: This research explores the critical integration of technology strategy with business strategy, particularly within the airline industry, recognizing technology's role in market dynamism and organizational performance. The study critiques existing literature on technology, corporate, and competitive strategies to identify gaps. It proposes an "Integration Model" comprising three stages: business strategy, competitive strategy, and technology strategy. The findings emphasize the importance of technology assessment for formulating effective technology strategies and the need for supportive tools to facilitate this integration process, aiming to enhance organizational flexibility and responsiveness in dynamic environments.

title: Towards an Updatable Strategy Logic
abstract:
This article is about temporal multi-agent logics. Several of these
formalisms have been already presented (ATL-ATL*, ATLsc, SL). They enable to
express the capacities of agents in a system to ensure the satisfaction of
temporal properties. Particularly, SL and ATLsc enable several agents to
interact in a context mixing the different strategies they play in a semantical
game. We generalize this possibility by proposing a new formalism, Updating
Strategy Logic (USL). In USL, an agent can also refine its own strategy. The
gain in expressive power rises the notion of "sustainable capacities" for
agents.
  USL is built from SL. It mainly brings to SL the two following modifications:
semantically, the successor of a given state is not uniquely determined by the
data of one choice from each agent. Syntactically, we introduce in the language
an operator, called an "unbinder", which explicitely deletes the binding of a
strategy to an agent. We show that USL is strictly more expressive than SL.Comment: In Proceedings SR 2013, arXiv:1303.007
summary: This article introduces Updating Strategy Logic (USL), a new formalism generalizing existing temporal multi-agent logics like ATL-ATL* and SL. USL enables agents to refine their strategies within a semantic game context, enhancing expressive power to describe "sustainable capacities." Built upon Strategy Logic (SL), USL modifies its semantics so that successor states are not solely determined by agents' choices, and introduces an "unbinder" operator to explicitly delete strategy-agent bindings. The authors demonstrate that USL is strictly more expressive than SL, advancing the field of multi-agent systems and temporal properties.

title: Strategy Workshops and Strategic Change
abstract: Despite the attention that strategic change as a topic of research has received, there remain considerable difficulties in conceptualizing the actual sources of strategic change. Strategy workshops represent one obvious and explicit research site since organizations often use such events as a means of effecting or initiating strategic change. This paper examines empirical data from ninety-nine strategy workshops in ten separate organizations to address the research question: Do strategy workshops produce strategic change? The paper concludes that workshops can produce change but that one-off workshops are much less effective than a series of workshops. The data presented indicates that the elapsed duration of the entire series of workshops, the frequency of workshops, the scope and autonomy of the unit concerned, and the seniority of participants have an impact on the success or failure of the venture
summary: This paper investigates whether strategy workshops can produce strategic change, addressing a gap in understanding the sources of such change. Using empirical data from 99 workshops across ten organizations, the study found that workshops can indeed effect change, but sequential workshops are significantly more effective than one-off events. Key factors influencing success include the elapsed duration and frequency of workshops, the scope and autonomy of the involved unit, and the seniority of participants. This research contributes to the conceptualization of strategic change by highlighting the mechanisms through which workshops can drive organizational transformation.

title: The Need and Requirements to a Strategy Ontology
abstract:
The importance of strategy and strategy construct is not a new

phenomenon. However as strategy work becomes less tangible, concerns with

understanding, describing, and managing strategies develops into an increasingly

complex subject. Current strategy concepts are dispersed and lack integration.

Moreover, the enablement of modelling practices around strategy concepts

considering the entire strategy lifecycle are also missing. Consequently, this

paper focuses on issues with strategy in theory and practice, why a strategy

ontology is needed and how this can be developed
summary: This paper addresses the growing complexity of strategy work, noting the dispersed and unintegrated nature of current strategy concepts and the absence of modelling practices across the strategy lifecycle. The authors emphasize the need for a strategy ontology to enhance understanding, description, and management of strategies. The study explores theoretical and practical issues, advocating for the development of a comprehensive strategy ontology to integrate disparate concepts and facilitate more effective strategic planning and management.

title: FE college capital investment strategy
publisher: Department for Business Innovation and Skills
summary: This document outlines the Further Education (FE) College Capital Investment Strategy, published in December 2012, aiming to support strong, sustainable growth in the UK by fostering a skilled workforce. It details the strategic approach to capital investment in FE colleges, emphasizing their role in meeting employer needs and driving economic development. The strategy addresses the FE estate challenge, outlines delivery plans, and includes case studies illustrating successful projects like the Wandsworth campus redevelopment. Key themes include skills reform, responsiveness to local employer demands, and the impact of modern facilities on learning outcomes and operational efficiency.

title: All Wales youth offending strategy
publisher: Wales. Department for Education, Lifelong Learning and Skills
summary: This document outlines the All Wales Youth Offending Strategy, emphasizing prevention as the most effective approach to reduce youth crime. It advocates for minimizing young people's entry into the criminal justice system and stresses that custody should always be a last resort due to its negative long-term impacts. The strategy details how Wales plans to break the cycle of re-offending by providing effective community-based interventions. It also highlights a universal entitlement for young people aged 11-25 in Wales, covering education, basic skills, volunteering, careers advice, personal support, and recreational opportunities, all designed to promote social inclusion and independent living.

title: The assessment for learning strategy
publisher: Department for Children, Schools and Families
summary:
This strategy outlines the UK government's 

£150 million investment over three years to embed Assessment for Learning (AfL) in all classrooms, aiming to enhance pupil learning and progression. The initiative emphasizes personalized teaching, ensuring students and teachers understand learning progress, next steps, and effective methods. It details how schools can leverage available resources, including professional development for teachers and tools from the Chartered Institute of Educational Assessors (CIEA), to improve assessment practices and achieve a world-class education system.

title: A Learning and Skills Strategy
abstract:
"The Learning and Skills Strategy sets out a vision for a learning region and offers a framework for

achieving that vision. It is entirely encompassed within the Regional Strategy (as the Investing in People

section). The strategy is based on a formal Labour Market assessment and the extensive consultation

exercise undertaken by the NWDA; it has been further informed by a standing group (the Skills and

Learning Forum) representing key players in education and training and a group of employers and their

representatives. Throughout the strategy the phrase ‘learning and skills’ embraces all elements of

education and learning appropriate to social and economic fulfillment.
fieldOfStudy: Business, Labour Market, Regional Strategy, Education, Training, Workforce Development, Skills Policy
summary: The Learning and Skills Strategy, entirely integrated within the Regional Strategy's "Investing in People" section, outlines a vision and framework for a learning region. Developed through a formal Labour Market assessment, extensive NWDA consultations, and input from the Skills and Learning Forum (education, training, employers), it addresses challenges in skill demand and supply. The strategy aims to foster a more highly skilled workforce, emphasizing that "learning and skills" encompasses all elements of education for social and economic fulfillment. It highlights the need for businesses to adopt high added-value strategies rather than solely competing on cost.

title: Child poverty strategy for Wales
publisher: Department for Children, Education, Lifelong Learning and Skills (DCELLS) (Wales)
summary: This document outlines the Welsh Assembly Government's Child Poverty Strategy for Wales, detailing its commitment to reducing poverty over the next three years (2011	14). It focuses on improving health, education, and economic outcomes for children in low-income families. Key aims include increasing family income, reducing material deprivation, promoting parental employment, enhancing educational attainment, improving health equality, and ensuring access to decent housing and safe communities for children. This strategy represents a comprehensive approach to tackling long-term and intergenerational effects of child poverty through various interventions and partnerships.

title: Communication strategy tool user guide
abstract: The application of Cradle to Cradle (C2C) principles in business sites is likely to be hampered by several barriers, some of which are socio-cultural in nature. To promote change and new thinking in the way business sites are designed, built and operated, there is the need to properly understand socio-cultural issues that create ‘lock-in’ to existing practices (Peterson and Anderson, 2009) so that these can be taken into account in the way C2C is presented to different business site stakeholders to secure their commitment to C2C inspired projects. These socio-cultural barriers are deeply rooted in the basic assumptions and value priorities of stakeholders. Strategies for communicating and promoting the C2C vision must therefore be aligned with such stakeholder value priorities and assumptions
fieldOfStudy: Business Communication Strategy, Stakeholder Engagement, Cradle to Cradle
summary: This document outlines socio-cultural barriers to applying Cradle to Cradle (C2C) principles in business sites, emphasizing the need to understand stakeholder values to secure commitment for C2C-inspired projects. It introduces a C2C Communication Strategy Tool designed to diagnose stakeholder value priorities and map relevant C2C value propositions. The goal is to align communication strategies with stakeholder assumptions, ensuring messages resonate effectively. While the tool aids message framing, it notes that other factors like financing and governance structures are crucial for successful C2C implementation. Keywords: Cradle to Cradle, C2C, business sites, socio-cultural barriers, communication strategy, stakeholder engagement, value propositions.

title: MARKETING STRATEGY - "HANDBOOK IN INSTALLMENT"
summary: This text explores a new marketing strategy, termed "handbook in installment," for the publishing industry, particularly in the context of Ukrainian higher education transitioning to the Bologna system. It proposes a shift from mass marketing to targeted segmentation and consumer-led dialogue, drawing on concepts from Olvin Tofle and Frederick Raykhheld. The strategy involves delivering textbooks in parts (e.g., sections, modules) over time, paid for incrementally. This approach aims to provide publishers with guaranteed income and real-time insights into consumer needs, while offering students cost savings and relevant educational materials. It emphasizes relational marketing and requires detailed segment investigation and analysis of publisher capacities.

title: Strategy Logic with Imperfect Information
abstract:
We introduce an extension of Strategy Logic for the imperfect-information
setting, called SLii, and study its model-checking problem. As this logic
naturally captures multi-player games with imperfect information, the problem
turns out to be undecidable. We introduce a syntactical class of "hierarchical
instances" for which, intuitively, as one goes down the syntactic tree of the
formula, strategy quantifications are concerned with finer observations of the
model. We prove that model-checking SLii restricted to hierarchical instances
is decidable. This result, because it allows for complex patterns of
existential and universal quantification on strategies, greatly generalises
previous ones, such as decidability of multi-player games with imperfect
information and hierarchical observations, and decidability of distributed
synthesis for hierarchical systems. To establish the decidability result, we
introduce and study QCTL*ii, an extension of QCTL* (itself an extension of CTL*
with second-order quantification over atomic propositions) by parameterising
its quantifiers with observations. The simple syntax of QCTL* ii allows us to
provide a conceptually neat reduction of SLii to QCTL*ii that separates
concerns, allowing one to forget about strategies and players and focus solely
on second-order quantification. While the model-checking problem of QCTL*ii is,
in general, undecidable, we identify a syntactic fragment of hierarchical
formulas and prove, using an automata-theoretic approach, that it is decidable.
The decidability result for SLii follows since the reduction maps hierarchical
instances of SLii to hierarchical formulas of QCTL*ii
summary: This paper introduces SLii, an extension of Strategy Logic for imperfect-information settings, and investigates its model-checking problem. Initially undecidable, the authors identify a syntactical class called "hierarchical instances," proving decidability for SLii when restricted to these instances. This significantly generalizes previous results concerning multi-player games with imperfect information and hierarchical observations, and distributed synthesis for hierarchical systems. The work also introduces and studies QCTL*ii, an extension of QCTL*, demonstrating a reduction from SLii to QCTL*ii and establishing decidability for hierarchical formulas within QCTL*ii using an automata-theoretic approach. This research contributes to formal methods for multi-player games.

title: Child poverty strategy for Scotland
summary: This document outlines the Scottish Government's 2011 Child Poverty Strategy, aiming to eliminate the disadvantage children face due to poverty. It details a multi-faceted approach focusing on maximizing household resources, improving children's life chances, leveraging the role of communities, and driving change through partnerships with local stakeholders. The strategy also includes plans for monitoring and reviewing progress annually and refreshing the strategy every three years, utilizing national indicators and local data improvement initiatives.
