This addresses issues of income poverty, material deprivation, and interconnected social problems.

title: Managing strategy through business process
abstract: The work presented in this paper, following an in depth review of literature, developed a set of requirements for a Dynamic Strategy Management Process. Having evaluated the existing strategy management frameworks, models, methodologies, tools and techniques, the research concluded that although all approaches reviewed collectively met all the requirements, individually none of the approaches fulfilled all of these requirements. To fulfil these dynamic strategy management process requirements, PROPHESY (Process Oriented Performance Headed Strategy) was developed. The paper describes in some detail, the evaluation of the PROPHESY process and demonstrates its application through a case study. The paper concludes that strategy should focus on creating value that is independent for each business unit. This means developing horizontal strategies that have objectives of co-ordinating business processes and developing objectives that encourage the sharing of resources and skills
summary: This paper presents the development of PROPHESY (Process Oriented Performance Headed Strategy), a dynamic strategy management process. The research conducted an extensive literature review and evaluated existing strategy management frameworks, models, methodologies, tools, and techniques. It was found that while all reviewed approaches collectively met a set of defined requirements, none individually fulfilled them. PROPHESY was thus developed to address these gaps. The paper details the evaluation of PROPHESY and demonstrates its practical application through a case study. The findings emphasize that strategy should prioritize creating independent value for each business unit, advocating for horizontal strategies focused on coordinating business processes and encouraging resource and skill sharing.

title: BlogForever: D3.1 Preservation Strategy Report
abstract: This report describes preservation planning approaches and strategies recommended by the BlogForever project as a core component of a weblog repository design. More specifically, we start by discussing why we would want to preserve weblogs in the first place and what it is exactly that we are trying to preserve. We further present a review of past and present work and highlight why current practices in web archiving do not address the needs of weblog preservation adequately. We make three distinctive contributions in this volume: a) we propose transferable practical workflows for applying a combination of established metadata and repository standards in developing a weblog repository, b) we provide an automated approach to identifying significant properties of weblog content that uses the notion of communities and how this affects previous strategies, c) we propose a sustainability plan that draws upon community knowledge through innovative repository design
summary: This report details preservation strategies from the BlogForever project for weblog repositories, addressing limitations of current web archiving practices. It discusses the rationale and scope of weblog preservation, proposing practical workflows using established metadata and repository standards. The report also introduces an automated method for identifying significant weblog content properties based on community notions, and outlines a sustainability plan leveraging community knowledge through innovative repository design. This work contributes to digital preservation, web archiving, and information science by offering structured approaches for long-term weblog accessibility.

title: Business strategy and earnings quality
abstract: ABSTRACT: Using the Miles and Snow (1978) strategy typology, this study investigates whether business strategy is associated with the quality of reported earnings. In a sample of U.S. listed firms, we predict and find that defender strategy firms are associated with higher levels of earnings management and prospector-strategy firms are associated with higher levels of accounting conservatism. However, this relation between business strategy and earnings quality is altered during high and low economic growth periods. In high-growth periods, while prospector firms exhibit lesser accounting conservatism, defender firms exhibit lesser earning management. In low-growth periods, the prospector firms become more conservative in reporting while the defender firms engage in more aggressive earnings management. Our findings provide direct evidence of the link between business strategy and earnings quality
summary: This study investigates the association between business strategy, specifically using the Miles and Snow (1978) typology, and the quality of reported earnings in U.S. listed firms. The research finds that defender strategy firms are linked with higher earnings management, while prospector-strategy firms show greater accounting conservatism. This relationship is notably influenced by economic growth periods: in high-growth, prospectors are less conservative and defenders manage less, but in low-growth, prospectors become more conservative and defenders engage in more aggressive earnings management. The findings provide direct evidence linking business strategy with earnings quality.

title: Japanese manufacturing: strategy and practice
abstract: A striking characteristic of Japanese factories is the extent of process control: from both the technical and the social viewpoint the labour and production system is controlled down to the very last detail. The characteristics of management and organization which underlie this are closely interwoven with Japanese culture. This explains why the work content, working conditions and working relationships in the factories look so different from those in western cultures. The paper shows why factories in the West cannot and should not copy Japanese factories
summary: This paper examines the extensive process control characteristic of Japanese factories, highlighting its technical and social dimensions, and its deep connection with Japanese culture. The authors argue that these cultural linkages fundamentally differentiate Japanese labor and production systems from Western counterparts, influencing work content, conditions, and relationships. Through observations in the consumer electronics assembly industry, the study concludes that Western factories should not attempt to directly copy Japanese models due to inherent differences in economic and social systems. Key themes include Japanese manufacturing, process control, organizational culture, and cross-cultural management.

title: Quality improvement strategy 2003/06
summary: This document outlines the Learning and Skills Council's Quality Improvement Strategy for 2003-2006, aiming to reform and enhance further education and training in the UK. Building on the government's "Success for All" initiative and backed by significant investment, the strategy focuses on raising standards, eliminating weaknesses, and increasing participation. Key methods involve collaborative partnerships with providers to improve planning and funding. The strategy details actions and targets to secure excellence for all learners by 2006, including establishing Learning and Skills Beacons, meeting national improvement targets, and ensuring teacher qualifications.

title: The Full Strategy Minority Game
abstract:
The Full Strategy Minority Game (FSMG) is an instance of the Minority Game
(MG) which includes a single copy of every potential agent. In this work, we
explicitly solve the FSMG thanks to certain symmetries of this game.
Furthermore, by considering the MG as a statistical sample of the FSMG, we
compute approximated values of the key variable {\sigma}2/N in the symmetric
phase for different versions of the MG. As another application we prove that
our results can be easily modified in order to handle certain kind of initial
biased strategies scores, in particular when the bias is introduced at the
agents' level. We also show that the FSMG verifies a strict period two dynamics
(i.e., period two dynamics satisfied with probability 1) giving, to the best of
our knowledge, the first example of an instance of the MG for which this
feature can be analytically proved. Thanks to this property, it is possible to
compute in a simple way the probability that a general instance of the MG
breaks the period two dynamics for the first time in a given simulation.Comment: To appear in Physica
summary: This work explicitly solves the Full Strategy Minority Game (FSMG), an instance of the Minority Game (MG) with every potential agent. Leveraging game symmetries, the authors compute approximated values of the key variable "sigma^2/N" in the symmetric phase for various MG versions. The results can be modified to handle initial biased strategies, particularly at the agent level. The FSMG is shown to exhibit strict period two dynamics, providing the first analytical proof for this feature in an MG instance. This property simplifies computing the probability of a general MG instance breaking period two dynamics.

title: Care leaver strategy : a cross-departmental strategy for young people leaving care, October 2013
fieldOfStudy: Business, Youth Care, Social Policy, Welfare Reform
summary: This document outlines a cross-departmental strategy for young people leaving care, published in October 2013. It details a comprehensive vision covering critical areas such as education, employment, financial assistance, health, housing, and engagement with the justice system. The strategy aims to provide ongoing support and explores tailored approaches and innovative methods to meet the needs of care leavers effectively. Key questions are posed regarding frontline services, welfare reform considerations, and barriers to new support initiatives. Feedback from care leavers is encouraged to inform future policy and monitor progress.

title: Strategy Derivation for Small Progress Measures
abstract:
Small Progress Measures is one of the most efficient parity game solving
algorithms. The original algorithm provides the full solution (winning regions
and strategies) in $O(dm \cdot (n/\lceil d / 2 \rceil)^{\lceil d/2 \rceil})$
time, and requires a re-run of the algorithm on one of the winning regions. We
provide a novel operational interpretation of progress measures, and modify the
algorithm so that it derives the winning strategies for both players in one
pass. This reduces the upper bound on strategy derivation for SPM to $O(dm
\cdot (n/\lfloor d / 2 \rfloor)^{\lfloor d/2 \rfloor})$.Comment: polished the tex
fieldOfStudy: Business, Strategy, Game Theory, Algorithm Optimization
summary: This paper introduces a novel operational interpretation of progress measures to modify the Small Progress Measures (SPM) algorithm, a highly efficient method for solving parity games. The original SPM algorithm provided winning regions and strategies but required a re-run for complete solutions. The improved algorithm derives winning strategies for both players in a single pass, significantly reducing the upper bound on strategy derivation time to O(dm 	 (n/⌊d/2⌋)⌊d/2⌋). This advancement simplifies the application of SPM, offering a more streamlined approach to analyzing infinite duration games on directed graphs.

title: Channel strategy adaptation
abstract: Using transaction cost theory, considerable research in marketing has focused on the conditions under which firms would use direct or vertically integrated versus indirect or arms length channels of distribution. Data from the field, however, indicate that channel configurations are more varied and complex, with multiple channels and composite channels being just as common as direct and indirect channels. In an attempt to explain this variety, this paper revisits the influence on channel structure of another contending variable, namely environmental complexity. We explore the role and influence of its two components, namely volatility (stability) and heterogeneity (homogeneity). Our study of 139 firms in the healthcare industry reveals that firms facing highly volatile and customer concentrated environments tend to use direct channels, and firms facing highly stable and heterogeneous environments tend to use distribution channels. Intermediate forms such as composite channels and multiple channels were favored by firms facing combinations of the environment where the intensity of one component was high and the other low. In general, firms seem to first choose a business strategy to address their external environment, and then choose a channel strategy to support that business strategy. Firms did not always adapt by making structural changes. Under certain conditions, they simply reallocated channel functions within the same structure, thus virtually deriving all the benefits of a new structure without having to create one.marketing; channels of distribution;
summary: This paper investigates channel strategy adaptation, moving beyond transaction cost theory to examine the influence of environmental complexity on distribution channel structures. The study, involving 139 firms in the healthcare industry, explores how environmental volatility and heterogeneity impact channel choices. Findings indicate that volatile, customer-concentrated environments favor direct channels, while stable, heterogeneous environments prefer indirect channels. Intermediate forms, such as composite and multiple channels, are chosen in mixed environmental conditions. The research suggests firms prioritize business strategy to address their external environment before selecting a supportive channel strategy, sometimes reallocating functions within existing structures rather than making structural changes. Key areas include marketing and channels of distribution.

title: Children's workforce strategy : a strategy to build a world-class workforce for children and young people
summary: This document outlines a strategy to build a world-class workforce for children and young people, emphasizing the importance of dedicated individuals in delivering services and achieving improved outcomes. It details plans for national and local action, addresses challenges in early years, social care, foster care, schools, health, and the voluntary sector. The strategy proposes creating and supporting a skilled workforce, including a qualifications framework, to enhance professional roles and strategic leadership within children's and youth services. Key areas covered include workforce development, integrated services, and professional qualifications for various roles.

title: From winning strategy to Nash equilibrium
abstract:
Game theory is usually considered applied mathematics, but a few
game-theoretic results, such as Borel determinacy, were developed by
mathematicians for mathematics in a broad sense. These results usually state
determinacy, i.e. the existence of a winning strategy in games that involve two
players and two outcomes saying who wins. In a multi-outcome setting, the
notion of winning strategy is irrelevant yet usually replaced faithfully with
the notion of (pure) Nash equilibrium. This article shows that every
determinacy result over an arbitrary game structure, e.g. a tree, is
transferable into existence of multi-outcome (pure) Nash equilibrium over the
same game structure. The equilibrium-transfer theorem requires cardinal or
order-theoretic conditions on the strategy sets and the preferences,
respectively, whereas counter-examples show that every requirement is relevant,
albeit possibly improvable. When the outcomes are finitely many, the proof
provides an algorithm computing a Nash equilibrium without significant
complexity loss compared to the two-outcome case. As examples of application,
this article generalises Borel determinacy, positional determinacy of parity
games, and finite-memory determinacy of Muller games
fieldOfStudy: Business, Game Theory, Nash Equilibrium, Determinacy, Borel
summary: This article explores the transferability of determinacy results in game theory from two-outcome games with winning strategies to multi-outcome settings with pure Nash equilibria. It demonstrates that any determinacy result over an arbitrary game structure can be converted into the existence of a multi-outcome pure Nash equilibrium on the same structure. The equilibrium-transfer theorem relies on cardinal or order-theoretic conditions, and counter-examples highlight the relevance of these requirements. For finitely many outcomes, the proof offers an algorithm to compute a Nash equilibrium with minimal complexity loss. Applications include generalizing Borel determinacy, positional determinacy of parity games, and finite-memory determinacy of Muller games.

title: Modified Renormalization Strategy for Sandpile Models
abstract:
Following the Renormalization Group scheme recently developed by Pietronero
{\it et al}, we introduce a simplifying strategy for the renormalization of the
relaxation dynamics of sandpile models. In our scheme, five sub-cells at a
generic scale $b$ form the renormalized cell at the next larger scale. Now the
fixed point has a unique nonzero dynamical component that allows for a great
simplification in the computation of the critical exponent $z$. The values
obtained are in good agreement with both numerical and theoretical results
previously reported.Comment: APS style, 9 pages and 3 figures. To be published in Phys. Rev.
fieldOfStudy: Physics Theoretical, Statistical Mechanics, Condensed Matter
summary: This paper introduces a simplified renormalization strategy for analyzing the relaxation dynamics of sandpile models, building upon the Renormalization Group scheme by Pietronero et al. The proposed scheme uses five sub-cells to form a renormalized cell, leading to a unique nonzero dynamical component at the fixed point. This greatly simplifies the computation of the critical exponent 'z'. The values obtained for 'z' are in good agreement with previously reported numerical and theoretical results, contributing to the understanding of Self-Organized Criticality (SOC) in dynamically driven systems.

title: Kenya: Data Strategy and Capacity Building
abstract: Kenya has undertaken much work to date on data and knowledge issues, and has advanced this through the Kenya Data Forum—a national initiative managed by the Deputy President's office that aims to develop and implement a long term sustainable local data strategy. Kenya, however, lacks an organized framework for collecting reliable and comparable data on philanthropy in the country; to help meet this need, the Philanthropy Sector in Kenya has come together over the decades through the creation of the East Africa Association of Grantmakers (EAAG) and more recently the Kenya Philanthropy Forum (KPF) and its Data Sub-group. In June 2015 the KPF organized a Philanthropy Data Management convening that brought together over 30 foundations and trusts to explore opportunities for strengthening data collection, management, and sharing data in the philanthropy forum for greater impact and influence on national development efforts in Kenya. As a result, certain outcomes and aspirations were agreed upon. They included:Establishing the principles for data management for philanthropy.Expanding the forum so that participation reflects the size and diversity of existing forms of philanthropy.Developing a standardized tool for data collection.Actively engaging in the existing philanthropy data initiative.Partnering with the Kenya National Bureau of Statistics (KNBS) to establish data sets that effectively capture the contribution of philanthropy in Kenya's development.The June 2015 meeting highlighted the urgent need for philanthropic data and that "Kenya lacks an organized framework for collecting reliable and comparable data on philanthropy in the country." To begin systematically addressing these recommendations, Foundation Center (a philanthropic support organisation based in New York) designed a multi-stage Data Strategy and Capacity Building Program, working in partnership with KPF, EAAG, Kenya Community Development Foundation (KCDF), and the Sustainable Development Goals Philanthropy Platform (SDGPP). This initiative was kicked off at a special "Data Scoping Meeting" of the KPF on 28 April 2016, attended by a total of 51 participants representing across section of Kenyan foundations, trusts, and support organisations. As reflected in the meeting agenda (see Appendix A), the objectives of the Data Scoping Meeting were as follows:1. Establish principles for collaborative data and knowledge management2. Understand the core data needs of philanthropy in Kenya3. Leverage available technologies for collecting and sharing data and knowledge4. Leverage global knowledge for local purposes5. Identify data challenges and set local goalsThis report summarizes the outcomes of the Data Scoping Meeting and outlines next steps in preparation for a follow-up meeting on Data Capacity Building in the coming months
fieldOfStudy: Business, Philanthropy, Data Management, Capacity Building
summary: This report details the outcomes of the 2016 Data Scoping Meeting, organized by the Kenya Philanthropy Forum (KPF) in partnership with Foundation Center, EAAG, KCDF, and SDGPP. The meeting, attended by Kenyan foundations and support organizations, aimed to address the urgent need for a structured framework for collecting reliable philanthropy data in Kenya. Key objectives included establishing principles for collaborative data management, understanding core data needs, leveraging technology and global knowledge, identifying challenges, and setting local goals. The initiative outlines steps towards strengthening data collection, management, and sharing within Kenya's philanthropic sector to enhance its impact on national development efforts, particularly given Kenya's lack of an organized framework for philanthropic data.

title: Strategy-proof Sharing
abstract: We consider the problem of sharing a divisible good, where agents prefer more to less. First, we prove that a sharing rule satisfies strategy proofness if and only if it has the quasi-constancy property: no one changes her own share by changing her announcements. Next, by constructing a system of linear equations in a manner that is consistent with quasi-constancy, we provide a way to find every strategy-proof sharing rule. Finally, we identify a necessary and sufficient condition for the existence of non-constant, strategy-proof sharing rules, by examining the relationship between the constancy of strategy-proof sharing rules and the dimension of the solution space of the linear system.Strategy-proofness, Bossiness, Non-constancy, Quasi-constancy.
summary: This paper investigates strategy-proofness in the context of sharing a divisible good among agents who prefer more to less. The authors prove that a sharing rule is strategy-proof if and only if it exhibits the quasi-constancy property, meaning agents cannot alter their share by changing their announcements. They provide a method to construct all strategy-proof sharing rules using a system of linear equations consistent with quasi-constancy. Furthermore, the study identifies the conditions necessary and sufficient for the existence of non-constant, strategy-proof sharing rules by analyzing the dimension of the linear system's solution space. Key concepts include Bossiness, Non-constancy, and Quasi-constancy.

title: CAPITAL PLANNING STRATEGY
abstract: The author outlines reasons for the declining capital productivity in the Supermarket Industry, present cash flow generated inadequate to sustain desired growth rate.Productivity Analysis,
summary: This article addresses the declining capital productivity within the supermarket industry, highlighting how current cash flow is insufficient to support desired growth rates. The author, Leonard W. Arentsen, outlines a capital planning strategy encompassing capital needs, financial strength evaluation, capital sources, and risk policy. Key areas discussed include working capital, property, internal cash flow, income statement effects, and tax considerations like investment credit. The paper identifies challenges such as high costs and lower sales per square foot, suggesting strategies like leveraging debt for growth and exploring alternative capital uses like vertical integration and convenience stores.

title: The Lisbon Strategy
abstract: The Lisbon Strategy Targets are presented and assessed as accordingly to the domains of the structural indicators, the common indicators created to measure the progress towards reaching these objectives: Economic performance; Employment; Research, Innovation and education; Economic reform; Social cohesion; Environment.structural indicators, economic performance.
summary: This paper assesses the Lisbon Strategy Targets by analyzing their progress across key structural indicators: economic performance, employment, research, innovation, education, economic reform, social cohesion, and environment. The strategy, initiated in March 2000 by the European Council, aims to transform the EU into the world's most competitive and dynamic knowledge-based economy, ensuring sustainable economic growth, improved employment opportunities, and enhanced social cohesion. It emphasizes economic, social, and environmental renewal through a commitment from EU governments.

title: India country strategy
abstract:
This strategy outlines a vision of where Australia\u27s relationship with India should be in 2025 and how Australia should get there.

Australia and India entered into a strategic partnership in 2009. By elevating the relationship to this level, both countries confirmed a strong commitment to expand and deepen collaboration.

India is a major regional power, and one that is rising globally. Of Australia’s significant bilateral relationships in Asia, that with India has perhaps the greatest potential to grow and develop towards 2025.

India can contribute to Australia’s vision of a more productive and resilient economy through greater trade and investment. Closer people-to-people, migration and travel links will benefit both countries, as will stronger bilateral and multilateral cooperation.

With a population of 1.2 billion people, India is a large and complex country.

In 2012, India became the third-largest economy in the world in terms of purchasing power parity (PPP), following 10 years in which average annual gross domestic product (GDP) growth was more than 7 per cent. The Indian economy is projected to grow at an average annual rate of 6.75 per cent between 2012 and 2025.

According to the United Nations Development Programme, over half of India’s population faces multidimensional poverty. Future growth and reduction in poverty will require a sustained effort to create jobs, improve skills, develop infrastructure and deliver better public services. The opportunities and challenges Australia faces when engaging with India could vary significantly depending on India’s rate and quality of growth, and the scale of its reform.

Australia can supply the resources that India needs to develop, whether this is coking coal for steel, or copper for construction. India is our fifth-largest export market and 10th-largest two-way trading partner. The two-way investment relationship is also growing. In 2012, India invested $10 billion in Australia, while Australia invested $5.7 billion in India
publisher: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade
summary: This document outlines a strategic vision for the Australia-India relationship by 2025, aiming for deeper collaboration across various sectors. Initiated from a 2009 strategic partnership, the strategy emphasizes enhancing trade, investment, and people-to-people links, acknowledging India's rising global economic power and its projected growth. It explores opportunities and challenges for Australia in supporting India's development, particularly in resources. The document details pathways for connecting communities, businesses, and governments, and highlights the importance of cooperation in the Indian Ocean region. Key themes include economic partnership, bilateral cooperation, and regional stability.

title: The urgent need for a revised Global Strategy. Chapter 1. Introduction to the Global Coconut Strategy
summary: This document outlines the urgent need for a revised Global Strategy for the Conservation and Use of Coconut Genetic Resources, initiated by upgrading COGENT's organization in 2012. Key changes included modifying the Steering Committee's role for increased stability and participation, establishing biennial meetings linked to APCC COCOTECH, and creating six permanent International Thematic Action Groups (ITAGS). Despite its crucial role in developing the global coconut conservation system, COGENT faces sustainability challenges, necessitating international collaboration for managing genetic resources. The revised strategy aims for a more efficient and sustainable global conservation system, emphasizing improved planning, coordination, and cooperation.

title: China country strategy
abstract:
This strategy outlines a vision of where Australia\u27s relationship with China should be in 2025 and how Australia should get there.

China’s rise to the top of the global economic and political order is defining the 21st century. By 2025, China is set to be the world’s largest economy. The Chinese economy’s size and scale, combined with robust growth, will consistently make China the largest contributor to global and Asian economic growth leading up to 2025.

How China manages its transformation from exportand investment-led development to a consumption and innovation-driven economy will determine the shape of the global economic system in the coming decades
fieldOfStudy: Business, International Relations, Economics, Strategic Planning
summary: This document outlines Australia's strategic vision for its relationship with China by 2025, detailing how Australia can navigate China's rise as the world's largest economy. It addresses the transformation of China's economy to a consumption and innovation-driven model, and its implications for global and Asian economic growth. The strategy proposes methods for connecting communities, businesses, and governments, including strengthening China capabilities, broadening multilateral cooperation, and developing defence relationships. Key areas include economic growth, international relations, trade, and strategic partnerships, with a focus on sustainable and inclusive development in the Asian century.

title: Heap games, numeration systems and sequences
abstract:
We propose and analyse a 2-parameter family of 2-player games on two heaps of
tokens, and present a strategy based on a class of sequences. The strategy
looks easy, but is actually hard. A class of exotic numeration systems is then
used, which enables us to decide whether the family has an efficient strategy
or not. We introduce yet another class of sequences, and demonstrate its
equivalence with the class of sequences defined for the strategy of our games.Comment: To appear in Annals of Combinatoric
fieldOfStudy: Business, Combinatorics, Game Theory, Numeration Systems, Sequence Analysis
summary: This paper introduces and analyzes a 2-parameter family of 2-player games played on two heaps of tokens. The authors propose a strategy based on a specific class of sequences, noting its deceptive simplicity. To determine the efficiency of this strategy, the study employs exotic numeration systems. Additionally, a new class of sequences is introduced, and its equivalence with the sequences used for the game strategy is demonstrated. This research contributes to understanding complex game strategies, numeration systems, and their interrelations, particularly for combinatorial games and sequence analysis.

title: Analytical strategy 2006
summary: This analytical strategy document outlines ten strategic themes to guide future initiatives and research, including demography, globalization, technology, social mobility, and user focus. It addresses the role of demand in shaping services, system reform, horizon scanning, value for money, and metrics. The document, published in 2006 by the Department for Education and Skills, also lists various research reports related to education, employment, and social welfare, such as studies on Sure Start Local Programmes, supply teachers, young people in jobs without training, and social exclusion, providing valuable resources for policy development and academic inquiry.

title: Book Review: Grant's Contemporary Strategy Analysis
fieldOfStudy: Business, Strategy, Strategic Management, Management Education
summary: This book review examines Robert M. Grant's "Contemporary Strategy Analysis: Text & Cases" (7th ed.), exploring the inherent complexities and multifaceted nature of strategy as an academic discipline. The review critiques the traditional textbook approaches that often present strategy as a collection of tools (e.g., PEST, SWOT, Five Forces) without fostering a deeper understanding. It suggests an alternative, more philosophical approach, potentially integrating "strategy as practice" with proven tools. The review praises Grant's effort to connect contemporary and ancient strategic concepts, linking external competitive advantage with internal resources, despite its grounding in conventional analysis.

title: Problems of the Strategy of Regions
abstract:
Problems that arise in the application of general prescriptions of the
so-called strategy of regions for asymptotic expansions of Feynman integrals in
various limits of momenta and masses are discussed with the help of
characteristic examples of two-loop diagrams. The strategy is also reformulated
in the language of alpha parameters.Comment: 12 pages, LaTeX with axodraw.st
summary: This paper discusses issues arising from applying the "strategy of regions" for asymptotic expansions of Feynman integrals, particularly in various limits of momenta and masses. The authors examine characteristic examples using two-loop diagrams, identifying specific problems. They also reformulate this strategy within the framework of alpha parameters. The purpose is to refine the understanding and application of this crucial technique for analyzing leading asymptotic behavior in quantum field theory, offering insights into its limitations and alternative representations. Key concepts include Feynman integrals, asymptotic expansions, strategy of regions, two-loop diagrams, and alpha parameters.

title: An improved lion strategy for the lion and man problem
abstract:
In this paper, a novel lion strategy for David Gale's lion and man problem is
proposed. The devised approach enhances a popular strategy proposed by Sgall,
which relies on the computation of a suitable "center". The key idea of the new
strategy is to update the center at each move, instead of computing it once and
for all at the beginning of the game. Convergence of the proposed lion strategy
is proven and an upper bound on the game length is derived, which dominates the
existing bounds.Comment: Preprint submitted to IEEE Control Systems Letter
fieldOfStudy: Business, Control Systems, Computational Game Theory
summary: This paper proposes a novel lion strategy for David Gale's lion and man problem, enhancing Sgall's popular approach. The key innovation is to continuously update the "center" at each move, rather than computing it only once at the game's outset. The study provides a rigorous proof of convergence for this new lion strategy and derives an upper bound on the game length. This derived bound significantly outperforms existing benchmarks, offering a more efficient and effective solution for pursuit-evasion games, specifically those categorized as combinatorial games. These advancements contribute to the field of control systems and computational game theory.

title: Play strategy for Scotland: our vision
summary: This document outlines Scotland's first National Play Strategy, aiming to make Scotland the best place for children and young people to grow up by valuing play as a life-enhancing daily experience. Developed with input from children, parents, carers, and the play sector, the strategy seeks to improve play experiences for all, including those with disabilities or from disadvantaged backgrounds. It emphasizes play's importance for brain development, bonding, independence, and autonomy, covering play in homes, nurseries, schools, and communities. Key sections include defining play, its significance, and positive support mechanisms.

title: Relative Strength of Strategy Elimination Procedures
abstract:
We compare here the relative strength of four widely used procedures on
finite strategic games: iterated elimination of weakly/strictly dominated
strategies by a pure/mixed strategy. A complication is that none of these
procedures is based on a monotonic operator. To deal with this problem we use
'global' versions of these operators.Comment: 8 page
summary: This paper compares the relative strength of four widely used procedures for reducing finite strategic games: iterated elimination of weakly/strictly dominated strategies by pure/mixed strategies. The authors address the complication that these procedures are not based on monotonic operators by utilizing 'global' versions of these operators. The study investigates the inclusions between these operators and their iterative outcomes, providing proofs for non-obvious implications. This work is crucial for understanding the foundational properties and practical applications of strategy elimination in game theory, focusing on theoretical comparisons and the mathematical framework for global operators.

title: Creating and Sustaining a Maintenance Strategy: A Practical Guide
abstract: Manufacturing companies should create maintenance strategy and link it to the manufacturing and business goals but recent research in the North East of England suggested that few companies do this. It is unclear why this inertia existed but it could have been due to the complexity and variety of the advice on offer in relation to the formulation and implementation of strategy. The purpose of this paper was to provide a simple generic guide or roadmap for practitioners to follow. It began by highlighting the importance and benefits of a maintenance strategy and then considered literature appropriate to the topic. A key point arising from this review was that the three elements; process, content, context, need to be considered over the lifecycle of a strategy. Moreover, most strategic models converged to simple sequential models affording a generic functional process to be developed. This involved the integration of the “corporate hard systems” model and the “Plan, do, check, act, cycle“, forming a suitable maintenance strategy process. Accordingly, further guidance on policy assured the right “content”. The paper concluded with a short questionnaire used to audit the effect of “contextual factors” on maintenance strategy. The result was a comprehensive guide on how to formulate and implement maintenance strategy
summary: This paper addresses the common issue of manufacturing companies failing to link their maintenance strategies to overall business goals, despite its importance. Recognizing the complexity and variety of existing strategic advice, the authors propose a simple, generic roadmap for practitioners. The research highlights that process, content, and context must be considered across a strategy's lifecycle. It integrates a 'corporate hard systems' model with the 'Plan, Do, Check, Act' cycle to form a robust maintenance strategy process, further guiding policy for appropriate content. The paper concludes with a questionnaire to audit contextual factors, providing a comprehensive guide for maintenance strategy formulation and implementation.

title: Strategy Similarity and Coordination.
abstract: This paper introduces similarity among strategies in the payoff assessment model of choice (Sarin and Vahid (1999, GEB)). The assessments of strategies that are more similar to the chosen strategy are updated more similarly to the chosen strategy. We use this model to explain a recent experiment.Econometric analysis of experimental data; Adaptive learning; Similarity; Coordination games; Payoff assessments without probabilities
fieldOfStudy: Business, Econometric Analysis, Adaptive Learning, Coordination Games
summary: This paper extends the payoff assessment model of choice (Sarin and Vahid, 1999) by introducing the concept of similarity among strategies. The core idea is that the assessments of strategies more closely resembling a chosen strategy will be updated more similarly. The authors apply this enhanced model to provide an explanation for observations from a recent experiment. Key themes include adaptive learning, coordination games, and payoff assessments without relying on probabilities.

title: The CMA Evolution Strategy: A Tutorial
abstract:
This tutorial introduces the CMA Evolution Strategy (ES), where CMA stands
for Covariance Matrix Adaptation. The CMA-ES is a stochastic, or randomized,
method for real-parameter (continuous domain) optimization of non-linear,
non-convex functions. We try to motivate and derive the algorithm from
intuitive concepts and from requirements of non-linear, non-convex search in
continuous domain.Comment: ArXiv e-prints, arXiv:1604.xxxx
summary: This tutorial provides a comprehensive introduction to the CMA Evolution Strategy (CMA-ES), a stochastic optimization method for real-parameter, non-linear, non-convex functions. The paper derives the algorithm from intuitive concepts and requirements for continuous domain search, covering key components such as basic sampling, selection and recombination for mean adaptation, and methods for adapting the covariance matrix, including Rank-"updates" and cumulation. It also addresses step-size control. This guide serves as a valuable resource for understanding and implementing the CMA-ES in various optimization challenges, particularly in evolutionary computation and machine learning.

title: Newsroom: Reuters: Logan on BP Strategy
authors: Roger Williams University School of Law
fieldOfStudy: Business Lawsuit Strategy Gulf Oil Spill Public Relations
summary: This news article details Dean David A. Logan's insights from Roger Williams University School of Law regarding BP's legal strategy following the Gulf oil spill. BP filed lawsuits against Transocean Ltd., Halliburton Co., and Cameron International Corp., seeking to spread the estimated $42 billion cost of the disaster, including punitive damages. Logan emphasizes that these suits aim to distribute liability and are part of a broader public relations effort to highlight that BP was not solely responsible for the catastrophic event, despite currently bearing the full cleanup and compensatory damage costs.

title: STRATEGIST'S TOOLKIT: STRATEGY MAPS
summary: This paper introduces strategy maps as a crucial tool within a comprehensive strategist's toolkit, designed to help managers navigate an increasingly competitive business environment. It outlines the importance of identifying and capitalizing on opportunities, fostering growth, and optimizing resource utilization. The authors, through consultations with business academics and alumni, developed a core toolkit including SWOT analysis, Porter's 5 forces, and PESTLE analysis. The strategic map tool, illustrated with an auto industry example (Mercedes, Ford, Toyota), aids in understanding competitive positioning and differentiation, cost leadership, and integrative strategies. The research suggests managers find these tools more valuable for analysis than for decision-making and implementation, highlighting a training gap.

title: Strategy for sustainable development : for consultation
summary: This document outlines the Learning and Skills Council's (LSC) strategy for sustainable development, seeking public consultation by March 31, 2005. It details how the LSC will integrate sustainable development through learning opportunities, resource management, and community engagement. The strategy aims to embed sustainable development skills within the post-16 education and training sector, addressing key areas like buildings, curriculum, and community involvement. It also invites feedback on proposals for working with partners and suggested actions to promote sustainability.

title: MEME-JACKING AS A MARKETING STRATEGY
summary: This document explores meme-jacking as an effective marketing strategy, leveraging the viral nature of internet memes. It outlines key advantages, including their inherent virality, significant influence on social media engagement, ability to attract traffic, likes, and links, and their ease of creation for content marketers. The paper suggests that by utilizing successful existing ideas, businesses can achieve market leadership in the dynamic digital landscape, emphasizing the importance of fun, engaging, and popular concepts for marketing campaigns.

title: The Complexity of Iterated Strategy Elimination
abstract:
We consider the computational complexity of the question whether a certain
strategy can be removed from a game by means of iterated elimination of
dominated strategies. In particular, we study the influence of different
definitions of domination and of the number of different payoff values. In
addition, the consequence of restriction to constant-sum games is shown
summary: This paper investigates the computational complexity of iterated elimination of dominated strategies in game theory. The authors explore how different definitions of domination and the number of distinct payoff values influence this complexity. Additionally, the study examines the implications of restricting the analysis to constant-sum games. The research contributes to understanding the computational demands of various solution concepts in game theory, focusing on strategy elimination and strategic decision-making. Key areas include computational complexity, game theory, iterated strategy elimination, dominance, and constant-sum games.

title: Thinking differently about strategy: comparing paradigms
abstract: Our paper shows that mainstream strategic thinking and research already challenges the established Newtonian-Cartesian paradigm. Newtonian thought is the customary mode of western thinking, but is that about to change? Some papers from a complexity standpoint have appeared in the mainstream journals but its precise implications and merits have yet to be systematically spelled out and debated. We aim to facilitate this debate by comparing the established Newtonian and emergent complexity paradigms, clarifying the implications of this new perspective for strategy research. We suggest that the complexity paradigm is better attuned to current strategic realities than its Newtonian-Cartesian counterpart
summary: This paper examines how mainstream strategic thinking challenges the established Newtonian-Cartesian paradigm, which has traditionally dominated Western thought. The authors note the emergence of complexity-based approaches in strategy research, but highlight the need for systematic debate on their implications. The study aims to facilitate this by comparing Newtonian and complexity paradigms, clarifying the new perspective's impact on strategy research. It suggests that the complexity paradigm is better suited to contemporary strategic realities than its Newtonian-Cartesian counterpart, offering a fresh lens for strategic management and organizational change.

title: Uganda: Data Strategy and Capacity Building
abstract: As part of Uganda's commitment to the Sustainable Development Agenda, the country has made substantial progress toward improved national development data—including the launch of a Development Data Hub supported by Development Initiatives and a review of open data readiness jointly undertaken by the government and the World Bank. Uganda however, lacks an organized framework for collecting and sharing reliable and comparable data on philanthropy. As such, the newly established Uganda National Philanthropy Forum (UPF) represents a key mechanism for the sector to consolidate its e orts and hone its contributions to national development. The forum was established in October 2015, facilitated by the East Africa Association of Grantmakers (EAAG), in partnership with Independent Development Fund (IDF), Development Network of Indigenous Voluntary Associations (DENIVA) and GoBig Hub. Its objective is to explore strategies for consolidating and organizing the philanthropy sector in Uganda.As a follow up to the UPF agenda on advancing philanthropy data in Uganda, EAAG and the Foundation Center in partnership with IDF and DENIVA hosted a Data Scoping Meeting on October 25th 2016. The objective of the meeting was to explore opportunities to strengthen data sharing and management to enhance the sector's coordination and in uence on national development policy. The meeting brought together 35 foundations, trusts and other local philanthropy organizations
fieldOfStudy: Business, Philanthropy, Data Strategy, Capacity Building
summary: Uganda has made significant strides in national development data, but lacks a structured framework for philanthropy data. In response, the Uganda National Philanthropy Forum (UPF) was established in 2015 to consolidate efforts and enhance contributions to national development. A 2016 Data Scoping Meeting, involving 35 organizations, aimed to strengthen data sharing and management within the philanthropy sector to improve coordination and influence on national policy. Key objectives included providing a platform for best practices and fostering joint learning. The initiative seeks to generate reliable data on local philanthropy's impact on national development.

title: East Midlands Transport Equipment Sector Strategy
abstract: Transport equipment has been identified as a key sector in the East Midlands economy. This strategy sets out a vision for the development of the sector and how it can contribute to the attainment of regional economic development objectives
fieldOfStudy: Business, Regional Economic Development, Transport Equipment Sector, Strategy
summary: This document outlines the East Midlands Transport Equipment Sector Strategy, developed by emda in October 2007. The strategy aims to contribute to regional economic development objectives by focusing on the transport equipment sector, identified as key to the East Midlands economy. It details the sector's significance, scale, and proposes priority actions to support its growth, address skills needs, and enhance efficiency and excellence within the region. The report considers various niche sectors and how local agencies can provide customized support, ensuring alignment between training providers, business support organizations, and sector requirements. Key sectors include transport equipment, construction, food and drink, and healthcare.

title: Towards A regional resources strategy consultation
abstract: Report produced for emda to inform the agency's input into regional Waste and Resources Strategies.  Reviews policy context, available data and views from key stakeholders
summary: This report, prepared for emda by Atkins Limited in July 2010, aims to inform regional Waste and Resources Strategies by reviewing policy context, available data, and stakeholder views. It outlines a two-stage project involving a document review and consultation process, presenting the results from both. The document explores political changes and proposes actions such as developing support frameworks for smaller waste organizations, establishing resource recovery parks, and promoting innovative community-level approaches. It also advocates for consistent recycling regimes, product stewardship schemes, and specific waste reduction strategies for various sectors.

title: Evaluation of Phase 1 City Strategy
summary: This report evaluates Phase 1 of the City Strategy (CS) initiative, focusing on its impact on employment and benefit off-flow rates. Conducted by the Institute for Employment Research for the Department for Work and Pensions, the study employs regressions to model off-flow rates from Jobseeker's Allowance (JSA), including off-flows to employment. Initial findings suggest a positive CS effect on JSA off-flows, though a similar increase was observed in comparison areas. The report explores potential reasons for observed differences, acknowledging the influence of wider economic conditions on employment outcomes and the challenges in isolating the specific impact of the CS program.

title:
Integrating fluctuations into distribution of resources in
  transportation networks
abstract:
We propose a resource distribution strategy to reduce the average travel time
in a transportation network given a fixed generation rate. Suppose that there
are essential resources to avoid congestion in the network as well as some
extra resources. The strategy distributes the essential resources by the
average loads on the vertices and integrates the fluctuations of the
instantaneous loads into the distribution of the extra resources. The
fluctuations are calculated with the assumption of unlimited resources, where
the calculation is incorporated into the calculation of the average loads
without adding to the time complexity. Simulation results show that the
fluctuation-integrated strategy provides shorter average travel time than a
previous distribution strategy while keeping similar robustness. The strategy
is especially beneficial when the extra resources are scarce and the network is
heterogeneous and lowly loaded.Comment: 14 pages, 4 figure
fieldOfStudy: Business, Transportation Networks, Resource Distribution, Traffic Management
summary: This paper proposes a resource distribution strategy to minimize average travel time in transportation networks with a fixed generation rate. The approach distributes essential resources based on average vertex loads and integrates instantaneous load fluctuations into the allocation of extra resources. The fluctuation calculation is efficiently incorporated into average load computations without increasing time complexity. Simulation results indicate that this fluctuation-integrated strategy achieves shorter average travel times and similar robustness compared to previous methods, particularly benefiting heterogeneous, lowly loaded networks with scarce extra resources. This strategy is valuable for optimizing traffic flow and congestion management in complex networks.

title: The Complexity of All-switches Strategy Improvement
abstract:
Strategy improvement is a widely-used and well-studied class of algorithms
for solving graph-based infinite games. These algorithms are parameterized by a
switching rule, and one of the most natural rules is "all switches" which
switches as many edges as possible in each iteration. Continuing a recent line
of work, we study all-switches strategy improvement from the perspective of
computational complexity. We consider two natural decision problems, both of
which have as input a game $G$, a starting strategy $s$, and an edge $e$. The
problems are: 1.) The edge switch problem, namely, is the edge $e$ ever
switched by all-switches strategy improvement when it is started from $s$ on
game $G$? 2.) The optimal strategy problem, namely, is the edge $e$ used in the
final strategy that is found by strategy improvement when it is started from
$s$ on game $G$? We show $\mathtt{PSPACE}$-completeness of the edge switch
problem and optimal strategy problem for the following settings: Parity games
with the discrete strategy improvement algorithm of V\"oge and Jurdzi\'nski;
mean-payoff games with the gain-bias algorithm [14,37]; and discounted-payoff
games and simple stochastic games with their standard strategy improvement
algorithms. We also show $\mathtt{PSPACE}$-completeness of an analogous problem
to edge switch for the bottom-antipodal algorithm for finding the sink of an
Acyclic Unique Sink Orientation on a cube
fieldOfStudy: Computer Science, Computational Complexity, Game Theory
summary: This paper investigates the computational complexity of "all-switches" strategy improvement algorithms, a class of algorithms used for solving graph-based infinite games. The authors introduce and analyze two decision problems: the edge switch problem (whether an edge 'e' is ever switched) and the optimal strategy problem (whether 'e' is used in the final strategy). They demonstrate PSPACE-completeness for both problems across various settings, including parity games with discrete strategy improvement, mean-payoff games with the gain-bias algorithm, and discounted-payoff/simple stochastic games with standard strategy improvement. The findings are significant for understanding the theoretical limits of these widely-used game-solving algorithms.

title: Welsh-medium Education Strategy (information document)
abstract:
"This Strategy sets out the ambition of the Welsh Assembly

Government for a country where Welsh-medium education and

training are integral parts of the education nfrastructure. We want to ensure that our education system makes it possible for more learners of all ages to acquire a wider range of language skills in Welsh. This will enable them to use the language in their personal lives, socially and in the workplace. We want to see a system which is responsive to public demand for an increase in Welsh-medium provision." - introduction
publisher: Department for Children, Education, Lifelong Learning and Skills (DCELLS) (Wales)
summary: This document outlines the Welsh Assembly Government's Strategy and Implementation Programme for Welsh-medium education, aiming to integrate it into the education infrastructure across Wales. The purpose is to enable more learners of all ages to acquire Welsh language skills for personal, social, and workplace use, responding to public demand for increased provision. Key initiatives include expanding Welsh-medium training places for youth workers and promoting language awareness across diverse communities. It emphasizes the importance of Welsh as an additional language and for speakers of other languages, involving various educational bodies and local authorities.

title: Corporate real estate asset management : aligned vision
abstract:
Purpose – The purpose of this paper is to evaluate the relationship between corporate strategy and corporate real estate (CRE) strategy.

Design/methodology/approach – The paper will identify, and evaluate, a number of components that collectively form the CRE strategy. Linkages between the business environment, the aims and objectives of the organisation and the real estate solution will be explored.

Findings – The paper will illustrate the alignment of the CRE strategy to the corporate strategy through the development of a CRE alignment model. The model will demonstrate that only when optimum alignment is achieved can the CRE strategy deliver added value and enhanced organisational performance.

Practical implications – CRE managers can use the model to evaluate the alignment of their CRE strategy with their corporate strategy.

Originality/value – The paper fills a void by proposing a framework that seeks to identify the true impact of real estate to business by examining the benefits of optimal alignment between, planet, position, purpose, place, paradigm, processes and people to produce performance and productivity.</p
fieldOfStudy: Business, Corporate Real Estate Strategy, Real Estate Asset Management
summary: This paper evaluates the relationship between corporate strategy and Corporate Real Estate (CRE) strategy, proposing a CRE alignment model. It identifies and assesses components of CRE strategy, exploring linkages between the business environment, organizational objectives, and real estate solutions. The model demonstrates that optimal alignment between CRE and corporate strategy delivers added value and enhanced organizational performance. It offers a framework for CRE managers to evaluate alignment, emphasizing the impact of real estate on business through considering elements like planet, position, purpose, place, paradigm, processes, and people to improve productivity. Key themes include corporate strategy, real estate management, organizational performance, and asset maximization.

title: Building and implementing an effective local workforce strategy Module 8: launching, promoting and communicating the strategy
publisher: National College for Leadership of Schools and Children's services (NCSL)
summary: This guide outlines a practical framework for building and implementing an effective local workforce strategy within children's services. Developed jointly by the National College for Leadership of Schools and Children's Services, the Children's Workforce Development Council, and the Training and Development Agency for Schools, it focuses on enabling people within organizations to drive change. The resource provides guiding principles for creating and launching strategies to ensure excellence in practice, collaborative working, and professional development, ultimately aiming to improve outcomes for children and young people. Key themes include workforce development, leadership, and strategic planning.

title: Child poverty strategy progress report 2013
summary: This 2013 progress report from the Children's Commissioner for Wales outlines efforts to combat child poverty and champion children's rights. It details the Commissioner's role, established by acts like the Care Standards Act 2000, in supporting, listening to, advising, and influencing government to ensure children lead safe and happy lives. Key updates include sections on child poverty in Wales, the Community Ambassadors Pilot Scheme, and equality matters, emphasizing the commitment to reducing socio-economic inequalities. The report serves as a valuable resource for stakeholders interested in child welfare and public policy in Wales.

title: Transport strategy in Scotland since devolution
abstract: This article critically reviews how the Scottish Executive's approach to transport has developed since devolution. Although there is much to commend, a number of concerns can be identified, including the possibility that a number of strategic infrastructure schemes appear to have been approved on political rather than on technical grounds. It is difficult to know whether the current set of transport infrastructure investment plans represents good value for public money
authors: Standing Committee on Trunk Road Assessment (SACTRA)
summary: This article critically reviews the Scottish Executive's evolving approach to transport since devolution, identifying both commendations and concerns. It highlights potential issues with strategic infrastructure schemes approved on political rather than technical grounds, questioning the value for public money of current investment plans. The paper investigates transport strategy development, governance, institutional change, and public policy, offering insights into transport geography, policy, and practice. Key topics include public spending, investment decisions, and the reopening of the Waverley rail route as a case study.

title: The Evolution Of The Philadelphia Stock Exchange
summary: This article explores the enduring survival of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange (PHLX), the oldest in the U.S., amidst larger and more liquid securities markets. John Caskey identifies factors contributing to its longevity and how their significance has changed over time. The paper also profiles major shifts in U.S. securities markets in recent decades, highlighting the often-overlooked role of regional stock exchanges. This analysis provides insights into market evolution, institutional resilience, and historical financial structures, relevant for financial history and market microstructure.

title: Review Of  Finance And The Good Society  By R.J. Shiller
summary: This document presents a review of Robert J. Shiller's book, "Finance and the Good Society," by Erin Todd Bronchetti, published in the Journal of Economic Literature. It also includes a discussion of Hugh Rockoff's "America's Economic Way of War," which surveys 20th-century conflicts and their impact on the U.S. economy. Rockoff's work challenges the idea that wartime economies are aberrations, arguing that understanding these periods is crucial for comprehending 20th-century economic development. Key themes include economic history, the role of finance, and the economic effects of war.

title: OECD\u27s FDI Regulatory Restrictiveness Index: Revision And Extension To More Economies
abstract: This paper provides a revised measure of regulatory restrictions on inward foreign direct investment (FDI) for OECD countries and extends the approach to 13 non-member countries. The methodology is largely similar to that adopted in the previous version of the OECD indicator and covers three broad categories of restrictions: limitations on foreign ownership, screening or notification procedures, and management and operational restrictions. The FDI restrictiveness indicator captures statutory deviations from  national treatment , i.e. discrimination against foreign investment. When combined with other factors having an influence on foreign investment decisions, it has proven to be a good predictor of countries\u27 inward FDI performance
summary: This paper introduces a revised measure of regulatory restrictions on inward foreign direct investment (FDI) for OECD countries, extending its application to 13 non-member economies. The methodology, consistent with prior OECD indicators, categorizes restrictions into foreign ownership limitations, screening/notification procedures, and management/operational constraints. The FDI restrictiveness indicator specifically quantifies statutory deviations from national treatment, highlighting discrimination against foreign investment. This indicator, when integrated with other influencing factors, demonstrates strong predictive power for a country's inward FDI performance, making it a valuable tool for economic analysis and policy formulation related to international investment flows.

title: Are Corporate Takeovers In The Nation\u27s Interest?
summary: This work explores the critical question of whether corporate takeovers serve the nation's interest. The author, Ellen B. Magenheim, investigates the economic implications and public policy considerations surrounding these financial transactions. Published in the Forum For Applied Research And Public Policy, the article delves into the potential benefits and drawbacks of takeovers, likely examining their impact on employment, market competition, shareholder value, and broader economic stability. It provides a foundational discussion for understanding corporate finance and its societal effects, particularly from an economic perspective.

title: Economic effects of tax cooperation in an enlarged European Union
abstract: This study evaluates the economic effects of different scenarios of tax cooperation in the enlarged European Union in the framework of a General Equilibrium Model. The study develops scenarios for a common corporate tax base applicable in all EU Member States, for full harmonisation of tax bases and tax rates, and for the exchange of savings information in the context of personal income taxationEuropean Union, taxation, company taxation
summary: This study evaluates the economic effects of various tax cooperation scenarios within an enlarged European Union using a General Equilibrium Model. It develops scenarios for a common corporate tax base, full harmonization of tax bases and rates, and the exchange of savings information in personal income taxation. The research aims to understand the implications of these tax policies on the EU's economy, considering factors like corporate tax rates across member states and elasticities in the model, to inform policy decisions regarding EU taxation and economic integration.

title: Stratification Economics and Identity Economics
abstract: Stratification economics represents an important new approach devoted to explaining economic inequality in terms of how social groups are separated or stratified along economic lines. This paper combines stratification economics with identity economics to address complications that the phenomenon of intersectionality – people having multiple social group identities – creates for stratification economics. It distinguishes two types of social identities recognized by social psychologists, categorical and relational social identities, and uses this distinction to explain how individuals’ personal identities, understood as ordered sets of social identities, can be seen to be both socially and self-constructed. Individuals order and rank their categorical social identities according to weights they assign to them in interactive social settings in which their role-based relational social identities combine different categorical social identities. Recent research in social psychology in the stigma identity threat literature is then reviewed to distinguish two different ways in which individuals respond to others’ stigmatization of their social groups in interactive settings. The paper argues that individuals respond to stigma by assigning weights to their categorical social group identities in ways that reflect both functional power relationships and stigmatization in a way that on balance tend to reinforce social stratification
fieldOfStudy: Business, Economics, Social Psychology, Identity Economics, Stratification Economics
summary:
This paper integrates stratification economics with identity economics to explore how intersectionality 

—multiple social group identities 

—complicates economic inequality explanations. It distinguishes categorical and relational social identities, explaining how personal identities are both socially and self-constructed. Individuals rank their categorical identities based on weights assigned in interactive settings, where relational identities combine different categorical ones. Reviewing stigma identity threat literature, the paper identifies two responses to stigmatization, arguing that individuals assign weights reflecting functional power and stigma, which ultimately reinforces social stratification. This research is important for understanding economic inequality, social groups, and identity formation.

title: [Review of the book \u3ci\u3ePersonnel Economics\u3c/i\u3e]
abstract: [Excerpt] What is personnel economics? Despite its name (non-economists may be put off by the use of the word “personnel,” which was left behind by what is now called human resource management about a quarter century ago), personnel economics deals with issues of fundamental importance in the workplace. As the editors explain in the introduction, “The literature is distinguished from other parts of labour economics primarily by its focus on problems that are central to business.” Thus, personnel economics is economics, it is that part of economics that deals with workplace issues, and it is firmly grounded in labor economics. Whether you call it personnel economics, workplace economics, an economic approach to human resource management, or something else, the field is breaking exciting new ground, asking questions that simply were not asked when I and others of my academic generation were learning labor economics
fieldOfStudy: Business, Human Resource Management, Labor Economics, Labor Relations
summary: This review discusses a book on personnel economics, a field focusing on workplace issues and business-centric problems within labor economics. It highlights the distinction between U.S. and European approaches to Human Resource Management (HRM), emphasizing the book's value in comparing HR models and providing summaries of key research streams. The book is recommended for students and practitioners interested in global HR systems and the future direction of the field, offering a new model and case studies for analyzing HR contributions.

title: The Emperor\u27s Clothes
abstract: Argues that neoclassical economics is primarily a theory of the human individual in economic life but contemporary mainstream economics does not posses a theory of the human individual. Definition of mainstream economics; Origin of the Enlightenment theory of the individual that came to underlie neoclassical economics at the end of the nineteenth century; Problems in neoclassical economics\u27 treatment of individuals
fieldOfStudy: Business Economics History of Economic Thought
summary: This article argues that while neoclassical economics was fundamentally a theory of the human individual in economic contexts, contemporary mainstream economics lacks such a theory. The author concurs with the verdict that "neoclassical economics" as a term should be considered obsolete, but for different reasons than previously proposed. The paper explores the definition of mainstream economics, traces the Enlightenment origins of the individual theory underlying neoclassical economics, and identifies problems in how neoclassical economics treats individuals. This disappearance of a theory of the individual is emphasized due to its historical importance in Western thought and economics.

title: The importance of meta-economics
abstract:
E.F. Schumacher was one of the first scholars who recognized the crucial role of metaeconomics.

In his "Small is beautiful" he writes: "The science of economics is 'so prone to usurp

the rest' … because it relates to certain very strong drives of human nature, such as envy and

greed. All the greater is the duty of its experts, the economists, to understand and clarify its

limitations, that is to say, to understand meta-economics." (Schumacher, E. F. 1973: p. 38)

Meta-economics is the basic assumptions about the subject-matter, value-orientation and

methodology of economics. (Zsolnai, L. 1991) The paper attempts to reconstruct the metaeconomic

foundation of mainstream economics and that of alternative economics initiated by

Schumacher. It shows how the emerging alternative economics transcends the erroneous metaeconomic

assumptions of mainstream economics by considering the total economic process,

choosing sustainable livelihood as basic value-orientation, and employing a constructive

methodology
summary: This paper reconstructs the meta-economic foundations of mainstream economics and alternative economics, initiated by E.F. Schumacher. It highlights Schumacher's recognition of meta-economics' crucial role, which he defined as the basic assumptions about economics' subject-matter, value-orientation, and methodology. The study argues that alternative economics transcends erroneous mainstream assumptions by considering the total economic process, adopting sustainable livelihood as a core value, and employing a constructive methodology. This approach aims to make economics a more reliable tool for ecological and human reconstruction, preventing it from losing its relevance in academia and policy. Key concepts include meta-economics, alternative economics, sustainable livelihood, and constructive methodology.

title: HEALTH AND HEALTH ECONOMICS: A CONCEPTUAL FRAMEWORK
abstract: Over the last three decades, treating health economics as an independent scientific discipline and providing specific treatment to the topics related to the economics of the health care sector have become more and more common. Currently, the field is so well established that it has appeared in the ordinary curriculum of most universities, and even if health economists are mainly to be found in the medical departments, the connections to economics proper are being strengthened, and the methodologies applied are getting refined. In this connection the paper highlights about the concept of health, why does health matter, relationship between health and Health Economics, and the justification of health economics
summary: This paper conceptualizes health economics as an independent scientific discipline, increasingly integrated into university curricula and strengthening its ties to broader economics. It explores the multifaceted concept of health, emphasizing why health is crucial, and elucidates the relationship between health and health economics. The authors aim to justify the field's existence and refine its methodologies, particularly by examining definitional challenges of health for economic analysis. This work provides a framework for understanding the foundations and applications of health economics.

title: Ocean Economics
abstract: Supply and demand is alive and well on the high seas. Just ask Finn McMichael ’16. He spent the summer putting his economics and math skills to work during an internship at the Northeast Fisheries Science Center, part of the National Marine Fisheries Service. Living on Cape Cod, McMichael worked with an economist to estimate quota prices for Northeast fisheries, specifically groundfish such as cod, flounder, halibut and sole. The internship was part of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Hollings Undergraduate Scholarship program
fieldOfStudy: Business, Economics, Math, Computer Science, Ocean Economics, Natural Resource Economics
summary: Finn McMichael, a Linfield College student, applied his economics and math skills during a summer internship at the Northeast Fisheries Science Center, part of NOAA. Working on Cape Cod, McMichael collaborated with an economist to estimate quota prices for various Northeast groundfish species, including cod, flounder, halibut, and sole. This experience, part of the NOAA Hollings Undergraduate Scholarship program, provided practical insights into ocean economics and resource management, enhancing his ability to translate theoretical knowledge into real-world applications. McMichael, also skilled in computer science, gained valuable hands-on experience for his future career in natural resource economics.

title: 2. Economics
abstract: The study of the way in which man makes a living — a short definition of economics — or of how he makes use of limited resources to satisfy unlimited wants -- another definition — has been traced in this work from Aristotle through the Middle Ages and mercantilism to the nineteenth century, when the classicists and their numerous critics, under the influence of industrialization and the intellectual trends of the day, created a large body of economic thought. In Chapter XIV we saw how, at the end of the century, Alfred Marshall (1842-1924) attempted to reformulate classical theory to bring it up to date. He was aware of the criticism that what the classicists had produced was a science of wealth which was not at all a science of welfare. This, many of them had insisted, was their true purpose, to limit themselves to treating what is to the exclusion of what ought to be. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
summary: This work traces the historical development of economic thought, defining economics as the study of how humans make a living or use limited resources to satisfy unlimited wants. It spans from Aristotle, through the Middle Ages and mercantilism, to the 19th century, highlighting the contributions of classicists and their critics, influenced by industrialization.
