The study notes Alfred Marshall's late 19th-century effort to reformulate classical theory, acknowledging criticisms that it was a science of wealth rather than welfare. Key themes include the evolution of economic definitions, theoretical reformulations, and the debate between wealth and welfare as economic objectives, useful for searching economic history and classical economics.

title: Is Takeover Fever Jeopardizing Our Nation\u27s Health?
summary: This article explores whether "takeover fever" jeopardizes the nation's economic health, challenging the simplistic view that takeovers always result in a net gain. It argues that increasing institutional shareholding and the threat of takeovers compel managers to prioritize short-run performance over long-term financial health, potentially stifling crucial investments in research and development. The author suggests that while some shareholders may benefit, others lose, and the overall economy faces risks like increased bankruptcy and unemployment from highly leveraged companies. Keywords: corporate takeovers, economic health, short-run performance, long-term investment, R&D, institutional shareholders, financial leveraging.

title: Behavioral Economics and Health Economics
abstract: The health sector is filled with institutions and decision-making circumstances that create friction in markets and cognitive errors by decision makers. This paper examines the potential contributions to health economics of the ideas of behavioral economics. The discussion presented here focuses on the economics of doctor-patient interactions and some aspects of quality of care. It also touches on issues related to insurance and the demand for health care. The paper argues that long standing research impasses may be aided by applying concepts from behavioral economics.
summary: This paper explores the integration of behavioral economics concepts into health economics, addressing market frictions and cognitive biases within the health sector. It focuses on doctor-patient interactions, quality of care, insurance, and healthcare demand. The author argues that applying behavioral economics can resolve long-standing research impasses, offering new perspectives on issues such as decision-making circumstances, market dynamics, and consumer behavior in health. This approach aims to enhance understanding and intervention strategies in health policy and practice.

title: Global influences on UK manufacturing prices: 1970-2000
abstract: This paper presents substantial new evidence on the competitive process that  links together industrial economic and international economics. Our time-series data base  concerns manufactured product prices and their domestic and international determinants.  We identity cointegrating relationships, using single equation and multivariate methods.  We find that both market imperfections, largely ignored in international economics, and  international factors, mostly neglected in industrial economics, should be jointly incorporated  into pricing analysis. The significance of global factors varies markedly: differentiated-product  sectors respond little to foreign price signals. Our findings are relevant to many fields within  economics, including the transmission of inflation
fieldOfStudy: Business, Industrial Economics, International Economics, Cointegration Analysis
summary: This paper presents new evidence on the competitive process linking industrial economics and international economics, using time-series data on manufactured product prices and their domestic/international determinants. Employing single equation and multivariate cointegration methods, the study finds that both market imperfections (often ignored in international economics) and international factors (often neglected in industrial economics) should be jointly incorporated into pricing analysis. The significance of global factors varies, with differentiated-product sectors showing less responsiveness to foreign price signals. These findings are relevant to various economic fields, including inflation transmission, industrial pricing, and international competition.

title: Petroleum Industry's Economic Contribution to North Dakota in 2007
abstract: Environmental Economics and Policy, Financial Economics, Production Economics,

Utilizing surveys administered with the North Dakota Petroleum Council, the research gathers data from companies and individuals in the industry, including oil leasing firms. Key methods involve collecting information on bonus payments for oil leases, the percentage distributed to various entities (in-state residents, federal, and state agencies), and net lease acres, categorized by private, federal, and state acreage. The findings aim to provide a comprehensive economic impact assessment for stakeholders, including state agencies and industry participants.

title: Influence of Course Delivery Method and Proctoring on Performance in Introductory Economics
abstract: This work was published in the Review of Agricultural Economics. See Wachenheim, C.J. 2009. Final Exam Scores in Introductory Economics Courses: Effect of Course Delivery Method and Proctoring. Review of Agricultural Economics 31(3), pp. 640-652.Online, Assessment, Education, Economics, Teaching/Communication/Extension/Profession,
summary: This study compares student performance on final exams in introductory economics courses delivered online versus in traditional classrooms, focusing on the impact of exam proctoring. The research found that students in classroom settings performed better on proctored final exams compared to those online. Notably, online students taking non-proctored online final exams scored significantly higher (more than a full letter grade) than their counterparts who took proctored online finals. This suggests that course delivery method and proctoring significantly influence student outcomes, impacting assessment, education, and teaching methods in economics.

summary: This collection of abstracts from annual meetings covers various topics in agribusiness and economics. One study examines the cost-benefit analysis of an abscission agent for citrus mechanical harvesting, finding a net present value between $60.8 and $79.9 million over 10 years. Another investigates labor costs and value in citrus operations with alternative technologies, using a discounted cash flow approach. Further research explores the impact of higher shipping costs on localized produce sourcing and the relationship between food prices and monetary policies in Iran. Additionally, risk perceptions regarding food safety are studied as a tool for market segmentation in the U.S. poultry market.

title: INVOLVEMENT OF AGRICULTURAL ECONOMICS IN GRADUATE AGRIBUSINESS PROGRAMS: AN UNCOMFORTABLE LINKAGE
abstract: Departments of agricultural economics face a changing environment. Some argue for the adoption of the Master of Agribusiness degree. I argue that agribusiness in not well differentiated from agricultural economics and that the forte of agricultural economics departments is teaching applied economics, not teaching management. Furthermore, in today's dynamic, open economy, a good understanding of economics is more valuable than ever before. Rather than leave our area of strength, we should look to improve our current degree programs given today's business needs.Agribusiness, Teaching/Communication/Extension/Profession,
summary: This paper argues against the adoption of Master of Agribusiness degrees by agricultural economics departments, asserting that agribusiness is not sufficiently distinct from agricultural economics. The author contends that the core strength of agricultural economics departments lies in teaching applied economics, rather than management. Given the dynamic, open economy, a strong understanding of economics is deemed more valuable than management training. Instead of shifting focus, the paper advocates for improving existing degree programs to meet contemporary business needs, emphasizing applied economics and analysis as areas of comparative advantage. Keywords: agribusiness, agricultural economics, graduate programs, applied economics.

title: Optimum Land Allocation for Species Protection and Military Training on DoD Installations
abstract: Replaced with revised version of poster 8/11/10.Environmental Economics and Policy, Health Economics and Policy, Land Economics/Use,

summary: This poster explores optimum land allocation for species protection and military training on DoD installations, addressing the complex problem of balancing conservation and military land use. The authors propose using optimization models, specifically integer programming, to identify suitable land for conservation while accounting for military needs. These models can incorporate spatial and ecological criteria, allowing for the simultaneous resolution of multiple land uses. Key findings suggest that adding spatial requirements can lead to less suitable, larger, or less compact conservation management areas and computationally more complex models. The research provides a framework for natural resource managers on military lands.

title: Modeling Pine as a Carbon Sequestering Crop in Arkansas
abstract: Carbon Sequestration, Loblolly Pine, Carbon Offset, Carbon Policy, Environmental Economics and Policy, Land Economics/Use, Resource /Energy Economics and Policy,

summary: This paper models the economic feasibility of using Loblolly Pine as a carbon sequestering crop in Arkansas. The study investigates how various climate change policy options, particularly those involving carbon markets like the Chicago Climate Exchange, could incentivize landowners to convert agricultural land to pine plantations for carbon sequestration. Utilizing a regional agricultural land use model, the research quantifies changes in acreage allocation, production practices, and net returns under different carbon offset price scenarios. Key findings include the impact of carbon prices on pine acreage expansion and the resulting carbon sequestration potential, providing insights into the economic drivers for carbon offset programs in agriculture.

title: Extreme Returns without News: A Microstructural Explanation
abstract: What triggers extreme exchange-rate returns? Though news is the source of volatility in standard theoretical models, in reality volatility is often unrelated to news. This paper shows that extreme exchange-rate returns -- and, more generally, high kurtosis of returns -- are statistically inevitable even in the absence of news. We identify four microstructural sources of return kurtosis in price-contingent order flow: (1) high kurtosis in the distribution of price-contingent order sizes; (2) clustering of price-contingent order executions at certain times of day; (3) clustering of order executions at certain price levels; and (4) the tendency of positive-feedback trading to propagate trends. Using simulations calibrated to price-contingent orders placed at a major foreign exchange dealing bank we show that when each factor operates in isolation, the one that contributes most to kurtosis in returns is kurtosis in the order-size distribution. When the factors operate simultaneously, however, their interactions prove far more important. Extreme returns in the absence of news should be viewed as natural rather than anomalous.kurtosis, exchange rates, order flow, high-frequency, microstructure, jump process, value-atrisk, risk management
summary: This paper investigates the triggers of extreme exchange-rate returns and high kurtosis of returns, positing their statistical inevitability even without news. It identifies four microstructural sources in price-contingent order flow: kurtosis in order sizes, clustering of executions by time and price, and positive-feedback trading. Using simulations calibrated to foreign exchange dealing bank data, the study reveals that while order-size kurtosis is significant in isolation, the interactions between these factors are far more crucial when they operate simultaneously. The findings suggest that extreme returns in the absence of news are natural rather than anomalous, contributing to understanding exchange rates, order flow, high-frequency trading, and risk management.

The reviewer praises the book's comprehensive nature and insightful perspective, particularly its critical examination of the field and its exploration of concepts like mutuality. It is recommended for scholars and practitioners in Islamic economics and finance.

These studies offer insights into agricultural economics, rural development, and policy analysis.

title: ON PRICE TAKING BEHAVIOR IN A NONRENEWABLE RESOURCE CARTEL-FRINGE GAME
abstract: We consider a nonrenewable resource game with one cartel and a set of fringe members. We show that (i) the outcomes of the closed-loop and the open-loop nonrenewable resource game with the fringe members as price takers (the cartel-fringe game a la Salant 1976) coincide and (ii) when the number of fringe firms becomes arbitrarily large, the equilibrium outcome of the closed-loop Nash game does not coincide with the equilibrium outcome of the closed-loop cartel-fringe game. Thus, the outcome of the cartel-fringe open-loop equilibrium can be supported as an outcome of a subgame perfect equilibrium. However the interpretation of the cartel-fringe model, where from the outset the fringe is assumed to be price taker, as a limit case of an asymmetric oligopoly with the agents playing Nash-Cournot, does not extend to the case where firms can use closed-loop strategies.
fieldOfStudy: Business Economics, Nonrenewable Resources, Dynamic Games
summary: This paper investigates a nonrenewable resource game featuring a cartel and fringe members. It demonstrates two key findings: first, the outcomes of closed-loop and open-loop nonrenewable resource games, where fringe members are price takers (the Salant 1976 cartel-fringe model), coincide. Second, as the number of fringe firms increases indefinitely, the equilibrium outcome of the closed-loop Nash game diverges from that of the closed-loop cartel-fringe game. The study concludes that while the cartel-fringe open-loop equilibrium can be supported as a subgame perfect equilibrium, the interpretation of the cartel-fringe model as a limit case of an asymmetric oligopoly does not extend to closed-loop strategies. Keywords include cartel-fringe, nonrenewable resources, and dynamic games.

This work is crucial for assessing environmental impacts at local scales.

title: Informality, Trade Policies And Smuggling In West Africa
abstract: In West Africa, recorded intra-regional trade is small but informal cross-border trade (ICBT) is pervasive, despite regional integration schemes intended to promote official trade. We argue that ICBT must be understood in light of two features of West African national boundaries: divergent economic policies between neighboring countries and the ease with which informal operators can ship goods across borders. We focus on two ICBT clusters: Senegal–The Gambia and Nigeria–Benin–Togo. Nigeria and Senegal have protected their domestic industries with high import barriers, whereas Benin, Togo and The Gambia have maintained lower import taxation. These differential trade policies, together with high mobility of goods and people across borders, lead to widespread smuggling, with goods imported legally in low-tax countries and re-exported unofficially to countries with higher import duties
summary:
This paper investigates the prevalence of informal cross-border trade (ICBT) in West Africa, despite regional integration efforts. The authors argue that ICBT is driven by divergent economic policies, specifically import barriers, between neighboring countries and the ease of cross-border movement for goods and people. Focusing on the Senegal
The Gambia and Nigeria
Benin
Togo clusters, the study reveals widespread smuggling where goods are legally imported into low-tax countries and unofficially re-exported to higher-tax nations. This research offers insights into trade policies, informal economies, and economic disparities in West Africa.

title: Financial Regulation in a Changing World: Lessons from the Recent Crisis
abstract: The current crisis is leading many to re-think the role of finance and how it snew. This paper reviews what was regarded as the conventional wisdom on financial regulation prior to the 2007 onset of the crisis, briefly recounts some of the main factors behind the events of the 2007-09 years, and then turns to lessons for regulatory reform. At some point in the 1990s, the financial systems of high-income countries seemed to be functioning well and withstood some significant shocks, yet by 2007 much had changed. However, the regulatory structure did not change in response, and in fact eased in such a way as to exacerbate the instability that was subsequently experienced. A key theme is that financial regulation needs to be more dynamic, taking account of financial innovations and how they affect the sector. No such approach to regulation seems possible without greater accountability for regulators and attention to the incentives for those in the sector and for those who regulate it.Financial crisis, Securitization, Regulation and Supervision, Safety Nets
fieldOfStudy: Business, Financial Crisis, Securitization, Regulation and Supervision, Safety Nets
summary: This paper examines the conventional wisdom on financial regulation prior to the 2007 crisis, analyzes the factors contributing to the 2007-09 financial events, and derives lessons for regulatory reform. It highlights that while financial systems in high-income countries appeared robust in the 1990s, the subsequent lack of dynamic regulatory adaptation to financial innovations exacerbated instability. The study emphasizes the need for more adaptable financial regulation, increased accountability for regulators, and attention to incentives within the financial sector and its oversight. Key themes include financial crisis, securitization, and safety nets.

title: Contracts, Hold-Up, and Exports: Textiles and Opium in Colonial India
abstract: Trade and export, it is argued, spur economic growth. This paper studies the microeconomics of exporting. We build a heuristic model of transactions between exporters and producers and relate it to East India Company operations in colonial Bengal. Our model and the historical record stress two difficulties: the exporter and its agents might not uphold pricing agreements, and producers might not honor sales contracts. The model shows when procurement succeeds or fails, highlighting the tension between these two hold-up problems. We analyze several cases including the East India Company's textile venture, the famous Opium Monopoly, and present-day contract farming.
summary: This paper investigates the microeconomics of exporting, proposing a heuristic model of transactions between exporters and producers. The study relates this model to historical East India Company operations in colonial Bengal, highlighting two key hold-up problems: exporters failing to uphold pricing agreements and producers not honoring sales contracts. The model clarifies conditions under which procurement succeeds or fails, focusing on the tension between these issues. Several case studies are analyzed, including the East India Company’s textile ventures, the Opium Monopoly, and modern-day contract farming, offering insights into trade and economic growth.

title: The Economics of Sportsmanship
abstract: Cheaters never win and winners never cheat. Most children have heard this simple admonition at some point. It is truly unfortunate that it is not true. Sometimes athletes cheat and win, at least for a while. But it is rarely a good long-term strategy. And given the desire to win evident in athletes at all levels, maybe we should not be surprised at the occasional act of cheating, but rather at the rampant cooperation and sportsmanship that in fact transpires each day in professional sports stadium, high school and college facilities, and parks and sandlots across America. In this essay, we will use the tools of economics to examine and explain this epidemic of sportsmanship and good behavior
summary: This essay employs economic tools to analyze and explain the prevalence of sportsmanship and good behavior in professional and amateur sports, despite the common perception that athletes frequently cheat to win. It challenges the adage "cheaters never win," acknowledging that some athletes do cheat and succeed, at least temporarily. However, the paper argues that cheating is rarely a good long-term strategy, and it highlights the surprisingly rampant cooperation and ethical conduct observed daily across various sports levels, from professional stadiums to local parks. The study explores the underlying economic incentives and disincentives that shape player behavior.

title: Transportation Economics
fieldOfStudy: Business economics, transportation economics, airline management
summary: This paper investigates the drastic decline in domestic trunk airline profits post-1959 jet service introduction, which prompted complaints about CAB-induced over-competition and passenger traffic slowdown. Robert J. Gordon challenges the assumption that lower profits were solely due to revenue decline relative to costs, instead exploring the possibility of unnecessarily high costs and intercarrier variations in average cost. The study systematically analyzes management efficiency as a factor beyond traditional economic scope, highlighting its impact on performance and advocating for continuous data generation for rate-making cases. The author suggests price competition as a mechanism to reflect management efficiency in transportation economics.

abstract: Agribusiness, Agricultural and Food Policy, Consumer/Household Economics, Land Economics/Use,
