title: HEALTH AND HEALTH ECONOMICS: A CONCEPTUAL FRAMEWORK
abstract: Over the last three decades, treating health economics as an independent scientific discipline and providing specific treatment to the topics related to the economics of the health care sector have become more and more common. Currently, the field is so well established that it has appeared in the ordinary curriculum of most universities, and even if health economists are mainly to be found in the medical departments, the connections to economics proper are being strengthened, and the methodologies applied are getting refined. In this connection the paper highlights about the concept of health, why does health matter, relationship between health and Health Economics, and the justification of health economics.Health and Health Economics
summary: This paper highlights the increasing importance and establishment of health economics as an independent scientific discipline. It explores the conceptual framework of health, emphasizing its multifaceted nature beyond the mere absence of disease, and discusses why health matters. The authors delve into the intricate relationship between health and health economics, providing justification for this specialized field. Key methods involve defining health from a practical viewpoint using metrics like life expectancy and infant mortality. The study aims to strengthen connections between medical departments and broader economic methodologies, refining applied approaches within health economics.

title: A consumer's guide to regional economic multipliers
abstract: Regional economics ; Multiplier (Economics)
summary: This article provides a consumer's guide to regional economic multipliers, which are used to estimate the economic effects of significant changes in a region's economy, such as major construction projects or manufacturing facility closures. The authors explain how these multipliers calculate changes in output, income, and employment resulting from initial spending shifts. Using a hypothetical example of a decline in aircraft sales, the paper illustrates how a $50 million reduction could lead to a $132 million output decrease and 1,130 job losses in a local economy. The text also delves into the structure of input-output models, distinguishing between open and closed models concerning the household sector.

title: Conceptions of Individual Rights and Freedom in Welfare Economics: A Re-examination
abstract: This paper examines the literature in welfare economics with a focus on individual rights and freedom, two important components in welfare economics. The paper discusses conceptions of rights and freedom intuitively and presents a critical examination of the existing literature. Working Paper 07-3
publisher: Department of Economics in the Andrew Young School of Policy Studies
summary: This paper re-examines the literature in welfare economics, focusing on the fundamental concepts of individual rights and freedom. It provides an intuitive discussion of various conceptions of rights and freedom and critically analyzes existing scholarly work in this domain. The study aims to clarify theoretical understandings and identifies key issues for further research in normative economics and social welfare evaluations, particularly concerning the ethical implications of individual choice and societal policies. Keywords: welfare economics, individual rights, freedom, normative economics, social choice.

title: In the field:Coase an exemplar in the tradition of Smith, Marshall and Ostrom
abstract: This paper argues that Coase provides the primary 20th century exemplar of the grounding of analytical developments in economics in direct fieldwork observation. In particular, his focus on the business enterprise, its internal functions (including decision-making), and its external relations (including contracting) has provided a stimulus for radical developments in microeconomics and in managerial and decision economics in particular. The argument is developed by a stylization of the development of economics, referring to Adam Smith in the 18th century, Alfred Marshall in the 19th century, Ronald Coase in the 20th century, and Elinor Ostrom in the 21st century
summary: This paper argues that Ronald Coase represents the 20th-century ideal for grounding economic analytical developments in direct fieldwork observation. His research on business enterprises, including their internal functions and external relations like contracting, significantly spurred advancements in microeconomics, particularly managerial and decision economics. The argument traces this tradition from Adam Smith and Alfred Marshall to Coase and Elinor Ostrom, highlighting the importance of empirical observation in shaping economic theory and providing a framework for understanding organizational economics and transaction costs.

title: Integration of all FSSIM components within SEAMLESS-IF and a stand alone Graphical User Interface for FSSIM
abstract: Agricultural and Food Policy, Environmental Economics and Policy, Farm Management, Land Economics/Use,
fieldOfStudy: Business, Agricultural and Food Policy, Environmental Economics and Policy, Farm Management, Land Economics/Use
summary: This report details the integration of all Farming Systems SIMulator (FSSIM) components within the SEAMLESS-IF framework and the development of a standalone Graphical User Interface for FSSIM. The SEAMLESS integrated project aims to create a multi-scale, generic, modular, and open framework for ex-ante assessment of agricultural and environmental policies and technological innovations, spanning from field to EU25 and global levels. Key components like FSSIM-AM (Agricultural Management) and FSSIM-MP (Mathematical Programming Model) are described, facilitating the evaluation of production techniques and resource constraints. The project involves 30 partners led by Wageningen University.

title: The Status of Women Economists in the U.S. — and the World
abstract: This paper gives an overview of the current (and recent past) status of women economists in the United States and describes what American economists have done to promote gender equality in the economics profession. Initiatives include in large part what the American Economic Association, through its Committee on the Status of Women in the Economics Profession has done. It also discusses the creation and subsequent activities of the International Association for Feminist Economics and the activities of several other groups and committees recently formed in other parts of the world. It closes by considering what needs to be done worldwide to improve the status and increase the participation of women in the economics profession.academic labor markets, economics profession, women in economics
summary: This paper provides an overview of the status of women economists in the United States, detailing initiatives by American economists, particularly the American Economic Association's Committee on the Status of Women in the Economics Profession, to promote gender equality. It also examines the creation and activities of the International Association for Feminist Economics and other global groups. The discussion concludes with recommendations for worldwide improvements in the status and participation of women in the economics profession, addressing academic labor markets and the economics profession itself.

title: OILSEED ECONOMICS
abstract: Crop Production/Industries,
summary: This staff paper, "Oilseed Economics," by Rich Alderfer and Bill Lazarus, explores the economic implications and opportunities presented by changes in U.S. farm policy, specifically the 1990 Farm Bill. It focuses on the increased interest in alternative crops like canola, oil-type sunflowers, and soybeans on "flex acres." The authors analyze the profitability of these oilseeds, considering factors such as price, yield, and crush value. The paper provides methods for calculating returns and discusses future considerations, including crop breeding improvements, new varieties, and risk reduction for producers, offering insights for agricultural economics and crop production.

title: Starting life in Scotland in the new millennium : population replacement and the reproduction of disadvantage
abstract: Scotland, in line with the rest of Europe, is experiencing low rates of child-bearing and its population is ageing. This does not necessarily mean that people in Scotland are going grey at a faster rate than they used to. Rather, it means that there is an increasing proportion of elderly people in its population, with more people who are growing old than are growing up. The "birth dearth" and "population greying" are not unconnected: low fertility is the key influence on the age structure of a population as well as the rate of population growth
summary: This report examines the demographic challenges facing Scotland, specifically addressing the phenomena of low child-bearing rates and an ageing population, which are consistent with trends across Europe. The study highlights that low fertility is a primary driver of changes in population age structure and growth rates. It implicitly aims to analyze the implications of these demographic shifts for societal well-being and potentially for policy-making. Keywords: Scotland, demography, population ageing, low fertility, birth dearth, population growth, social policy.

title: Reform and Growth in Latin America: All Pain, No Gain?
abstract: This paper addresses the adequacy of post-reform growth in Latin America in the 1990s on the basis of international comparisons as well as historical and other relevant standards, analytically exploring and empirically testing a number of hypotheses to explain the perceived dissatisfaction with growth performance in the region. We find that there is no Â“growth puzzleÂ” in Latin America. Growth has not been higher in the post-reform period not because of a failure of reforms to yield the growth payoff that they should have been expected to do on the basis of international experience, but because of the combination of an unfavorable external environment with insufficient depth and breadth of reform. We also estimate the long-run growth payoff of macroeconomic reforms, the additional gains that can be achieved by deepening this first generation of reforms, and the potential payoff from broadening the scope of reform into a second generation of reforms encompassing deeper structural and institutional areas.
summary: This paper analyzes the adequacy of post-reform economic growth in Latin America during the 1990s, using international and historical comparisons. It explores various hypotheses to explain dissatisfaction with the region's growth performance, concluding there is no "growth puzzle." The study finds that growth was not higher due to an unfavorable external environment and insufficient depth/breadth of reforms, rather than a failure of reforms themselves. The authors estimate the long-run growth payoff of macroeconomic reforms, potential gains from deepening first-generation reforms, and the benefits of broadening to second-generation structural and institutional reforms, providing insights into economic policy and development.

title: Climate Change, Markets, and Technology
abstract: Environmental Economics and Policy, Resource /Energy Economics and Policy, Q15, Q25, Q38,
fieldOfStudy: Business Economics, Resource Economics, Environmental Economics and Policy
summary: This study examines the impacts of climate change on irrigated agriculture in arid regions, using California as a case study. It focuses on increased water scarcity, greater water supply variation, and reduced yields due to heat stress, driven by rising temperatures. The authors suggest that technological advancements and market changes can partially or entirely offset these negative effects. Key methods include analyzing forecast reductions in irrigation water supplies and observing historical technological impacts on crop yields. This research offers insights into adaptation strategies for climate change in similar arid, post-industrial agricultural economies, particularly regarding water management.

title: On information efficiency and financial stability
abstract:
We study a simple model of an asset market with informed and non-informed
agents. In the absence of non-informed agents, the market becomes information
efficient when the number of traders with different private information is
large enough. Upon introducing non-informed agents, we find that the latter
contribute significantly to the trading activity if and only if the market is
(nearly) information efficient. This suggests that information efficiency might
be a necessary condition for bubble phenomena, induced by the behavior of
non-informed traders, or conversely that throwing some sands in the gears of
financial markets may curb the occurrence of bubbles.Comment: 14 pages, 2 figure
summary: This study examines a simple asset market model with informed and non-informed agents to understand information efficiency and financial stability. It finds that without non-informed agents, the market achieves information efficiency when there are sufficient traders with diverse private information. Crucially, the introduction of non-informed agents significantly increases trading activity only if the market is already information efficient. This suggests that information efficiency may be a prerequisite for bubble phenomena driven by non-informed traders, or conversely, that measures to impede financial market mechanisms could reduce bubbles. Key concepts include asset markets, information efficiency, non-informed agents, trading activity, and bubble phenomena.

title: Changes in the Academic Labor Market for Economists
abstract: [Excerpt] American colleges and universities are increasingly substituting non-tenure track full-time and part-time faculty for full-time tenured and tenure track faculty. Moreover, institutions of public higher education, where almost two-thirds of the full-time faculty members at four-year institutions are employed, are under severe financial pressure. The share of state budgets devoted to public higher education is declining. The salaries of economics department faculty members at public higher education institutions have fallen substantially relative to the salaries of their counterparts at private higher education institutions and it is becoming increasingly difficult for the publics to compete for top faculty in economics. Moreover, it is at the economics departments in public institutions where the greatest increase in the usage of non-tenure track faculty has also occurred.   This article begins by presenting levels of Ph.D. production, and then discusses factors determining demand for economics departments, differences between public and private universities, and the range of pay between departments within universities
summary: This article examines the evolving academic labor market for economists, focusing on the increasing substitution of non-tenure track faculty for tenured positions, particularly in public higher education institutions facing severe financial pressure. It discusses the decline in state budgets for public universities, leading to a substantial drop in economics faculty salaries relative to private institutions, making it harder to attract top talent. The study presents Ph.D. production levels, analyzes factors influencing demand for economics departments, and compares pay structures between public and private universities. Key findings indicate a growing reliance on non-tenure track faculty in public economics departments.

title: What is Behavioural Economics Like?
abstract: Behavioural Economics’ milestones, Endowment Effect and Loss Aversion, have been recognized as ‘well documented,’ ‘robust,’ and ‘important’ even by the critics. But well documented, robust, and important what? Are these stylized facts, theoretical constructs, or psychological truths? Do they express genuine preferences or are they judgement mistakes? We discuss the problems with the nature of these claims in the lights of the goals of Behavioural Economics: to improve economics’ realisticness and to be considered mainstream. We argue that, under sensible interpretations of Loss Aversion and Endowment Effect, Behavioural Economics is neither more realistic than, nor part of the mainstream.Behavioural Economics, Decision-Making, Endowment Effect, Loss Aversion, Uncertainty
fieldOfStudy: Business, Behavioural Economics, Decision Making, Endowment Effect, Loss Aversion, Uncertainty
summary: This paper critically examines the foundational concepts of Behavioural Economics, specifically the Endowment Effect and Loss Aversion, which are often cited as robust and important. The authors discuss the inherent problems with the nature of these claims, questioning whether they represent stylized facts, theoretical constructs, or genuine psychological truths. The study argues that, under reasonable interpretations, Behavioural Economics, despite its goals of improving realism and achieving mainstream acceptance, is neither more realistic than traditional economics nor has it successfully integrated into the mainstream. Key concepts explored include Decision-Making and Uncertainty within the Behavioural Economics framework.

title: Professionalisation of Australian Agricultural Economics: 1920 - 1970
abstract: Australian agricultural economics was on the verge of professional recognition at the beginning of the 1950s. The discipline had emerged from the Second World War in a strong position due primarily to the work of the State Departments of Agriculture, the Economics Departments of the banks, and the pioneering efforts of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. Agricultural economics as a field of study was being taken up by economics and agricultural science students alike, and research projects in agricultural economics were burgeoning. This paper investigates the factors which contributed to the professionalisation of agricultural economics in Australia after the Second World War. All vocations aspire to professional status but, even when it does receive professional recognition, a vocation is often still questioned regarding the legitimacy of that status. It is therefore significant to explore the origins and evolution of the agricultural economics profession in order to discover the reasons why it came into existence and the process by which the professionalisation occurred. The changed economic environment during and after the Second World War meant that agricultural economists were given opportunities to present a convincing case to pursue the professionalisation of their discipline. The distinguishing and overruling characteristic of a profession is the possession of specialized knowledge which has been acquired as a result of prolonged training. The knowledge is intellectual and based on the exploration of a recognized field of study. The way in which this knowledge is obtained is an important part of the professionalisation process. This paper identifies the economists and scientists who established the discipline of agricultural economics in Australian universities and set it on the path to professionalisation. The second most important aspect of professionalisation is the formation of a professional society for members and the development of a professional journal to disseminate research and other general information to members. The formation of the professional organisation associated with agricultural economics in Australia is examined in this paper. Australian agricultural economics was at the peak of its influence in the 1970s. All the mainland universities had at least one professor of agricultural economics, there was a strong professional association, annual conferences, and bi-annual outlook conferences, and three separate professional journals were in publication. The value of the agricultural economics profession was widely accepted throughout the policy community.Teaching/Communication/Extension/Profession,
summary: This paper investigates the professionalisation of Australian agricultural economics between 1920 and 1970, exploring the factors that contributed to its emergence and recognition after the Second World War. It details how the discipline, initially supported by state departments, banks, and the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, gained professional status by establishing specialized knowledge, academic programs in universities, and professional societies and journals. The study identifies key economists and scientists who shaped the field, highlighting its peak influence in the 1970s with widespread acceptance within the policy community and robust institutional support. Keywords include agricultural economics, professionalisation, Australia, post-WWII, academic development, professional societies.

title: The Impact of Biofuels Crop and Land Rental Markets on Farm Household Incomes: Evidence from South Africa
abstract: Consumer/Household Economics, Land Economics/Use,
summary: This study examines the impact of biofuels crop and land rental markets on rural farm household incomes in South Africa, a relatively new and controversial phenomenon in Sub-Saharan Africa. The research aims to determine if biofuels investments, often by foreign firms, benefit smallholder farmers or are merely exploitative. Utilizing detailed household survey data, the paper employs an endogenous switching regression model to analyze participation decisions and income effects. Key findings indicate that involvement in these markets has varied impacts on household wellbeing and cash income, highlighting the complex economic dynamics for smallholder farmers in the context of biofuels expansion.

title: Private provision of rural infrastructure services: competing for subsidies
abstract: Market-oriented reforms of infrastructure in developing countries tend to focus primarily on commercially viable services in urban areas. Nevertheless, an increasing number of countries are beginning to experiment with extending the market paradigm to infrastructure services in rural areas that are often less attractive in commercial terms. In these cases, subsidies are used to close the gap between market requirements and development needs, and are increasingly determined and allocated on a competitive basis. The authors discuss the conditions under which competition among firms for such subsidies-successfully used in the telecommunications sector in a number of middle-income countries-could also be applied to electricity, water and sanitation, and transportation services in lower-income countries.Health Economics&Finance,Environmental Economics&Policies,Public Sector Economics&Finance,Decentralization,ICT Policy and Strategies,Health Economics&Finance,Environmental Economics&Policies,Public Sector Economics&Finance,Town Water Supply and Sanitation,ICT Policy and Strategies
fieldOfStudy: Business, Health Economics & Finance, Environmental Economics & Policies, Public Sector Economics & Finance, Decentralization, ICT Policy and Strategies, Town Water Supply and Sanitation
summary: This paper examines extending market-oriented reforms to rural infrastructure services in developing countries, moving beyond the usual focus on urban, commercially viable services. The authors investigate how competitive allocation of subsidies, successfully used in telecommunications in middle-income nations, could bridge the gap between market requirements and development needs for services like electricity, water, sanitation, and transportation in lower-income countries. This approach addresses the commercial unattractiveness of rural services and proposes a mechanism for efficient subsidy utilization to foster development.

title: From tools to theories: The emergence of modern financial economics
abstract: It is shown that early research in modern financial economics had substantially been driven by the application of the research strategy of economics and the use of newly developed mathematical methods. For this purpose the professionalization of business education as a consequence of changes in the U.S. economy after Word War II is presented. The emergence of professional Journals in financial economics, similar to the academic culture including the trend of applying abstract mathematical reasoning and during the war developed methods like linear programming are highlighted. Also the meaning of Milton Friedman's 1953 essay The Methodology of Positive Economics for the dominance of abstract and prediction driven research in modern financial economics gets discussed. Finally, the emergence of Harry Markowitz's paper Portfolio Selection (1952) is used to substantiate the hypothesis. --history of finance,portfolio theory,business schools,modern financial economics,modelling,theories of modern financial economics,risk management,positivism,professionalization,methodology of finance
summary: This paper examines how early modern financial economics was shaped by the research strategies of economics and new mathematical methods. It highlights the professionalization of business education in post-WWII U.S., the rise of professional journals, and the influence of abstract mathematical reasoning and wartime-developed methods like linear programming. The essay discusses Milton Friedman's 1953 essay "The Methodology of Positive Economics" and Harry Markowitz's 1952 paper "Portfolio Selection" to support the hypothesis that abstract, prediction-driven research became dominant. Keywords include history of finance, portfolio theory, business schools, modelling, risk management, and positivism.

title: The Economists of Tomorrow
abstract: This paper is a prepublication version of a submission to the International Review of Economics Education. It outlines a code of conduct for economics, in the form of a pluralist benchmark for Quality Assurance in economics education. This is a necessary corrective to the publicly-recognised failure of economics in the face of the 2008 crisis, which Colander et al (2009 term its “systemic failure”. This systemic failure is analysed as a consequence of the regulatory capture of the academic profession of economics, arising from and institutionalised by its present peer ranking procedures. Pluralism is the necessary antidote. It affords two decisive benefits: it produces good economics and better economists. The paper is part of a broad consultation on teaching in economics, organised by the UK-based Association for Heterodox Economists (AHE). It argues that a pluralist subject benchmark, derived from a pluralist code of conduct, is a prerequisite for the reform of the profession. Critical, pluralistic and independent thinking should be the primary requirement good economic practice, and pecific provisions should be made to recognise, promote, defend and guarantee this good practice in teaching and assessment alike. Systemic failure requires a systemic solution. The paper explains how the built-in tendency of the economic profession to select for conformity has led to its regulatory capture. Existing UK benchmarks have substituted peer-ranking – the appointment of judges selected for comformity – for collaborative peer review – the pluralistic integration of the strengths of the academic community. This past practice has become institutionalised at every level. The profoundly non-scientific practice of simply reproducing a politically acceptable consensus has thereby replaced the independent and critical pursuit of knowledge as the primary peer-recognised hallmark of quality. Tomorrow’s economists need to be defended against the systemic failure of the economics of today. This requires a conscious regulatory intervention – benchmarking for pluralism.Economics Teaching, Pluralism, Heterodox Economics
fieldOfStudy: Business, Economics Teaching, Pluralism, Heterodox Economics
summary: This paper proposes a code of conduct for economics, advocating for a pluralist benchmark in Quality Assurance for economics education. This initiative responds to the "systemic failure" of economics, particularly its inability to anticipate the 2008 crisis, attributed to regulatory capture within the academic profession. The authors argue that pluralism fosters better economics and economists, emphasizing critical, independent thinking as essential for good economic practice. The paper, part of a consultation by the Association for Heterodox Economists, highlights how existing peer-ranking systems reinforce conformity, replacing critical knowledge pursuit with politically acceptable consensus. It calls for conscious regulatory intervention to promote pluralism and protect future economists from systemic failures.

title: Transportation Economics
summary: This introduction to "Transportation Economics" evaluates the state of transportation economics as a profession, noting a revival of professional interest after a period of abeyance from approximately 1930 to the mid-1950s, when macroeconomic problems dominated. The text highlights a shift in focus back to microeconomic issues like transportation. It sets the stage for a conference on the subject, acknowledging contributions from key individuals and outlining several papers not included in the volume, covering topics such as costs of private carriage, military airlift, spatial economic structure, transportation and development, and transportation planning in underdeveloped countries.

title: Liquidity constraints on consumption: the real effects of "real" lending policies
abstract: Consumption (Economics) ; Income ; Credit ; Liquidity (Economics)
summary: This article investigates the hypothesis that households frequently face constraints on consumption, preventing them from spending as much as their permanent income would justify. It specifically argues that lending criteria based on payment-to-income ratios can inappropriately restrict borrowing and, consequently, consumption. The study finds that variables used to proxy for payments (nominal interest rate) and income (unemployment rate) significantly influence consumption growth, supporting the proposed hypothesis. In contrast, real interest rates show little impact on consumption. This research is relevant for understanding economic consumption, credit, and liquidity constraints.

title: Economic Impact of the Conservation Reserve Program in North Dakota
abstract: Environmental Economics and Policy, Land Economics/Use,
fieldOfStudy: Environmental Economics and Policy, Land Economics/Use, Business
summary: This report examines the economic impact of the Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) in North Dakota, focusing on its effects on agricultural economics and land use. The study quantifies the economic benefits and costs associated with the CRP, analyzing factors such as land values, agricultural production, and regional economic activity. It provides an assessment of how the program has influenced the state's economy, offering insights into policy implications for land conservation and rural development. Key findings include an analysis of sales for final demand by pool group, providing detailed economic data from 1980 to 1987.

title: Future Land Use Decisions of North Dakota Conservation Reserve Program Participants
abstract: Environmental Economics and Policy, Land Economics/Use,
fieldOfStudy: Environmental Economics and Policy, Land Economics/Use, Agricultural Economics
summary: This report investigates the future land use decisions of North Dakota Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) participants. The study aims to understand factors influencing their choices regarding land enrollment or removal from the CRP program, particularly in response to potential changes in rental payments. It explores the socioeconomic characteristics of participants and the history of U.S. conservation programs to provide context. The methodology includes a survey administered to CRP participants, gathering data on financial assets, debt, farm income, and their willingness to withdraw land at different rental rate reductions. The findings offer insights into agricultural economics and land-use policy.

title: Post Independence India's contribution to Islamic Economics
abstract: One of the most important themes to which Indian scholars have made pioneering contribution is the area of Islamic Economics. The present paper attempts to attempt to bring on the record postindependence India's contribution to Islamic economics.Islamic Economics; Indian Economics;
summary: This paper examines the main difficulties faced by the Islamic banking and finance movement in India, acknowledging that some obstacles may be common but are intensified by prevailing suspicion or indifference and a lack of executive power. It traces the modern history of Islamic banking in India back to early 20th-century debates on bank interest legitimacy, which led to a consensus on prohibition and the search for Islamic-principled alternatives. The purpose is to prompt scholars and business activists to devise solutions for these challenges, which hinder the establishment of full-fledged Islamic financial institutions in India.

title: Estimating Optimal Landfill Sizes and Locations in North Dakota
abstract: Resource /Energy Economics and Policy, Land Economics/Use,
fieldOfStudy: Business, Resource/Energy Economics and Policy, Land Economics/Use, Agricultural Economics
summary: This report, published in March 1993 by the Department of Agricultural Economics at North Dakota State University, aims to estimate optimal landfill sizes and locations in North Dakota. The study, financially supported by the Environmental Protection Agency, acknowledges contributions from the North Dakota State Department of Health and Consolidated Laboratories, as well as several editors and reviewers. It includes tables detailing land requirements, predevelopment, and construction costs for different-sized landfills in North Dakota in 1992. The document provides detailed economic data relevant to waste management and land use planning.

title: The Double Paradox of Elementary Economics Education
abstract: Elementary economics textbooks have become less attractive to students requiring only an introduction to economics, given that their content is pervaded by mathematical diagrams and simple equations. Also they are of relatively little value to those interested in, for example, attempting to gain an understanding of the New Economy, for they rarely emphasise business innovation and its crucial dynamic role. These factors engender something of a double paradox. First (paradox of the tools and the audience), newcomers are frequently 'turned off' by existing economics textbooks due to the pervasive use of mathematics. Second (paradox of the content and relevance), those newcomers who are not initially turned off tend to be disenchanted with economics because they perceive that economics is of little use in understanding the New Economy in which they work, or will come to work. We suggest an integrated solution to both paradoxes. The implementation entails a minor reorientation of the traditional pedagogical strategy for teaching introductory economics.Double paradox, elementary economics education
summary: This paper addresses a "double paradox" in elementary economics education: students are deterred by pervasive mathematics in textbooks, and those who persist find the content irrelevant to understanding the "New Economy" and business innovation. The authors propose an integrated solution involving a minor reorientation of traditional pedagogical strategies for introductory economics. They argue that neglecting business innovation's dynamic role, despite its economic significance and inspiration for modern growth models, contributes to this disconnect. The study highlights issues with current teaching methods and textbook content in economics education.

title: An Institutional Analysis of European Systems for Impact Assessment
abstract: Agricultural and Food Policy, Environmental Economics and Policy, Farm Management, Land Economics/Use,
fieldOfStudy: Business, Agricultural and Food Policy, Environmental Economics and Policy, Farm Management, Land Economics/Use
summary: This report details the SEAMLESS integrated project, aiming to develop a multi-scale framework for ex-ante assessment of agricultural and environmental policies and technological innovations. The framework, designed to be generic, modular, and open, will utilize state-of-the-art software and span from field to EU25 and global scales. Conducted by a consortium of 30 partners led by Wageningen University, the project focuses on integrated impact assessment systems in Europe, particularly for agricultural and environmental policy appraisal, and sustainable development.

title: A DECOMPOSITION APPROACH TO ASSESS ILUC RESULTS FROM GLOBAL MODELING EFFORTS
abstract: Environmental Economics and Policy, Resource /Energy Economics and Policy,
summary: This contributed paper at the IATRC Public Trade Policy Research and Analysis Symposium in 2010 proposes a decomposition approach to assess Indirect Land Use Change (ILUC) results from global modeling efforts. It discusses methodologies for comparing outputs from various global models, particularly focusing on the challenges of integrating and processing data from models like GTAP for consistent analysis. The research aims to harmonize data definitions and apply correction factors to facilitate comparisons of production, demand, and net trade results across different modeling frameworks, especially when comparing with partial equilibrium models that use physical units. The study highlights the need for extensive data processing to ensure comparability.

title: The Surf Clam ITQ Management: An Evaluation
abstract: Environmental Economics and Policy, Resource /Energy Economics and Policy,
fieldOfStudy: Business, Environmental Economics and Policy, Resource/Energy Economics and Policy
summary: This evaluation assesses the U.S. surf clam offshore fishery's management under individual transferable quota (ITQ) systems and limited entry from 1977. Facing over-exploitation and natural disaster, federal management aimed to curb declining biomass and over-capitalization. Initial limited entry, including vessel moratoriums and catch quotas, proved insufficient to address inefficiency caused by increasing vessel sizes and fishing gear. The subsequent ITQ system, implemented from 1990, allowed market mechanisms to reduce capital utilization and enhance economic efficiency. Within two years, the fleet size decreased by 54%, and vessel capacity utilization and productivity significantly improved, generating $11.4 million in resource rent for vessel owners by 1992. The study highlights the effectiveness of ITQs in achieving economic efficiency and sustainable resource management.

title: Fiscal and trade distorting effects of capital gains tax on land sales - empirical evidence from agricultural land market in Finland
abstract: capital gains, taxes, land, trade, fiscal effects, Agricultural Finance, Financial Economics, Land Economics/Use,
fieldOfStudy: Business, Agricultural Finance, Financial Economics, Land Economics/Use
summary: This study examines the fiscal and trade-distorting effects of capital gains tax on agricultural land sales in Finland, focusing on the "lock-in" effect where taxes discourage land transactions. The research highlights how this effect can lead to a deviation between land ownership and active farming, increasing land tenancy and tenure insecurity, which in turn incurs social costs by delaying necessary land improvements. The paper aims to quantify the trade-off between capital gains tax levels, land sales, and fiscal revenues to inform optimal policy design. Keywords: capital gains tax, land sales, agricultural land market, Finland, lock-in effect, land tenancy, fiscal revenue.

title: A Management Agency Perspective of the Economics of Fisheries Regulation
abstract: Environmental Economics and Policy, Resource /Energy Economics and Policy,
fieldOfStudy: Business, Environmental Economics and Policy, Resource/Energy Economics and Policy, Marine Resource Economics
summary: This paper addresses the gap in rigorous analysis of how fisheries agencies can rationally manage fisheries, focusing on enforcement issues within an autonomous agency framework. While existing literature extensively covers fisheries management economics and the efficiency of various control types, the problem of selecting and optimally implementing a management regime under limited agency budgets, considering non-compliance, avoidance, and enforcement costs, has been largely unexplored. The study aims to fill this void by providing a general discussion of a management agency's perspective on the economics of fisheries regulation, emphasizing factors affecting economically efficient fishing levels and the relative efficiency of control types.

title: Veal calf industry economics
abstract:
This paper provides an outline of the veal industry, its standing relative to other cattle farming enterprises, and its future prospects. In 2008 some 20 per cent of bovines slaughtered in the EU were for veal production and

about one-third of them were dairy calves. France, the Netherlands and Italy were Europe’s leading producers. Veal consumption in the European Union has been in steady decline since 1970. In 2008, it averaged 1.6 kg per capita,

with France and Italy being the largest consumers. Despite variations in farming systems and carcass characteristics from one country to another, veal production is an important outlet for milk replacer producers and provides

a market for their industrial dairy products. Regular changes in production factors such as the price of 8-day-old calves and milk replacers and their availability engender recurrent output fluctuations. Veal calf production

plays a major part in regulating the milk and bovine-meat markets: it has largely contributed to stemming dairy (and sometimes meat) surpluses. However, the context has changed since 2008 with no more surplus milk supply and reduced EU-support for incorporating skimmed milk powder into milk feeds. Therefore, the relative attractiveness of other productions using 8-day-old calves and the support policies for cattle farming as a whole will affect the future of the veal calf industry
summary: This paper outlines the veal industry, its position within cattle farming, and future prospects. In 2008, veal production accounted for 20% of bovines slaughtered in the EU, with France, Netherlands, and Italy as leading producers. Veal consumption has declined since 1970, averaging 1.6 kg per capita in 2008. The industry serves as a crucial market for milk replacer producers. Fluctuations in calf and milk replacer prices impact output. Veal calf production regulates milk and bovine-meat markets, historically stemming surpluses. However, post-2008 changes, including the absence of surplus milk supply and reduced EU support, will influence the industry's future viability and competitiveness against alternative uses for 8-day-old calves.

title: Incentives for Spatially Coordinated Land Conservation: A Conditional Agglomeration Bonus
abstract: Environmental Economics and Policy, Land Economics/Use,
fieldOfStudy: Business, Economics, Land Use, Environmental Policy
summary: This study introduces a conditional agglomeration bonus as an incentive mechanism for spatially coordinated land conservation. Focusing on programs like the USDA's Conservation Reserve Program (CRP), which involves billions in annual expenditures, the research addresses the challenge of achieving environmental benefits that often require contiguous conservation efforts. It highlights that the marginal benefit of conservation can be minimal until a certain spatial threshold is met, such as for species habitat viability. The paper likely explores economic models and policy implications for optimizing conservation fund allocation to maximize environmental outcomes through coordinated land use. Keywords: land conservation, agglomeration bonus, Conservation Reserve Program, environmental economics, spatial coordination, habitat conservation.

title: Using Land Values to Predict Future Farm Income
abstract: land values, almon lag, farm profitability, Agribusiness, Agricultural Finance, Farm Management, Financial Economics, Production Economics,
fieldOfStudy: Business, Agribusiness, Agricultural Finance, Farm Management, Financial Economics, Production Economics
summary: This paper investigates the relationship between agricultural land values and future farm income, aiming to explain and predict earnings. It builds on previous agricultural finance research that analyzed land prices based on simultaneous movements with cash flow measures like land rents or income per acre. The study employs increasingly sophisticated models, including those that integrate spatial correlation and examine lagged returns to define real asset values, to understand and predict future agricultural earnings. The findings are intended to inform agricultural policy, specifically to help reduce the volatility of agricultural asset prices, using current prices to predict future income. Key methods include Almon lag models and regression analysis (OLS, RLS, RGMM).

title: Economics of nuclear energy
abstract: While few people now believe that nuclear power would provide ‘power too cheap to meter’, there is still a common perception that nuclear power is a cheap source of electricity. The fact that nuclear power has not come to dominate electricity generation is seen as being due to a combination of public opposition and dealing with the safety issues raised by accidents such as those at Three Mile Island (1978), Chernobyl (1986) and Fukushima (2011). The reality is that nuclear power has seldom been the cheapest option for new power stations. Worse, the real cost of any normal successful technology goes down over time due to the effect of intuitively sensible factors such as ‘learning-by-doing’, economies of scale and general technical progress. For nuclear power, these factors do not seem to have worked and for its entire commercial history, the real cost of nuclear power has only ever gone upwards. The Fukushima disaster can only give a further twist to this upward spiral. This paper examines the determinants of the cost of a kilowatt hour (kWh) of nuclear electricity; what the latest designs of nuclear power plant can offer; how new nuclear plants might be financed; and what issues will determine whether South Africa can successfully launch a new nuclear programme
summary: This paper critically examines the economics of nuclear energy, challenging the common perception of it being a cheap electricity source. It highlights that nuclear power has rarely been the most affordable option for new power stations, and unlike most technologies, its real costs have consistently increased throughout its commercial history, further exacerbated by incidents like Fukushima. The study investigates the determinants of nuclear electricity costs per kilowatt-hour, evaluates the offerings of the latest nuclear power plant designs, explores financing models for new plants, and considers the factors influencing the successful launch of a new nuclear program in South Africa. Key themes include energy economics, cost analysis, nuclear technology, and financing.

title: Farmer Participation in the Conservation Reserve Program and Bio-fuel Production under Uncertainty and Irreversibility
abstract: Crop Production/Industries, Land Economics/Use, Resource /Energy Economics and Policy,
fieldOfStudy: Business, Crop Production Industries, Land Economics Use, Resource Energy Economics and Policy
summary: This study examines farmer participation in the Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) and bio-fuel production, considering uncertainty and irreversibility. It addresses the crucial land-use choices farmers face after CRP contract expiration, particularly amidst increasing competition from energy crops. The research aims to inform the design of CRP contracts that effectively promote enrollment and re-enrollment. Preliminary numerical simulations, using data from Nebraska, investigate enrollment thresholds under varying subsidy levels and contract lengths (10 or 15 years), considering factors like fixed CRP rental payments, risk-free interest rates, and switchgrass return volatility. Key findings will guide policies to balance conservation and bio-fuel production.

title: Performing Economics: A Critique of 'Teaching and Learning'
abstract: Economics students find difficulty in developing effective learning strategies; they would also welcome and benefit from a more pluralistic teaching of economics. Nevertheless, economics teaching has become less pluralistic over the recent past. Recent benchmark statements seem content to underwrite an essentially monist approach to the discipline in the hope that a deepening crisis in economics teaching can be averted by expanding teaching and learning programmes taking the content of teaching as given and instead concentrating on presentational reform. The paper argues that such teaching and learning strategies are part of the problem rather than its solution.
summary: This paper critically examines current teaching and learning strategies in economics, arguing they exacerbate rather than solve difficulties students face and the increasing monism of the discipline. Despite students desiring and benefiting from more pluralistic approaches, economics teaching has become less diverse. Recent benchmark statements advocate for expanding programs and presentational reform, taking content as given, which the authors contend is problematic. The research challenges the prevailing assumption that teaching is merely a presentational issue, abstracting it from content. Keywords: economics education, pluralism, learning strategies, teaching reform, monist approach.

title: Anatomy of Stigmatized Behavior: Peer Influence and Relative Concern
abstract: This paper is based on an ongoing joint work with David Sahn and Xiaobo Zhang.Social Stigma, Peer Influences, Relative Concern, Blood Donation, China, Agricultural and Food Policy, Community/Rural/Urban Development, Consumer/Household Economics, Food Security and Poverty, Health Economics and Policy, Institutional and Behavioral Economics, International Development, Labor and Human Capital, Research Methods/ Statistical Methods, Risk and Uncertainty, JEL: I32, J22, D13, D63,
fieldOfStudy: Business, Social Stigma, Behavioral Economics, International Development, Health Economics and Policy
summary: This paper investigates the anatomy of stigmatized behavior, focusing on peer influence and relative concern beyond mere poverty. It highlights that even among the poor, not everyone engages in stigmatized activities, suggesting other underlying factors. The research explores how concern for social status shapes such behaviors, especially when the consequences of falling behind are severe. The study utilizes a household survey and gift network data to define reference groups and measure relative deprivation using various indices, including Wildman and Deaton's. It also employs three strategies for identifying peer effects on behaviors like blood donation, using instrumental variables and spatial instruments derived from network structures.

title: Leaving the mainstream behind? Uncovering subjective understandings of economics instructors' roles
abstract: In the wake of the economic crisis, a number of student organizations and researchers highlighted the lack of pluralism and heterodox approaches in economics curricula. The relevance of pluralism becomes clear once set within the implications of a given scientific discourse on reality (e.g. economics and policy making). This study explores the role of instructors in co-constructing the pluralism discourse and debates, while recognizing the role of institutional obstacles to change within the discipline. An empirical field study is conducted with lecturers in introductory economics courses at the WU Vienna University of Economics and Business where they place themselves within the pluralism discourse via a Q-study - a mixed method employed for studying subjectivity in socially contested topics. In Q, a set of statements undergo a sorting procedure on a relative ranking scale, followed by factor-rendering. Four voices are identified: Moderate Pluralist, Mainstreamers, Responsible Pluralists, and Applied Pluralists. The implications of their ideas are discussed from the viewpoint of discursive institutionalism, stressing the role of ideas and discourse in institutional change. Although a discursive readiness for changes towards more pluralism is claimed, strategies for overcoming the difficulties on the institutional level need to be developed
summary: This study investigates the discourse on pluralism and heterodox approaches in economics curricula, prompted by concerns following the economic crisis. Utilizing a Q-study methodology with lecturers at WU Vienna University of Economics and Business, the research explores instructors' subjective understandings of their roles in fostering pluralism. Four distinct perspectives emerged: Moderate Pluralist, Mainstreamers, Responsible Pluralists, and Applied Pluralists. The findings are discussed through the lens of discursive institutionalism, highlighting the influence of ideas and discourse on institutional change. While a readiness for increased pluralism is evident, the study emphasizes the need for strategies to overcome institutional barriers to change.

title: Forest resources and rural livelihoods in the north-central regions of Namibia
abstract: Economics, Forestry, Markets, Community/Rural/Urban Development, Environmental Economics and Policy,
fieldOfStudy: Business, Environmental Economics and Policy, Forestry, Markets, Community/Rural/Urban Development
summary: This discussion paper by James MacGregor, Charles Palmer, and Jonathan Barnes, published by the International Institute for Environment and Development (IIED) in September 2007, focuses on forest resources and rural livelihoods in north-central Namibia. The IIED's Environmental Economics Programme aims to apply economics to environmental issues in developing countries, conducting research and policy analysis on natural resources, economic development, and poverty alleviation. Key areas include the impact of economic policies on resource management, the economic value of natural resources, and policy incentives for internalizing environmental values in decision-making. The overarching theme is capacity building through collaborative research.

title: The major characteristics of environmental policies and agro-ecological technologies to be studied in Test case 2
abstract: Agricultural and Food Policy, Environmental Economics and Policy, Farm Management, Land Economics/Use,
fieldOfStudy: Business, Agricultural and Food Policy, Environmental Economics and Policy, Farm Management, Land Economics Use
summary: This report, part of the SEAMLESS integrated project (System for Environmental and Agricultural Modelling; Linking European Science and Society), details the major characteristics of environmental policies and agro-ecological technologies for 'Test case 2'. The SEAMLESS framework aims for ex-ante assessment of agricultural and environmental policies and technological innovations, offering multi-scale capabilities from field to EU25/global levels. It is designed to be generic, modular, and open, utilizing state-of-the-art software. Key areas of focus include land use optimization, pest control, soil fertility maintenance, and specific EU legislations regarding Natura 2000, nitrogen, pesticides, and water. The project involves 30 partners led by Wageningen University.

title: Review of approaches to establish reference levels to interpret indicators
abstract: Agricultural and Food Policy, Environmental Economics and Policy, Farm Management, Land Economics/Use,
fieldOfStudy: Business, Agricultural and Food Policy, Environmental Economics and Policy, Farm Management, Land Economics Use
summary: The SEAMLESS integrated project (EU FP 6, contract no. 010036) aims to develop a multi-scale, generic, modular, and open framework for ex-ante assessment of agricultural and environmental policies and technological innovations. This framework will operate from field to global levels, utilizing state-of-the-art software. The project involves 30 partners led by Wageningen University, focusing on integrating diverse scientific and societal perspectives. The report details a review of approaches to establish reference levels for interpreting indicators, crucial for assessing agroecosystem health and sustainability in agriculture. This initiative links European science and society to address global change and ecosystems.

title: THE EUROPEAN UNION’S FRAMEWORK FOR CLIMATE CHANGE ADAPTATION: IMPLICATIONS OF AGRICULTURE’S ADAPTATION THROUGH SUSTAINED YIELD GROWTH
abstract: Agricultural and Food Policy, Environmental Economics and Policy, Resource /Energy Economics and Policy,
fieldOfStudy: Agricultural and Food Policy, Environmental Economics and Policy, Resource/Energy Economics and Policy
summary: This paper examines the European Union's framework for climate change adaptation, specifically analyzing the implications of agriculture's adaptation through sustained yield growth. It investigates how agricultural policy and economic factors influence adaptive strategies within the context of global climate change, focusing on mitigation, trade, and food security. The research contributes to understanding the broader economic and policy challenges associated with climate impacts on agriculture and explores responses devised by governmental and nongovernmental organizations.

title: Capitalist Dynamics: A Technical Note
abstract: Carl Menger, the founder of the Austrian School of Economics, had the ambition that economics should be a .map of the forces at workÿ. Standard textbook economics (.neo-classical economicsÿ) takes as its starting point a metaphor of .equilibriumÿ based on the state of the physics profession in the 1880s. This force towards equilibrium is, however, only one of many forces at work. The most fundamental feature of capitalism is change, and this change is only poorly reflected in standard economics. Financial crises are just one of the many things that happen in real life, but cannot happen in standard textbook economics. From the standpoint of Joseph Alois Schumpeter (1883-1950), Austrian economist and Harvard economics professor who spent much time at Harvard Business School, .equilibriumÿ is the opposite of economic development. Equilibrium theory therefore fails to reflect many of the mechanisms of industrial and economic dynamics that create economic welfare. This note attempts to outline some of these forces.
summary: This technical note outlines various forces at work in capitalist dynamics, challenging the limitations of standard neo-classical economics, which often starts with an "equilibrium" metaphor. Drawing on the perspectives of Carl Menger and Joseph Alois Schumpeter, the paper argues that equilibrium theory fails to adequately reflect the fundamental feature of capitalism: change. It highlights that phenomena like financial crises, which occur in real life, cannot be explained by standard textbook economics. The note emphasizes the importance of understanding industrial and economic dynamics that create economic welfare, moving beyond static equilibrium models. Keywords: capitalist dynamics, neo-classical economics, equilibrium theory, financial crises, economic development, Austrian School of Economics, Joseph Alois Schumpeter, Carl Menger.

title: The Benefits and Costs of Alternative Policies for the Management of Pierce's Disease: A Case Study of the Blue-Green Sharpshooter in the Napa Valley
abstract: Replaced with revised version of poster on 07/23/10.Production Economics, Resource /Energy Economics and Policy,
fieldOfStudy: Business, Production Economics, Resource/Energy Economics and Policy
summary: This study examines the benefits and costs of alternative policies for managing Pierce's Disease, focusing on the blue-green sharpshooter in the Napa Valley. Through a case study approach, the authors analyze how neighboring vineyard owners' control choices influence each other. They develop and parameterize a bio-economic model using interviews with vineyard managers, focusing on blocks with varying disease incidence. The model aims to understand and predict grower behavior under different scenarios, such as new control techniques or changes in disease spread, providing insights into optimal disease management strategies within agricultural economics.

title: Optimal Parochialism: The Dynamics of Trust and Exclusion in Networks
abstract: Networks such as ethnic credit associations, close-knit residential neighborhoods, 'old boy' networks, and ethnically linked businesses play an important role in economic life but have been little studied by economists. These networks are often supported by cultural distinctions between insiders and outsiders and engage in exclusionary practices which we call parochialism. We provide an economic analysis of parochial networks in which the losses incurred by not trading with outsiders are offset by an enhanced ability to enforce informal contracts by fostering trust among insiders. We first model one-shot social interactions among self-regarding agents, demonstrating that trust (i.e., cooperating without using information about one's trading partner) is a best response in a mixed-strategy Nash equilibrium if the quality of information about one's partner is sufficiently high. We show that since larger networks have lower quality information about specific individuals and greater trading opportunities, there may be an optimal (payoff-maximizing) network size. We then model the growth and decline of networks, as well as their equilibrium size and number. We show that in the absence of parochialism, networks may not exist, and the appropriate level of parochialism may implement an optimal network size. Finally, we explore the welfare implications and reasons for the evolutionary success of exclusion on parochial and other grounds.
summary: This paper presents an economic analysis of parochial networks, such as ethnic credit associations and 'old boy' networks, which engage in exclusionary practices. The authors model how the losses from not trading with outsiders are offset by enhanced enforcement of informal contracts and trust among insiders. They demonstrate that trust can be a best response in a mixed-strategy Nash equilibrium if information quality is high, suggesting an optimal network size. The research also explores network growth, decline, and equilibrium, showing that parochialism may be crucial for network existence and optimal size, with implications for welfare and the evolutionary success of exclusion.

title: Educational Outcomes and House Values: A Test of the Value-Added Approach
abstract: We use house price hedonics to compare the extent that homeowners value traditional measures of school quality or the “value added” of schooling. Unlike other studies, we use spatial statistics as an identification strategy. Based on our study of 310 school districts and 77,000 house transactions, we find little support for the value added model. Instead, we find that households consistently value a district’s average proficiency test scores and expenditures. The elasticity of house prices with respect to school expenditures is 0.49 and an increase in test scores by one standard deviation, ceteris paribus, raises house prices by 7.1%.
summary: This study investigates whether homeowners value traditional school quality metrics or "value-added" schooling by analyzing house price hedonics. Utilizing spatial statistics as an identification strategy, the researchers examined 310 school districts and 77,000 house transactions. The findings indicate little support for the value-added model; instead, households consistently value average proficiency test scores and school expenditures. An increase in test scores by one standard deviation raises house prices by 7.1%, and the elasticity of house prices with respect to school expenditures is 0.49. Key terms include house prices, hedonic model, capitalization, school quality, value added, and achievement test scores.
